{"uri": "8241286416", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "12:58:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T12:58:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T12:58:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.thehindu.com/news/international/nepal-plane-crash-saurya-airlines-kathmandu-death-toll-highlights-july-24-2024/article68440504.ece", "title": "Nepal Plane Crash highlights: Flight crashes during takeoff killing 18 at Kathmandu airport; pilot sole survivor", "body": "At least 18 passengers, including a Yemeni national, and a child, were killed after a domestic plane with 19 people on board slipped off the runway and crashed on July 24 while trying to take off from the airport serving Nepal's capital Kathmandu.\n\nThe pilot has injuries to his eyes but his life is not in any danger, said a doctor at Kathmandu Medical College Hospital\n\nTimeline | Deadliest plane crashes in Nepal\n\nA press statement issued by the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said the Saurya Airlines domestic plane, which was scheduled to head to the resort town of Pokhara, took off at 11:11 a.m. local time from Kathmandu airport and turned right but crashed moments later in the eastern section of the airport.\n\nFollowing the accident, services at the Kathmandu airport were halted briefly before being resumed, the airport authorities said.\n\nPrime Minister KP Sharma Oli and Home Minister Ramesh Lekh separately visited the accident site to gather details about the incident and provide necessary directives.\n\nMr. Oli said he was deeply saddened by the tragic deaths in the crash and was at the site to inquire about the cause of the air crash with the Civil Aviation Authority's officials. He urged all for patience at this hour of grief.\n\n- PTI\n\nNepal's aviation authority identified one of the passengers as a child named Adhiraj Sharma, who was the son of Manu Raj Sharma, a technician of Saurya Airlines.\n\nSharma's wife Priza Khatiwada and their four-year old son Adhiraj died in the crash.\n\nA statement issued by the airline said that Priza and her son were initially identified as employees of the company, but it was later revealed that they were passengers.\n\n- PTI\n\nSource Aviation Safety Report - 2023, Nepal.jpg\n\nAccording to local media reports, the deadly Saurya Airlines aircraft, which crashed during takeoff resulting in the death of 18 people, was on a test flight.\n\nThe flight, with call sign 9N-AME, was undergoing a C Check, which is a comprehensive test that a plane has to pass on a regular basis. The plane was headed to a hangar in the Pokhara International Airport for a part check-up, reported Nepali Times.\n\nIt is unclear why a test flight was carrying so many passengers, it added.\n\nIn the last three decades, over 50 flights have crashed in Nepal. The country ranks 33 out of the 207 countries ordered based on the number of plane crashes between 1990 and 2023 . With 1,578 plane crashes, the U.S. leads the list, followed by Russia (464) and Canada (369). India ranks 13, with 99 crashes in the period.\n\nClick here to read a detailed data analysis on the crashes that have plagued Nepal's aviation history\n\nA press statement issued by the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said the Saurya Airlines plane had taken off at 11:11 a.m. from Kathmandu and was heading to resort town of Pokhara.\n\nThe plane had already taken off and turned right before it crashed in the eastern section of the airport, the statement said.\n\nFootage from the spot showed dramatic scenes of the plane speeding down the runway before a fire breaks out with high flames and thick black smoke billowing from the wreckage.\n\n- Agencies\n\nThe Saurya Airlines aircraft which crashed today had just taken off from Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. The plane was carrying 238 people but there were no serious injuries.\n\nThe Kathmandu airport, the main airport serving Nepal, is located inside a valley surrounded by mountains on most sides. It is considered a challenging airport for pilots and bigger planes have to come through an opening on the mountain to land. It is right next to the city. The airport is surrounded by houses and neighborhoods.\n\n- Agencies\n\nA passenger plane carrying 19 people crashed during takeoff in Kathmandu on Wednesday with the pilot surviving but \"many\" others aboard dead, police in the Nepali capital\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight was carrying two crew and 17 of the company's staff members, Nepali police spokesman Dan Bahadur Karki told AFP.\n\nEighteen Nepalis and one foreigner were aboard the flight, Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority told AFP, adding he did not have any details on the latter's nationality.\n\n- AFP\n\nFollowing the fatal plane crash of Saurya Airlines which killed at least 18 passengers onboard, Nepal's Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu has temporarily shut down operations.\n\n- Reuters\n\nPolice say 18 bodies have been recovered after a plane carrying 19 people slipped off the runway at a Nepal airport\n\nNepal authorities inspect the wreckage of the crashed flight in Kathmandu on July 24, 2024. Photo: X/@NepalPoliceHQ\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance -- issues compounded by the mountainous republic's treacherous geography.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThat accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach to Kathmandu airport.\n\nEarlier that year a Thai Airways aircraft had crashed near the same airport, killing 113 people.\n\n- AFP\n\nSmoke rises from the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal, Wednesday, July 24, 2024. State television in Nepal says a plane has slipped off the runway and crashed while trying to take off from Kathmandu airport. (AP Photo/Agniia Galdanova)\n\nAt least 18 people onboard the ill-fated Saurya Airlines aircraft have been killed after the flight crashed upon takeoff, reported Nepal's national news agency.\n\nThe domestic plane with 19 people on board slipped off the runway and crashed while trying to take off from the airport serving Nepal's capital.\n\nA passenger plane carrying 19 people crashed during takeoff in Kathmandu on Wednesday with the pilot surviving but \"many\" others aboard dead, police in the Nepali capital told AFP.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight was carrying two crew and 17 of the company's staff members for a test flight, Nepali police spokesman Dan Bahadur Karki told AFP.\n\nThe plane crashed at around 11:15 am (0530 GMT), the military said in a statement, adding that the army's quick response team had been lending assistance with rescue efforts.\n\n- AFP", "source": {"uri": "thehindu.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Hindu"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": It was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians and was going for regular maintenance to the new airport in Pokhara, which opened in January and is equipped with aircraft maintenance hangars, they said.\n\n\"Shortly after takeoff ... the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nEighteen of those on board were Nepali citizens while one engineer was from Yemen, Saurya said.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, a spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nTelevision images showed firefighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting to its right before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields, and bodies being carried to ambulances on stretchers as local residents looked on.\n\n\"The plane was scheduled to undergo maintenance for a month beginning Thursday. ... It is unclear why it crashed,\" said Mukesh Khanal, head of marketing at Saurya Airlines.\n\nKathmandu airport was closed temporarily after the crash but reopened within hours, officials said.\n\nA Saurya Airlines official said the plane was a 50-seat Bombardier CRJ-200 aircraft.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, exacerbated by many airports in the Himalayan country being located in remote hills and near peaks shrouded in clouds. Nepal is home to eight of the world's 14 tallest mountains.\n\nLocated in the heart of the Kathmandu Valley, the country's main airport is ringed by mountains, affecting wind directions and intensity in the area and making takeoffs and landings a challenge for pilots.\n\nNearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in Nepal since 2000. The deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nMost recently, at least 72 people Shortly after takeoff, the aircraft \"veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway.\"\n\nThe aviation authority said rescue operations were initiated immediately and, after getting the fire under control, 18 people were found dead.\n\nThe plane was headed to Pokhara for maintenance, police said on social media, and all 19 passengers were airline employees. {"uri": "8241023215", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:21:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:21:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:20:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/plane-crash-at-nepals-kathmandu-airport-kills-18/article_11d76318-2bbd-58ec-9918-517947eee19c.html", "title": "Plane crash at Nepal's Kathmandu airport kills 18", "body": "A view shows wreckage of a Saurya Airlines plane that caught fire after skidding off the runway while taking off at Tribhuvan International Airport, in Kathmandu, Nepal, July 24, 2024. REUTERS/Navesh Chitrakar\n\nKATHMANDU (Reuters) -Eighteen people were killed when a regional passenger plane belonging to Nepal's Saurya Airlines crashed and caught fire while taking off from the capital Kathmandu on Wednesday, officials said.\n\nThe plane, carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, was going for regular maintenance to Nepal's new Pokhara airport, which opened in January and is equipped with aircraft maintenance hangars, they said.\n\n\"Shortly after takeoff ... the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nEighteen of those on board were Nepali citizens while one engineer was from Yemen, Saurya said.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nTelevision visuals showed fire fighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting to its right before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields, and bodies being carried to ambulances on stretchers as local residents looked on.\n\n\"The plane was scheduled to undergo maintenance for a month beginning Thursday ... It is unclear why it crashed,\" said Mukesh Khanal, marketing head of Saurya Airlines.\n\nKathmandu airport was closed temporarily following the crash but reopened within hours, officials said.\n\nA Saurya Airlines official said the plane was a 50-seater CRJ-200 aircraft with the registration 9N-AME.\n\nNEPAL'S POOR AIR SAFETY RECORD\n\nAccording to Flightradar24 flight tracking, Saurya currently operates two CRJ-200 regional jets, a programme that was owned by Canada's Bombardier but which was bought by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in 2020.\n\nSaurya says it has another CRJ-200 in its fleet.\n\nBombardier referred questions about the incident to Canada-based MHI RJ Aviation Group, which did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nEstablished in 2014, Saurya says on its website that it has introduced the \"jet experience\" on Nepal's domestic routes and that it flies to five destinations.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, exacerbated by many airlines in the Himalayan country flying to small airports in remote hills and near peaks shrouded in clouds. Nepal is home to eight of the world's 14 tallest mountain peaks.\n\nLocated in the heart of the Kathmandu Valley, the country's main airport is ringed by mountains, affecting wind directions and intensity in the area and making takeoff and landing a challenge for pilots.\n\nNearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in Nepal since 2000. The deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, and nearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in the Himalayan country since 2000.\n\nThe deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nMost recently, at least 72 people were killed in a Yeti airlines crash in January 2023 that was later attributed to the pilots mistakenly cutting off power.\n\nFlightradar24 said it did not track the crashed Saurya flight because the aircraft \"was not equipped with a modern ADS-B transponder\".\n\n(Reporting by Kathmandu newsroom; Additional reporting by Lisa Barrington in Seoul, Ainnie Arif and Shivani Tanna; Writing by Sakshi Dayal; Editing by YP Rajesh and Raju {"uri": "8241082715", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:57:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:57:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:55:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-13667355/Terrifying-moment-Nepal-passenger-plane-crashes-explodes-killing-18.html", "title": "Terrifying moment Nepal passenger plane crashes & explodes killing 18", "body": "This is the shocking moment a passenger plane crashed and killed 18 people in Nepal after skidding off the runway and exploding. Footage shows the Bombardier CRJ 200 plane flying low above the runway before suddenly tilting sideways and quickly sailing nose-first towards the ground.\n\nThe aircraft exploded into a fireball after it crashed, with black smoke billowing into the sky while horrified bystanders watched on from an airport shuttle bus. The plane operated by Saurya Airlines was travelling to the resort town of Pokhara when it skidded off the runway at the Tribhuvan International Airport in the capital Kathmandu during take-off at around 11am local time (6.15am UK time).\n\nThe plane was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians to Pokhara city to repair another aircraft, officials said. The pilot was the only one onboard to survive, as officials said that 18 people had died in the crash. Videos from the crash site show firefighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky, with other footage showing rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields.\n\nBodies were carried to ambulances on stretchers as local residents looked on, local media footage showed. 'Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,' said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport. The pilot of the plane has been taken to the Kathmandu Medical College Hospital for treatment, said a doctor at the hospital who was not authorised to speak to media.\n\nThe pilot has injuries to the eyes but his life is not in any danger, the doctor added. Tribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crews worked. It is monsoon rainy season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash.\n\nVisibility was low across the capital, however, although it is not clear whether this contributed to the crash or why the plane skidded off the runway in the first place. Saurya Airlines operates two Bombardier CRJ 200 aircrafts on domestic routes - both are around 20 years old, according to Flight Radar 24. Nepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, and nearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in the Himalayan country since 2000.\n\nThe deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people. Most recently, on July 11, 2023, six people were killed in a helicopter crash in central Nepal. The chopper, which departed from Solukhunvhu district, home to Mount Everest and other high mountain peaks, had five Mexican nationals and one Nepali pilot on board.\n\nEarlier last year 72 people were killed in a Yeti airlines crash in January that was later attributed to the pilots mistakenly cutting off power. It was the worst air crash in the country since 1992. On March 12, 2018, 51 of 71 people on a Bangladeshi airliner operated by US-Bangla Airlines died when it crashed in cloudy weather as it came in to land at the Nepalese capital's hill-ringed airport.\n\nSeveral British citizens died in plane crashes in Nepal, most recently on September 28, 2012, when a small propeller-driven Dornier aircraft struck a bird and crashed shortly after takeoff from Kathmandu, killing 19 people, including seven British and five Chinese passengers.\n\nIt comes after more two years prior, on August 24, 2010, 14 people - including four Americans, a Japanese and British national - were killed when their small plane crashed in bad weather in Nepal. It was operated by privately held Agni Air.\n\nWant more stories like this from the Daily Mail? {"uri": "8240958091", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:41:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:41:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:40:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.indiatvnews.com/news/world/nepal-s-unfortunate-history-of-plane-crashes-a-look-at-major-aviation-accidents-since-2000-terrain-weather-infrastructure-discipline-updates-2024-07-24-943449", "title": "Nepal's unfortunate history of plane crashes: A look at major aviation accidents since 2000 | LIST", "body": "Kathmandu: In a tragic accident, a small plane skidded off the runway of the Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA) in Kathmandu and crashed on Wednesday morning, killing all but one person - the pilot Captain Manish Ratna Shakya. The incident has put the spotlight back on Nepal's poor safety record, as nearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in the Himalayan country since 2000.\n\nThe plane was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians to Pokhara city for maintenance checks, Airport Security Chief Arjun Chand Thakuri said. According to the Civil Aviation Authority, the 9N-AME/CRJ 200 call sign aircraft of Saurya Air crashed at 11:11 am (local time) on Wednesday while taking off from Tribhuvan International Airport to Pokhara.\n\nThe plane belonged to local Saurya Airlines, which operates domestic flights in Nepal with two Bombardier CRJ-200 regional jets, both around 20 years old, according to Flight Radar 24. At least 18 passengers were killed as the plane burst into flames after the crash, but the pilot managed to survive with injuries in his eyes.\n\nNepal's poor aviation safety record has been attributed to multiple reasons - from the rough mountainous terrain, unpredictable weather, poor maintenance and aircraft training as well as lack of proper infrastructure and maintenance of aircraft. Furthermore, Nepal has some of the world's most strenuous and remote runways, which pose a challenge for even experienced pilots. This came to the limelight after a Yeti Airlines plane crashed in Pokhara in January 2023, killing all 72 passengers on board.\n\nThe mountainous country sees frequent fluctuations in the weather and it is difficult to operate a flight without a proper weather forecasting mechanism. The deadliest aviation incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people. There have been more than 20 crashes in the last decade alone.\n\nThe Kathmandu Airport, known as one of the riskiest airports in the world, is located right in the middle of the city inside a valley surrounded by mountains on most sides, which makes it a challenge even for experienced pilots and small planes to come through an opening and land safely. It is also surrounded by houses and has a single bumpy runway. Nepal, being a struggling economy, is unable to buy upgraded aircraft and infrastructure that it clearly needs to avert such disasters.\n\nMeanwhile, the Tribhuvan International Airport, which was closed following the crash of the Saurya Airlines plane, has now re-opened and flights operations have resumed, according to the Himalayan Times.\n\n(with inputs from Reuters)", "source": {"uri": The video clip shows the plane engulfed in flames shortly after it skidded off the runway.\n\nThe plane crashed at approximately 11:15 am local time (0530 GMT), as confirmed by Nepal's military in an official statement.\n\nAccording to local news outlet, the Kathmandu Post, the flight was carrying 19 passengers, including the aircrew, on its way to Pokhara, a major tourist destination in the Himalayan nation.\n\nKhabarhub, another local news portal, stated that the plane caught fire after skidding on the runway, releasing a plume of smoke.\n\nIt should be noted that the Saurya Airlines runs exclusively with Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, as mentioned on their website. Notably, Nepal's challenging geography, with its high-altitude runways poses major challenges to most experienced pilots.\n\nThe plane was scheduled to leave for Pokhara from Kathmandu when the accident happened, The Himalayan Times reported. {"uri": "8240969524", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:48:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:48:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:48:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.asiaone.com/asia/plane-crash-nepals-kathmandu-airport-kills-18", "title": "AsiaOne", "body": "KATHMANDU -- Eighteen people were killed when a regional passenger plane belonging to Nepal's Saurya Airlines crashed and caught fire while taking off from the capital Kathmandu on Wednesday (July 24), officials said.\n\nThe plane, carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, was going for regular maintenance to Nepal's new Pokhara airport, which opened in January and is equipped with aircraft maintenance hangars, they said.\n\n\"Shortly after takeoff... the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nEighteen of those on board were Nepali citizens while one engineer was from Yemen, Saurya said.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nTelevision visuals showed fire fighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting to its right before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields, and bodies being carried to ambulances on stretchers as local residents looked on.\n\n\"The plane was scheduled to undergo maintenance for a month beginning Thursday ... It is unclear why it crashed,\" said Mukesh Khanal, marketing head of Saurya Airlines.\n\nKathmandu airport was closed temporarily following the crash but reopened within hours, officials said.\n\nA Saurya Airlines official said the plane was a 50-seater CRJ-200 aircraft with the registration 9N-AME.\n\nAccording to Flightradar24 flight tracking, Saurya currently operates two CRJ-200 regional jets, a programme that was owned by Canada's Bombardier but which was bought by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in 2020.\n\nSaurya says it has another CRJ-200 in its fleet.\n\nBombardier referred questions about the incident to Canada-based MHI RJ Aviation Group, which did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nEstablished in 2014, Saurya says on its website that it has introduced the \"jet experience\" on Nepal's domestic routes and that it flies to five destinations.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, exacerbated by many airlines in the Himalayan country flying to small airports in remote hills and near peaks shrouded in clouds. Nepal is home to eight of the world's 14 tallest mountain peaks.\n\nLocated in the heart of the Kathmandu Valley, the country's main airport is ringed by mountains, affecting wind directions and intensity in the area and making takeoff and landing a challenge for pilots.\n\nNearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in Nepal since 2000. The deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, and nearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in the Himalayan country since 2000.\n\nThe deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nMost recently, at least 72 people were killed in a Yeti airlines crash in January 2023 that was later attributed to the pilots mistakenly cutting off power.\n\nFlightradar24 said it did not track the crashed Saurya flight because the aircraft \"was not equipped with a modern ADS-B transponder\".", {"uri": "8240860944", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:42:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:42:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:41:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/plane-crashes-at-airport-in-nepals-capital-just-after-takeoff-killing-18-people-and-injuring/article_882a11e3-53a9-5629-bff3-d445ec00c947.html", "title": "Plane crashes at airport in Nepal's capital just after takeoff, killing 18 people and injuring pilot", "body": "Nepal army personnel stand by a plane crash site at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal, Wednesday, July 24, 2024. State television in Nepal says a plane has slipped off the runway and crashed while trying to take off from the Kathmandu airport.\n\nKATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) -- A domestic plane crashed Wednesday just after taking off from the airport serving Nepal's capital, killing 18 people and injuring a pilot who was the lone survivor.\n\nPolice official Basanta Rajauri said authorities have pulled out all 18 bodies. The only survivor was the pilot, who was taken to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital for treatment, said a doctor at the hospital who was not authorized to speak to media.\n\nThe pilot has injuries to the eyes but is not in any danger, the doctor said.\n\nA press statement issued by the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said the Saurya Airlines plane had taken off at 11:11 a.m. from Kathmandu and was heading to resort town of Pokhara.\n\nThe plane had already taken off and turned right before it crashed in the eastern section of the airport, the statement said.\n\nThe bodies have been taken to the T.U. Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for autopsy. The airline manifest showed there were two pilots and 17 passengers on board, among them there was only one female. The crew and 16 passengers were Nepali nationals with one identified as foreigner but no nationality was disclosed.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crew and investigators began their work.\n\nIt is monsoon rainy season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Visibility was low across the capital, however.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes.\n\nThe Kathmandu airport, the main airport serving Nepal, is located inside a valley surrounded by mountains on most sides. It is considered a challenging airport for pilots and bigger planes have to come through an opening on the mountain to land. It is right next to the city. The airport is surrounded by houses and neighborhoods.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. All 68 individuals on that flight were killed in the accident.\n\nUpdate: At least 18 people were killed when a Saurya Airlines plane crashed and caught fire during takeoff from Kathmandu, Nepal's capital, today, according to the BBC. The pilot, who survived and was hospitalized, was the only survivor among the 19 people on board, which included technical staff. The aircraft was on a test flight from Kathmandu to the popular tourist destination of Pokhara. {"uri": "8241002514", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:09:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:09:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:08:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/24/plane-crash-at-nepals-kathmandu-airport-kills-18-pilot-only-survivor", "title": "Plane crash at Nepal's Kathmandu airport kills 18; pilot only survivor", "body": "Saurya Airlines plane carrying two crew members and 17 passengers crashes shortly after takeoff and catches fire.\n\nA passenger plane has crashed and caught fire shortly after taking off from Nepal's capital, Kathmandu, killing 18 people, aviation officials say.\n\nThe pilot was the only survivor of Wednesday's crash and was being treated in hospital, the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nNineteen people were on the test flight conducted by the domestic carrier Saurya Airlines, including technical staff members and two crew members.\n\nThe incident took place right after the 11:11am (05:26 GMT) takeoff of the 50-seat Bombardier CRJ200, the aviation authority said. The plane then turned right and crashed into the eastern section of the airport, the statement said. It was on its way to the resort town of of Pokhara. The cause of the crash is being investigated.\n\nA doctor at Kathmandu Medical College Hospital told The Associated Press news agency that the pilot had suffered injuries to the eyes \"but is not in any danger\".\n\nEighteen Nepalis, including one child, and a Yemeni national were on the plane, the aviation authority confirmed.\n\nThe bodies were taken to the TU Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for autopsy.\n\nImages of the aftermath shared by Nepal's military showed the plane's fuselage split apart and charred.\n\nBroadcast images showed the bodies being carried to ambulances on stretchers. Other visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the burned remains of the plane.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, was closed for several hours as emergency workers and investigators began their work.\n\nThe airport is located inside a valley surrounded by mountains on most sides. It is considered a challenging airport for pilots, and bigger planes have to come through an opening on a mountain to land.\n\nNepal's aviation industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as local and international trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut the Himalayan country has a poor aviation safety record with a spate of deadly light plane and helicopter crashes over the decades.\n\nMuch of this is attributed to insufficient training and maintenance, which are compounded by the country's treacherous geography.\n\nNepal also has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on. Many are flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can change quickly in the mountains, creating dangerous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023 when a Yeti Airlines flight crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 people on board.\n\nIn 2018, at least 49 people were killed when a Bangladeshi plane carrying more than 70 people crashed and burst into flames as it landed in Kathmandu.\n\nIn 1992, all 167 people on board a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach at Kathmandu airport.\n\nEarlier that same year, a Thai Airways aircraft had crashed near the same airport, killing 113 people.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8241003331", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:09:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:09:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:08:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/world/asia-pacific/2024/07/24/plane-crash-kills-18-at-nepals-kathmandu-airport/", "title": "Plane crash kills 18 at Nepal's Kathmandu airport", "body": "Pilot is sole survivor after regional passenger plane veered and caught fire while taking off from capital\n\nEighteen people were killed when a regional passenger plane belonging to Nepal's Saurya Airlines crashed and caught fire while taking off from the capital Kathmandu on Wednesday, officials said.\n\nThe plane, carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, was going for regular maintenance to Nepal's new Pokhara airport, which opened in January and is equipped with aircraft maintenance hangars, they said.\n\n\"Shortly after take-off ... the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nEighteen of those on board were Nepali citizens while one engineer was from Yemen, Saurya said.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said a spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nTelevision footage showed firefighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting to its right before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in fields, and bodies being carried to ambulances on stretchers as residents looked on.\n\n\"The plane was scheduled to undergo maintenance for a month beginning Thursday ... it is unclear why it crashed,\" said Mukesh Khanal, marketing head of Saurya Airlines.\n\nKathmandu airport was closed temporarily following the crash but reopened within hours, officials said.\n\nA Saurya Airlines official said the plane was a 50-seater CRJ-200 aircraft with the registration 9N-AME. According to Flightradar24 flight tracking, Saurya currently operates two CRJ-200 regional jets, a programme that was owned by Canada's Bombardier but which was bought by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in 2020.\n\nSaurya says it has another CRJ-200 in its fleet.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, exacerbated by many airlines in the Himalayan country flying to small airports in remote hills and near peaks shrouded in clouds. Nepal is home to eight of the world's 14 tallest mountain peaks.\n\nLocated in the heart of the Kathmandu Valley, the country's main airport is ringed by mountains, affecting wind directions and intensity in the area and making take-off and landing a challenge for pilots.\n\nNearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in Nepal since 2000. The deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nMost recently, at least 72 people were killed in a Yeti airlines crash in January 2023 that was later attributed to the pilots mistakenly cutting off power. - Reuters", "source": {"uri": "irishtimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8241067246", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:46:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:46:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:46:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/world/plane-crash-at-nepals-kathmandu-airport-kills-18-post-5692726", "title": "Plane Crash at Nepal's Kathmandu Airport Kills 18", "body": "KATHMANDU -- Eighteen people were killed when a regional passenger plane belonging to Nepal's Saurya Airlines crashed and caught fire while taking off from the capital Kathmandu on Wednesday, officials said.\n\nThe plane, carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, was going for regular maintenance to Nepal's new Pokhara airport, which opened in January and is equipped with aircraft maintenance hangars, they said.\n\n\"Shortly after takeoff...the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nEighteen of those on board were Nepali citizens while one engineer was from Yemen, Saurya said.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nTelevision visuals showed fire fighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting to its right before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields, and bodies being carried to ambulances on stretchers as local residents looked on.\n\n\"The plane was scheduled to undergo maintenance for a month beginning Thursday...It is unclear why it crashed,\" said Mukesh Khanal, marketing head of Saurya Airlines.\n\nKathmandu airport was closed temporarily following the crash but reopened within hours, officials said.\n\nSaurya says it has another CRJ-200 in its fleet.\n\nBombardier referred questions about the incident to Canada-based MHI RJ Aviation Group, which did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nEstablished in 2014, Saurya says on its website that it has introduced the \"jet experience\" on Nepal's domestic routes and that it flies to five destinations.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, exacerbated by many airlines in the Himalayan country flying to small airports in remote hills and near peaks shrouded in clouds. Nepal is home to eight of the world's 14 tallest mountain peaks.\n\nLocated in the heart of the Kathmandu Valley, the country's main airport is ringed by mountains, affecting wind directions and intensity in the area and making takeoff and landing a challenge for pilots.\n\nNearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in Nepal since 2000. The deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nMost recently, at least 72 people were killed in a Yeti airlines crash in January 2023 that was later attributed to the pilots mistakenly cutting off power.\n\nFlightradar24 said it did not track the crashed Saurya flight because the {"uri": "8240815682", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:14:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:14:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:13:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.indiatvnews.com/news/world/nepal-plane-crash-who-is-the-lone-survivor-of-kathmandu-accident-that-killed-several-passengers-pilot-manish-ratna-shakya-2024-07-24-943425", "title": "Nepal plane crash: Who is the lone survivor of Kathmandu accident that killed 18? DETAILS", "body": "Kathmandu: A tragic incident occurred as a small plane caught fire after skidding off the runway at the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu and crashed on Wednesday while trying to takeoff, killing 18 out of 19 passengers. Only the pilot of the CRJ200 aircraft managed to survive the deadly incident.\n\nThe plane was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians to Pokhara city for maintenance checks, Airport Security Chief Arjun Chand Thakuri said. According to the Civil Aviation Authority, the 9N-AME/CRJ 200 call sign aircraft of Saurya Air crashed at 11:11 am (local time) on Wednesday while taking off from Tribhuvan International Airport to Pokhara.\n\nThe plane belonged to local Saurya Airlines, which operates domestic flights in Nepal with two Bombardier CRJ-200 regional jets, both around 20 years old, according to Flight Radar 24. According to eyewitnesses, the plane was taking off from the Southern end of the runway when it suddenly flipped with the wing tip hitting the ground.\n\nThe captain has been identified as Captain Manish Ratna Shakya, who is an airline pilot of the CRJ200 regional aircraft and also the Chief of Operations at Saurya Airlines, according to the official website of the airline. According to his LinkedIn profile, he has been working at Saurya Airlines for over nine years, after a nearly three-year tenure at Simrik Airlines. He has completed his education at St. Xavier's School.\n\nThe 37-year-old Captain Shakya rescued from the wreckage and taken to KMC Hospital, Sinamangal for treatment, according to the police. He is the lone survivor of the crash, as 18 out of 19 passengers aboard the aircraft have been confirmed killed. The pilot has injuries to the eyes but is not in any danger, said a doctor at the hospital.\n\nNepal has been criticised for its poor air safety record, with the deadliest incident occurring in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people. In January 2023, a Yeti Airlines flight crashed near the central city of Pokhara, killing all 72 passengers on board, including five Indians.\n\nPrior to that, a Tara flight with 22 people on board, including four Indians from Thane, crashed in Nepal's mountainous Mustang district on May 29, 2022, killing all people on board. Bad weather seems to be the main factor behind plane crashes in Nepal. The mountainous country sees frequent fluctuations in the weather and it is difficult to operate a flight without a proper weather forecasting mechanism. In addition, Nepal has some of the world's most strenuous and remote runways, which pose a challenge for even experienced pilots.", "source": {"uri": "indiatvnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8241174843", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "11:51:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T11:51:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T11:50:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://newsable.asianetnews.com/world/how-come-only-pilot-survived-outcry-erupts-over-tragic-nepal-plane-crash-calls-for-investigation-grows-snt-sh4m09", "title": "'How come only pilot survived?': Outcry erupts over tragic Nepal plane crash, calls for investigation grows", "body": "A private Nepalese airline plane crashed during takeoff and erupted in flames at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, resulting in the deaths of 18 people, including a foreign national.\n\nA private Nepalese airline plane crashed during takeoff and erupted in flames at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, resulting in the deaths of 18 people, including a foreign national. The pilot survived but sustained serious injuries. The Nepalese domestic flight, identified as N9AME and operated by Saurya Airlines, was en route to Pokhara for routine maintenance when the incident occurred at 11:11 a.m.\n\nThe Bombardier CRJ-200 aircraft \"suffered a runway excursion and burst into massive flames immediately\", the Search and Rescue Centre of the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nAlso read: Caught on camera: Dramatic moment when out-of-control Saurya Airlines plane crashed in Kathmandu (WATCH)\n\nVideos posted online captured the plane engulfed in flames and smoke, prompting a swift response from fire engines and ambulances at the scene.\n\nThe victims included co-pilot S. Katuwal and 17 Saurya Airlines employees, which comprised a Nepali woman and a Yemeni national. Pilot Captain Manish Shakya, 37, is currently receiving treatment at Kathmandu Model Hospital.\n\nAmong the deceased, 15 perished at the scene, while three others succumbed to their injuries at a local hospital, according to authorities.\n\nFollowing the accident, Kathmandu airport operations were briefly suspended before resuming, as reported by airport officials.\n\nSaurya Airlines, which operates flights to five tourist destinations within Nepal, has a fleet consisting of three Bombardier CRJ-200 jets, as stated on the company's website.\n\nThe incident has sparked significant attention on social media, with many users expressing astonishment that the pilot, Captain Manish Shakya, was the sole survivor among the 18 victims. The focus of social media has been intense, with many questioning how the pilot could survive such a devastating crash. This has led to increasing calls for a thorough investigation into the causes of the accident. Users on various platforms are demanding answers and transparency, expressing concerns over the possible factors that led to the disaster.\n\n\"Pilot is going to jail straight,\" wrote on user on X, while another added, \"How come only the pilot survived?\"\n\nAnother user noted, \"18 people died in plane crash that happened earlier today at TIA, Nepal; however, pilot is the only person who survived. Isn't it a hack to investigate about the incident? Yes, it is because plane crashes in Nepal are not just accident but mass murder due to illegal commissions.\"\n\nHere's a look at some of the other reactions on X following the Nepal plane crash:\n\nNepal has faced criticism for its poor air safety record in recent years, with contributing factors including sudden weather changes, challenging airstrips in rocky terrains, and human error.\n\nAccording to Nepal's civil aviation authority, there have been 914 fatalities from air crashes in the country since the first recorded disaster in August 1955.\n\nIn January of the previous year, a Yeti Airlines aircraft crashed in the resort city of Pokhara, resulting in the deaths of all 72 people on board, including five Indians. The crash was attributed to human error.\n\nOn January 15, 2023, a Yeti Airlines ATR-72 aircraft, registered as 9N-ANC, crashed into the Seti River bank between the old and new airports just minutes before landing. This incident marked the 104th aviation accident in Nepal and was the third deadliest in terms of casualties.\n\nAlso read: Nepal plane crash highlights risks of table-top runways; India has 5 such airports\n\nThe only two incidents with higher death tolls occurred in July and September 1992, involving Thai Airways and Pakistan International Airlines, which resulted in 113 and 167 fatalities, respectively.\n\nEarlier, on May 29, 2022, a Tara Air flight crashed in Nepal's mountainous Mustang district, killing all 22 people on board, including four members of an Indian family. Similarly, in 2016, another Tara Air plane crashed on the same route, resulting in 23 fatalities.\n\nAdditionally, in March 2018, a US-Bangla Airlines flight crashed at Tribhuvan International {"uri": "2024-07-432121721", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "13:02:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T13:02:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T12:47:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.cnc3.co.tt/plane-crashes-after-takeoff-from-nepals-capital-killing-18-people/", "title": "Plane crashes after takeoff from Nepal's capital, killing 18 people", "body": "Photo: Nepal army personnel cordon off a plane crash site at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal, Wednesday, July 24, 2024. State television in Nepal says a plane has slipped off the runway and crashed while trying to take off from the Kathmandu airport. (AP Photo/Sujan Gurung)\n\nA plane crashed Wednesday just after taking off from Nepal's capital, killing 18 people and injuring a pilot who was the lone survivor.\n\nPolice official Basanta Rajauri said authorities have pulled out all 18 bodies. The pilot has injuries to his eyes but his life is not in any danger, said a doctor at Kathmandu Medical College Hospital, where the pilot is being treated. The doctor spoke on condition of anonymity because she was not authorized to speak to media.\n\nA press statement issued by the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said the Saurya Airlines domestic plane, which was scheduled to head to the resort town of Pokhara, took off at 11:11 a.m. local time from Kathmandu airport and turned right but crashed moments later in the eastern section of the airport.\n\nIt is monsoon rain season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Visibility was low across the capital, however.\n\nThe Kathmandu airport, the main airport serving Nepal, is located inside a valley surrounded by mountains on most sides. It is considered a challenging airport for pilots and bigger planes have to come through an opening on the mountain to land. It is right next to the city, and is surrounded by houses and neighbourhoods.\n\nThe bodies have been taken to the T.U. Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for autopsy. The airline manifest showed there were two pilots and 17 passengers on board. The crew and 16 passengers were Nepali nationals and one passenger was identified as a Yemeni national.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crew and investigators began their work.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. {"uri": "8240820823", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:18:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:18:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:16:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/a-plane-slips-off-the-runway-and-crashes-in-nepal-killing-18-people-and-injuring/article_882a11e3-53a9-5629-bff3-d445ec00c947.html", "title": "A plane slips off the runway and crashes in Nepal, killing 18 people and injuring a pilot", "body": "Smoke rises from the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal, Wednesday, July 24, 2024. State television in Nepal says a plane has slipped off the runway and crashed while trying to take off from Kathmandu airport.\n\nKATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) -- A domestic plane crashed Wednesday while taking off from the airport serving Nepal's capital, killing 18 people and injuring a pilot who was the lone survivor.\n\nPolice official Basanta Rajauri said authorities have pulled out all 18 bodies. The only survivor was the pilot, who was taken to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital for treatment, said a doctor at the hospital who was not authorized to speak to media.\n\nThe pilot has injuries to the eyes but is not in any danger, the doctor said.\n\nThe bodies have been taken to the T.U. Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for autopsy. The airline manifest showed there were two pilots and 17 passengers on board, among them there was only one female. The crew and 16 passengers were Nepali nationals with one identified as foreigner but no nationality was disclosed.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines plane was heading from Kathmandu to the resort town of Pokhara.\n\nIt was not clear how it slipped.\n\nLocal media images showed smoke rising and plane wreckage scattered all over a ditch. A fire has been brought under control.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crew worked.\n\nIt is monsoon rainy season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Visibility was low across the capital, however.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes.\n\nThe Kathmandu airport, the main airport serving Nepal, is located inside a valley surrounded by mountains on most sides. It is considered a challenging airport for pilots and bigger planes have to come through an opening on the mountain to land. It is right next to the city. The airport is surrounded by houses and neighborhoods.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. {"uri": "8241062074", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:44:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:44:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:43:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.ntd.com/plane-crash-at-nepals-kathmandu-airport-kills-18-post_1006674.html", "title": "Plane Crash at Nepal's Kathmandu Airport Kills 18", "body": "KATHMANDU -- Eighteen people were killed when a regional passenger plane belonging to Nepal's Saurya Airlines crashed and caught fire while taking off from the capital Kathmandu on Wednesday, officials said.\n\nThe plane, carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, was going for regular maintenance to Nepal's new Pokhara airport, which opened in January and is equipped with aircraft maintenance hangars, they said.\n\n\"Shortly after takeoff...the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nEighteen of those on board were Nepali citizens while one engineer was from Yemen, Saurya said.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nTelevision visuals showed fire fighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting to its right before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields, and bodies being carried to ambulances on stretchers as local residents looked on.\n\n\"The plane was scheduled to undergo maintenance for a month beginning Thursday...It is unclear why it crashed,\" said Mukesh Khanal, marketing head of Saurya Airlines.\n\nKathmandu airport was closed temporarily following the crash but reopened within hours, officials said.\n\nA Saurya Airlines official said the plane was a 50-seater CRJ-200 aircraft with the registration 9N-AME.\n\nAccording to Flightradar24 flight tracking, Saurya currently operates two CRJ-200 regional jets, a programme that was owned by Canada's Bombardier but which was bought by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in 2020.\n\nSaurya says it has another CRJ-200 in its fleet.\n\nBombardier referred questions about the incident to Canada-based MHI RJ Aviation Group, which did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nEstablished in 2014, Saurya says on its website that it has introduced the \"jet experience\" on Nepal's domestic routes and that it flies to five destinations.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, exacerbated by many airlines in the Himalayan country flying to small airports in remote hills and near peaks shrouded in clouds. Nepal is home to eight of the world's 14 tallest mountain peaks.\n\nLocated in the heart of the Kathmandu Valley, the country's main airport is ringed by mountains, affecting wind directions and intensity in the area and making takeoff and landing a challenge for pilots.\n\nNearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in Nepal since 2000. The deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nMost recently, at least 72 people were killed in a Yeti airlines crash in January 2023 that was later attributed to the pilots mistakenly cutting off power.\n\nFlightradar24 said it did not track the crashed Saurya flight because the aircraft \"was not equipped with a modern ADS-B transponder.\"", "source": {"uri": "ntd.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NTD"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8241033219", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:26:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:26:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:26:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/plane-crash-at-nepal's-kathmandu-airport-kills-18/84820638", "title": "Plane crash at Nepal's Kathmandu airport kills 18", "body": "KATHMANDU (Reuters) -Eighteen people were killed when a regional passenger plane belonging to Nepal's Saurya Airlines crashed and caught fire while taking off from the capital Kathmandu on Wednesday, officials said.\n\nThe plane, carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, was going for regular maintenance to Nepal's new Pokhara airport, which opened in January and is equipped with aircraft maintenance hangars, they said.\n\n\"Shortly after takeoff ... the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nEighteen of those on board were Nepali citizens while one engineer was from Yemen, Saurya said.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nTelevision visuals showed fire fighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting to its right before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields, and bodies being carried to ambulances on stretchers as local residents looked on.\n\n\"The plane was scheduled to undergo maintenance for a month beginning Thursday ... It is unclear why it crashed,\" said Mukesh Khanal, marketing head of Saurya Airlines.\n\nKathmandu airport was closed temporarily following the crash but reopened within hours, officials said.\n\nA Saurya Airlines official said the plane was a 50-seater CRJ-200 aircraft with the registration 9N-AME.\n\nNEPAL'S POOR AIR SAFETY RECORD\n\nAccording to Flightradar24 flight tracking, Saurya currently operates two CRJ-200 regional jets, a programme that was owned by Canada's Bombardier but which was bought by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in 2020.\n\nSaurya says it has another CRJ-200 in its fleet.\n\nBombardier referred questions about the incident to Canada-based MHI RJ Aviation Group, which did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nEstablished in 2014, Saurya says on its website that it has introduced the \"jet experience\" on Nepal's domestic routes and that it flies to five destinations.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, exacerbated by many airlines in the Himalayan country flying to small airports in remote hills and near peaks shrouded in clouds. Nepal is home to eight of the world's 14 tallest mountain peaks.\n\nLocated in the heart of the Kathmandu Valley, the country's main airport is ringed by mountains, affecting wind directions and intensity in the area and making takeoff and landing a challenge for pilots.\n\nNearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in Nepal since 2000. The deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, and nearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in the Himalayan country since 2000.\n\nThe deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nMost recently, at least 72 people were killed in a Yeti airlines crash in January 2023 that was later attributed to the pilots mistakenly cutting off power.\n\nFlightradar24 said it did not track the crashed Saurya flight because the aircraft \"was not equipped with a modern ADS-B transponder\".\n\n(Reporting by Kathmandu newsroom; Additional reporting by Lisa Barrington in Seoul, Ainnie Arif and Shivani Tanna; Writing by Sakshi Dayal; Editing by YP Rajesh and Raju {"uri": "2024-07-432271541", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:13:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:13:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:04:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.wccbcharlotte.com/2024/07/24/plane-crashes-just-after-takeoff-from-nepals-capital-killing-18/", "title": "Plane Crashes Just After Takeoff From Nepal's Capital, Killing 18", "body": "1/7\n\nSmoke rises from the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal, Wednesday, July 24, 2024. State television in Nepal says a plane has slipped off the runway and crashed while trying to take off from Kathmandu airport. (AP Photo/Agniia Galdanova)\n\n2/7\n\nNepal army personnel cordon off a plane crash site at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal, Wednesday, July 24, 2024. State television in Nepal says a plane has slipped off the runway and crashed while trying to take off from the Kathmandu airport. (AP Photo/Sujan Gurung)\n\n3/7\n\nNepal army personnel stand by a plane crash site at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal, Wednesday, July 24, 2024. State television in Nepal says a plane has slipped off the runway and crashed while trying to take off from the Kathmandu airport. (AP Photo/Sujan Gurung)\n\n4/7\n\nRescuers search a plane crash site at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal, Wednesday, July 24, 2024. State television in Nepal says a plane has slipped off the runway and crashed while trying to take off from the Kathmandu airport. (AP Photo/Sujan Gurung)\n\n5/7\n\nNepal army personnel cordon off a plane crash site at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal, Wednesday, July 24, 2024. State television in Nepal says a plane has slipped off the runway and crashed while trying to take off from the Kathmandu airport. (AP Photo/Sujan Gurung)\n\n6/7\n\nFirefighters douse fire after a domestic plane belonging to Saurya Airlines crashed just after taking off at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal, Wednesday, July 24, 2024. (AP Photo/Sujan Gurung)\n\n7/7\n\nNepal army personnel sort through the debris after a domestic plane belonging to Saurya Airlines crashed just after taking off at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal, Wednesday, July 24, 2024. (AP Photo/Prabin Ranabhat)\n\nKATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) -- A plane crashed Wednesday just after taking off from Nepal's capital, killing 18 people and injuring a pilot who was the lone survivor.\n\nAll the people aboard the Saurya Airlines flight including the co-pilot were Nepali except for one passenger, who was a Yemeni national, the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said. Authorities have pulled all 18 bodies from the wreckage, police official Basanta Rajauri said.\n\nThe Bombardier CRJ 200 plane was heading to Nepal's second-most populous city of Pokhara for maintenance work and most of the passengers aboard were either mechanics or airline employees, airport officials said. They were speaking on condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak to reporters.\n\nThe pilot has injuries to his eyes but his life is not in any danger, said a doctor at Kathmandu Medical College Hospital, where the pilot is being treated. The doctor spoke on condition of anonymity because she was not authorized to speak to reporters.\n\nThe plane took off from the Kathmandu airport at 11:11 a.m. local time and turned right but crashed moments later in the eastern section of the airport, the Civil Aviation Authority said in a statement.\n\n\"I came out and saw a plane had crashed and there was huge smoke and fire coming out,\" said Ram Kumar Khatri Chetri, who own a car parts store barely 100 meters (330 feet) from the crash site. \"There was chaos and confusion.\"\n\n\"It was just horrible and there was no way that anyone could just go near the plane and help out when there was so much fire and even explosions,\" he said.\n\nIt is the monsoon rain season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Visibility was low across the capital, however.\n\nThe Kathmandu airport, the main airport serving Nepal, is inside a valley surrounded by mountains that make takeoffs and landings challenging for pilots. The airport is right next to the city, and is surrounded by houses and neighborhoods.\n\nThe bodies have been taken to the T.U. Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for autopsy. The airline manifest showed there were two pilots and 17 passengers on board.\n\nGrieving relatives gathered at the hospital forensics department to collect the bodies of their loved ones, though they are not likely to be released for a day or two.\n\nThe co-pilot Sasant Katuwal had been flying only for the past three years after completing training in France, his uncle Dhyan Bahadur Khadka said at the hospital. He had just received a visa to go to Germany for further training and was excited about that, Khadka said.\n\nKhadka said his nephew had a bright future in aviation. \"His parents are grieving the loss of their only child,\" Khadka said. \"He was unmarried. He was not just tall and handsome, but he was well behaved,\"\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, was closed for hours as emergency crew and investigators began their work.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. The plane was carrying 238 people but there were no serious injuries.\n\nFacebook\n\nTwitter\n\nPinterest\n\nLinkedin", "source": {"uri": "wccbcharlotte.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WCCB {"uri": "8241192661", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "12:01:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T12:01:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T12:01:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.indiatvnews.com/news/world/nepal-plane-crash-saurya-airlines-employee-his-wife-and-son-among-18-killed-in-tragic-plane-crash-2024-07-24-943480", "title": "Nepal: Saurya Airlines employee, his wife and son among 18 killed in tragic plane crash", "body": "Kathmandu: In the tragic Saurya Airlines plane crash in Nepal's national capital, eighteen people were killed, including three members of the same family. Manuraj Sharma, employed as a technical staff member at the ill-fated Saurya Airlines, his wife Priza Khatiwada, who worked as a computer operator at the Ministry of Energy, Water Resources and Irrigation, and their son Adhiraj Sharma, all died in the accident, Kathmandu Post reported.\n\nThe Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal (CAAN) confirmed the death toll of 18 from the crash of the Saurya Airlines aircraft, identified as Flight 9 NAME bound for Pokhara. Departing Kathmandu at 11:11 am on Wednesday, the flight suffered a runway excursion and subsequently crashed into a gorge on the eastern side of Tribhuvan International Airport. Captain MR Shakya was rescued and is currently undergoing treatment at KMC Hospital in Sinamangal, as reported by Nepal Police.\n\nThe plane, carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, was going for regular maintenance to Nepal's new Pokhara airport, which opened in January and is equipped with aircraft maintenance hangars, they said. \"Shortly after takeoff ... the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nEighteen of those on board were Nepali citizens while one engineer was from Yemen, Saurya said. \"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nTelevision visuals showed firefighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting to its right before it crashed. Other visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields, and bodies being carried to ambulances on stretchers as local residents looked on.\n\n\"The plane was scheduled to undergo maintenance for a month beginning Thursday ... It is unclear why it crashed,\" said Mukesh Khanal, marketing head of Saurya Airlines. We are in the process of taking them for post-mortem.\"\n\nThe flight was being conducted for either technical or maintenance purposes, Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority told AFP without giving further details.\n\nBahadur and Bhul were unable to confirm the nationality of the sole foreigner aboard.\n\nImages of the aftermath shared by Nepal's military showed the plane's fuselage split apart and burnt to a husk.\n\nPeople stand at the site after a Saurya Airlines' plane crashed during takeoff at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu\n\nAround a dozen soldiers in camouflage were standing on top of the wreckage with the surrounding earth coated in fire retardant.\n\nThe plane crashed at around 11:15 am (0530 GMT), the military said in a statement, adding that the army's quick response team had been lending assistance with rescue efforts.\n\nNews portal Khabarhub reported that the airplane had caught fire after skidding on the runway.\n\nThe plane was scheduled to fly on Nepal's busiest air route between Kathmandu and Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\n- Plagued by poor safety -\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance -- issues compounded by the mountainous republic's treacherous geography.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThat accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane people have been confirmed dead following the crash of a passenger plane in Kathmandu, Nepal's capital on Wednesday, AFP reported.\n\nThe small plane crashed on takeoff with the pilot rescued from the flaming wreckage, but all 18 others aboard were killed, police in the Nepali capital told AFP.\n\nThe plane was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians to Pokhara city to repair another aircraft, when the incident occurred.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nTelevision visuals showed firefighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky.\n\nThey also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields.\n\nBodies were carried to ambulances on stretchers as residents looked on, the television showed.\n\nThe plane was a Bombardier, officials said, and media reported it belonged to local Saurya Airlines.\n\nOfficial also added that the airport has been temporarily closed.\n\nSaurya operates domestic flights in Nepal with two Bombardier CRJ-200 regional jets, both around 20 years old, according to Flight Radar 24.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a {"uri": "8241032333", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:26:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:26:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:25:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/plane-crash-nepal-kathmandu-deaths-1929455", "title": "18 dead in fiery plane crash", "body": "Eighteen people died during a plane crash on Wednesday morning at the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal.\n\nA domestic Saurya Airlines plane bound for the city of Pokhara experienced a runway excursion during takeoff, causing it to flip and crash, resulting in a devastating fire, according to the local newspaper, The Kathmandu Post.\n\nEyewitnesses told the outlet that the plane was taking off from the southern end of the runway when its wing tip hit the ground, leading to the accident.\n\nThe plane then plunged into a gorge between a hangar and the radar station, producing thick billows of smoke visible from the airport.\n\nThe crash resulted in casualties, with 18 bodies recovered from the site, the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal (CAAN) confirmed to The Kathmandu Post. The flight had 19 people on board, including crew members. The sole survivor, Captain MR Shakya, was rushed to the hospital for medical treatment, airport spokesperson Subash Jha told the outlet.\n\nNepal Police said the aircraft was on its way to Pokhara for maintenance and all passengers were airline staff, The Kathmandu Post reported. According to its website, Saurya Airlines only uses one aircraft, the Bombardier CRJ 200, which can carry up to 50 passengers.\n\nThe cause of the accident is still unknown, Newsweek contacted local authorities for comment.\n\nEmergency response teams, including police and firefighters, undertook rescue operations at the crash site.\n\nNepal's airports are considered some of the most dangerous in the world. Tribhuvan International Airport in particular faces challenging geography as it's surrounded by gorges and valleys, making it difficult to navigate, the Economic Times reported. Concerns over the safety record of Nepalese airlines led the European Union to ban them from traveling to EU countries in 2013.\n\nA 2019 safety report from Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority found that \"the diversity of weather patterns together with hostile topography are the main challenges surrounding aircraft operations in Nepal.\"\n\nThe terrain is especially difficult for helicopters and small aircraft, which have 19 seats or less, according to the report. Nepal is home to the most challenging airports on the planet, as reported by Forbes, with Tenzin-Hillary Airport in Lukla at number one. This is due to issues such as strong winds, low pressure due to high altitude, and shorter runways.\n\nIn January 2023, Nepal saw its worst domestic plane crash in history, according to The Kathmandu Post. The aircraft traveled the same route as the Saurya Airlines plane and crashed just a few minutes before landing killing 68 out of the 72 people on board.", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com",
