{"uri": "2024-07-431747372", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "07:41:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T07:41:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T06:07:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.aol.com/news/plane-19-people-board-slips-060734040.html", "title": "A plane slips off the runway and crashes in Nepal, killing 18 passengers and injuring the pilot", "body": "A plane slips off the runway and crashes in Nepal, killing 18 passengers and injuring the pilot\n\nBINAJ GURUBACHARYA\n\nJuly 24, 2024 at 9:19 AM\n\nKATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) -- A domestic plane slipped off the runway and crashed Wednesday while trying to take off from the airport serving Nepal's capital, killing the 18 passengers and injuring the pilot.\n\nPolice official Basanta Rajauri said authorities have pulled out all 18 bodies. The only survivor was the pilot, who was taken to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital for treatment, said a doctor at the hospital who was not authorized to speak to media.\n\nThe pilot has injuries to the eyes but is not in any danger, the doctor said.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines plane was heading from Kathmandu to the resort town of Pokhara.\n\nIt was not clear how it slipped.\n\nLocal media images showed smoke rising and plane wreckage scattered all over a ditch. A fire has been brought under control.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crew worked.\n\nIt is monsoon rainy season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Visibility was low across the capital, however.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. {"uri": "8240832230", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:26:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:26:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:24:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/business/3028006-tragic-crash-18-killed-in-saurya-airlines-flight-in-kathmandu", "title": "Tragic Crash: 18 Killed in Saurya Airlines Flight in Kathmandu | Business", "body": "A Saurya Airlines plane crashed and caught fire during takeoff from Kathmandu, killing 18 people. The aircraft, carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, was en route for maintenance at Pokhara airport. The captain is the only survivor, and Nepal's air safety history remains under scrutiny.\n\nAt least 18 people were killed after a Nepal's Saurya Airlines plane crashed and caught fire during takeoff from Kathmandu on Wednesday, officials reported.\n\nThe plane, carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, was headed for regular maintenance at the newly opened Pokhara airport. Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Tribhuvan International Airport, mentioned that only the captain survived and is currently hospitalized.\n\nTelevision footage showed firefighters battling the flames and thick black smoke. Clips also revealed the plane barely above the runway before tilting and crashing. Rescue workers were seen combing through the charred wreckage and transporting bodies to ambulances.\n\nThe airport was temporarily shut down. Saurya Airlines revealed the crashed plane was a 50-seater CRJ200 aircraft.\n\nAccording to Flight Radar 24, Saurya operates two CRJ-200 jets, a fleet initially by Bombardier and now under Mitsubishi Heavy Industries since 2020. While Bombardier deferred queries to MHI RJ Aviation Group, the latter did not respond immediately. Established in 2014, Saurya prides itself on offering a 'jet experience' on domestic routes in Nepal.\n\nNepal's air safety has faced criticisms, with nearly 350 fatalities in crashes since 2000. The gravest happened in 1992 when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed, killing 167. {"uri": "8240989392", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:01:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:01:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:00:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/nepal-plane-crash-saurya-airlines-33312976", "title": "Airline pilot only survivor of plane crash horror as 18 confirmed dead", "body": "The pilot of a plane which crashed after skidding on the runway at Kathmandu's airport was the only survivor, it has been confirmed.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight crashed and burst into flames while taking off the at Tribhuvan Airport in Nepal's capital on Wednesday morning. Some 19 people were on board at the time, with 18 dead.\n\nHeading for the resort town of Pokhara, the domestic flight took off at 11.11am local time before disaster struck. A rescue operation was immediately carried out to extinguish the flames an pull people from the wreckage.\n\nPolice official Basanta Rajauri said 18 bodies were recovered, adding that the pilot was the only survivor. The pilot was taken to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital for treatment, a doctor at the hospital who was not authorised to speak to media said.\n\nThe doctor added that the pilot had injuries to the eyes as a result of the crash but was not in any danger. The 19 aboard included technical staff members and two crew members.\n\nAll bodies have been taken to the T.U. Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for autopsy. The airline manifest showed there were two pilots and 17 passengers on board. The crew and 16 passengers were Nepali nationals and one passenger was identified as a Yemeni national.\n\nWhile the country is currently in the midst of monsoon season, it was not raining at the time of the crash, although visibility was low. The exact reason for the plane skidding has yet to be clarified.\n\nA press statement issued by the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said the Saurya Airlines domestic plane, which was scheduled to head to the resort town of Pokhara, took off at 11:11am local time from Kathmandu airport and turned right but crashed moments later in the eastern section of the airport.\n\nNepal has a poor track record when it comes to aviation safety, with at least 72 people killed in a Yeti Airlines crash in Pokhara in January last year. Flight 691 was making its final approach to the town from Kathmandu when it crashed into a river bank.\n\nThose on board included British national Ruan Calum Crighton, 34, with the passengers' final moments broadcast in a chilling Facebook live stream. Surrounded by mountains on most sides and generally considered a challenging airport to land in, Tribhuvan is Nepal's main airport, serving the capital.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.\n\nAnd in 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. The Pokhara-bound Saurya Airlines plane met with the accident at around 11 am.\n\nThe plane was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians to Pokhara city for maintenance checks, Airport Security Chief Arjun Chand Thakuri said. \"It (the plane) caught fire after skidding off the runway at Kathmandu airport and crashing into a field east of the runway,\" Thakuri said.\n\nThe pilot of the aircraft has been taken to a hospital, a security official deployed at the airport told PTI without giving further details. A fire that broke out from the aircraft has been put off, he added. Police and firefighters are carrying out rescue operations at the accident site.\n\nSaurya operates domestic flights in Nepal with two Bombardier CRJ-200 regional jets, both around 20 years old, according to Flight Radar 24. {"uri": "8241168609", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "11:47:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T11:47:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T11:46:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://kashmirobserver.net/2024/07/24/18-killed-as-private-airline-plane-crashes-during-takeoff-at-kathmandu-pilot-survives/", "title": "18 Killed As Private Airline Plane Crashes During Takeoff At Kathmandu, Pilot Survives", "body": "Kathmandu- A private Nepalese airline plane crashed during takeoff and caught fire at the Tribhuvan International Airport here on Wednesday, killing 18 people aboard, including a foreigner, while the pilot survived with major injuries.\n\nThe Nepalese domestic plane N9AME, belonging to Saurya Airlines, was bound for Pokhara for regular maintenance service when the accident occurred at 11.11 am.\n\nThe Bombardier CRJ-200 aircraft \"suffered a runway excursion and burst into massive flames immediately\", the Search and Rescue Centre of the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nVideos posted online showed the plane being enveloped in fire and smoke. Fire engines and ambulances were rushed to the spot after the incident.\n\nThe deceased were identified as co-pilot S Katuwal and 17 employees of the Saurya Airlines, including a Nepali female and a Yemeni national. Pilot captain Manish Shakya, 37, is undergoing treatment at Kathmandu Model Hospital.\n\nOf the deceased, 15 died on the spot while three died during treatment at a local hospital, authorities said.\n\nFollowing the accident, services at the Kathmandu airport were halted briefly before being resumed, the airport authorities said.\n\nSaruya Airlines operates flights to five tourist destinations within Nepal, with a fleet of three Bombardier CRJ-200 jets, according to the company's website.\n\nNepal has been criticised for its poor air safety record in recent years but the reasons also include partly sudden weather changes and partly airstrips located in hard-to-access rocky terrains apart from human error.\n\nAccording to Nepal's civil aviation body, 914 people have died in air crashes in the country since the first disaster was recorded in August 1955.\n\nIn January last year, all 72 people on board, including five Indians, were killed when a Yeti Airlines aircraft crashed in the resort city of Pokhara. The crash was attributed to a human error.\n\nYeti Airlines' 9N-ANC ATR-72 aircraft crashed on the bank of the Seti River between the old airport and the new airport minutes before landing on January 15, 2023, which was the 104th crash in Nepali skies and third biggest in terms of casualties.\n\nThe only incidents in which more people were killed took place in July and September 1992. Those crashes involved aircraft of Thai Airways and Pakistan International Airlines and left 113 and 167 people dead, respectively.\n\nOn May 29, 2022, all 22 people on board, including four members of an Indian family, were killed as a Tara Air plane crashed in Nepal's mountainous Mustang district.\n\nIn 2016, all 23 people aboard were killed when a plane of the same airline flying the same route crashed after takeoff.\n\nIn March 2018, a US-Bangla Air crash occurred at the Tribhuvan International Airport, killing 51 people on board.", "source": {"uri": "kashmirobserver.net", "dataType": {"uri": "2024-07-432349049", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:28:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:28:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T12:18:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.omanobserver.om/article/1156762/world/asia/update-6-plane-crash-at-nepals-kathmandu-airport-kills-18", "title": "UPDATE 6-Plane crash at Nepal's Kathmandu airport kills 18", "body": "A view shows wreckage of a Saurya Airlines plane that caught fire, in Kathmandu, Nepal. -- Reuters\n\nKATHMANDU: Eighteen people were killed when a small passenger plane belonging to Nepal's Saurya Airlines crashed and caught fire while taking off from the capital Kathmandu on Wednesday, officials said.\n\nThe plane, carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, was going for regular maintenance to Nepal's new Pokhara airport, which opened in January last year and is equipped with aircraft maintenance hangars, they said. \"Shortly after takeoff ... the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nNepal's prime minister, K.P. Sharma Oli, visited the crash site and asked people to \"be patient\" in a social media post, without elaborating. An emergency cabinet meeting was called to form a panel to probe the crash, a government spokesman said.\n\nEighteen of those on board the crashed 50-seater CRJ-200 aircraft, with the registration 9N-AME, were Nepali citizens while one engineer was from Yemen, Saurya said.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nTelevision visuals showed fire fighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. Images also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting to its right before it crashed. Other visuals showed rescue workers examining the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields, and bodies being carried to ambulances on stretchers as residents looked on.\n\n\"The plane was scheduled to undergo maintenance for a month beginning Thursday ... It is unclear why it crashed,\" said Mukesh Khanal, marketing head of Saurya Airlines. Kathmandu airport was closed temporarily following the crash but reopened within hours, officials said.\n\nAccording to Flightradar24 flight tracking, Saurya currently operates two CRJ-200 regional jets, a programme that was owned by Canada's Bombardier but which was bought by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in 2020. Saurya says it has another CRJ-200 in its fleet. Bombardier referred questions about the incident to Canada-based MHI RJ Aviation Group, which did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nLocated in the heart of the Kathmandu Valley, the country's main airport is ringed by mountains, affecting wind directions and intensity in the area and making takeoff and landing a challenge for pilots. -- Reuters", "source": {"uri": A fire has been brought under control.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crew worked.\n\nIt is monsoon rainy season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. {"uri": "8240986794", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:59:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:59:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:59:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/nepal-plane-crash-kathmandu-pilot-only-survivor-18-deaths/", "title": "Plane crash in Nepal kills 18 people, with the pilot the sole survivor", "body": "New Delhi -- At least 18 people on board a small plane were killed Wednesday when it crashed shortly after taking off from the airport in Nepal's capital Kathmandu. The pilot of the plane was the lone survivor, national aviation officials said. He was being treated for serious injuries at a local hospital.\n\nA fire broke out on the aircraft not long after it took off from Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport, and it quickly crashed to the ground near one of the runways. The incident happened at around 11:15 local time (12:30 a.m. Eastern), according to a statement by the country's civil aviation authority.\n\nThe statement said the plane \"crashed on the east side of the runway\" and that the fire that had engulfed the aircraft \"was brought under control and the rescue work started immediately.\"\n\nVideos posted online showed the plane flying into the ground at a sharp angle, with its left wing pointed almost straight up into the air, crashing to the ground and being enveloped in flames. Dozens of rescuers, fire engines and ambulances arrived at the crash site, videos showed.\n\nAccording to authorities, rescuers found 18 bodies at the crash site. All of the victims were Nepali nationals apart from one Yemeni.\n\nThe plane belonged to Nepal's Saurya Airlines, which operates domestic flights between the country's five primary airports. Of the 19 people on the flight, 16 were technical staff of the airline, two were crew members, and the other was the pilot who survived.\n\nThe plane was destined for Pokhara, a popular tourist destination in the Himalayan nation known for its mountainous terrain and world-famous peaks, including the Mount Everest.\n\nNepal has a dismal history of aviation accidents, attributed largely to poor safety standards and unpredictable weather.\n\nAt least 68 people were killed when a Yeti Airlines plane crashed while landing at Pokhara in January last year. It was the country's deadliest air disaster since 1992, when 167 people on a Pakistan International Airlines plane were killed in a crash near Kathmandu's Airport.\n\nIn 2022, at least 22 people died when a plane crashed into a mountainside. In 2016, a Tara Air Twin Otter flying from Pokhara to Kathmandu crashed after take-off, killing all 23 people aboard.\n\nAccording to Flight Safety Foundation's Aviation Safety database, there have {"uri": "8240849074", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:34:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:34:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:34:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/nepal-plane-crash-at-kathmandu-airport-kills-18/article_11d76318-2bbd-58ec-9918-517947eee19c.html", "title": "Nepal plane crash at Kathmandu airport kills 18", "body": "A view shows wreckage of a Saurya Airlines plane that caught fire after skidding off the runway while taking off at Tribhuvan International Airport, in Kathmandu, Nepal, July 24, 2024. REUTERS/Navesh Chitrakar\n\nKATHMANDU (Reuters) -At least 18 people were killed when a regional passenger plane belonging to Nepal's Saurya Airlines crashed and caught fire while taking off from the capital Kathmandu on Wednesday, officials said.\n\nThe plane, carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, was going for regular maintenance to Nepal's new Pokhara airport, which opened last January and is equipped with aircraft maintenance hangars, they said.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nTelevision visuals showed fire fighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields. Bodies were carried to ambulances on stretchers as local residents looked on, the television showed.\n\nThe airport was closed temporarily, officials said.\n\nA Saurya Airlines official said the plane was a 50-seater CRJ200 aircraft.\n\nAccording to Flight Radar 24 flight tracking, Saurya currently operates two CRJ-200 regional jets, a programme that was owned by Canada's Bombardier but which was bought by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in 2020.\n\nSaurya says it has another CRJ200 in its fleet, but it has not flown for a long time.\n\nBombardier referred questions about the incident to Canada-based MHI RJ Aviation Group (MHIRJ), which did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nEstablished in 2014, Saurya says on its website that it has introduced the \"jet experience\" on Nepal's domestic routes and that it flies to five destinations.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, and nearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in the Himalayan country since 2000.\n\nThe deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nMost recently, at least 72 people were killed in a Yeti airlines crash in January 2023 that was later attributed to the pilots mistakenly cutting off power.\n\n(Reporting by Kathmandu newsroom; Additional reporting by Lisa Barrington in Seoul, Ainnie Arif and Shivani Tanna; Writing by Sakshi Dayal; Editing by YP Rajesh and Raju Gopalakrishnan)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "8241167552", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "11:47:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T11:47:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T11:46:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.peacefmonline.com/pages/foreign/news/202407/506681.php", "title": "Pilot Only Survivor Of Nepal Plane Crash", "body": "At least 18 people were killed after a plane crashed and caught fire while it was taking off from Nepal's capital of Kathmandu on Wednesday.\n\nThe pilot, who is currently receiving treatment in hospital, is the only survivor of the fatal accident.\n\nNineteen people were on the Saurya Airlines test flight, including technical staff members of the airline and two crew members.\n\nNepal's aviation industry has a poor safety record - that has been attributed to multiple factors over the years, from unpredictable weather to lax regulations.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines test flight on Wednesday was headed to Pokhara, a popular tourism destination.\n\nVideos posted online showed the plane being enveloped in fire and smoke. Fire engines and ambulances were rushed to the spot after the incident.\n\nThe incident happened at around 11:15 local time (05:30 GMT), a few minutes after the plane took off from the Tribhuvan International Airport, according to a statement by the Nepal Civil Aviation Authority's search and rescue coordination centre.\n\nThe statement said the plane \"turned right and crashed on the east side of the runway\".\n\n\"It was reported that the fire was brought under control and the rescue work was started immediately,\" it added.\n\n\"The dead bodies of 18 people were collected and one injured person was rescued and taken to the hospital.\"\n\nSeventeen of those who died are Nepali while one is a Yemeni national.\n\nAirport chief Jagannath Niraula told BBC Nepali that the accident \"happened as soon as it left the ground, in not even a minute\", however airport authorities have not been able to confirm the cause of the accident.\n\nNepali police spokesperson Dan Bahadur Karki also confirmed the deaths to BBC Nepali.\n\nAn airport official said \"some cracking noises were heard\" from the plane.\n\nNepal has been criticised for its poor air safety record. crashed and caught fire, killing all occupants bar the pilot.\n\nPolice official Basanta Rajauri said authorities have pulled out 18 bodies from the small plane which slipped off the runway while trying to take-off on Wednesday.\n\nThe only survivor was the pilot, who was taken to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital for treatment, said a doctor at the hospital who was not authorised to speak to media.\n\nThe pilot has injuries to the eyes but is not in any danger, the doctor said.\n\nThe airline manifest showed there were two pilots and 17 passengers on board, among them there was only one female.\n\nThe crew and 16 passengers were Nepali nationals with one identified as a foreigner but no nationality was disclosed.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines plane was heading from Kathmandu to the resort town of Pokhara.\n\nIt was not clear how the plane slipped.\n\nLocal media images showed smoke rising and plane wreckage scattered all over a ditch.\n\nA fire has been brought under The only survivor was the pilot, who was taken to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital for treatment, said a doctor at the hospital who was not authorized to speak to media.\n\nThe pilot has injuries to the eyes but is not in any danger, the doctor said.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines plane was heading from Kathmandu to the resort town of Pokhara.\n\nIt was not clear how it slipped.\n\nLocal media images showed smoke rising and plane wreckage scattered all over a ditch. A fire has been brought under control.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crew worked.\n\nIt is monsoon rainy season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Visibility was low across the capital, however.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. {"uri": "8241352559", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "13:39:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T13:39:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T13:37:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.sg/chilling-video-captures-moment-passenger-plane-nepal-crashes-bursts-into-flame-killing-18-people-75414", "title": "Chilling Video Captures Moment Passenger Plane in Nepal Crashes and Bursts into Flame Killing 18 People on Board [WATCH]", "body": "The pilot has been transported to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital for treatment, according to a doctor at the hospital who requested anonymity.\n\nA chilling video has emerged that captures the moment a passenger plane crashed in Nepal, killing 18 people after skidding off the runway and exploding -- leaving only the pilot as the sole survivor. Footage shows the Bombardier CRJ 200 plane flying low over the runway before abruptly tilting sideways and descending nose-first toward the ground.\n\nUpon crashing, the aircraft erupted into a fireball, sending black smoke into the sky as shocked bystanders looked on from an airport shuttle bus. The Saurya Airlines plane was headed to the resort town of Pokhara when it skidded off the runway at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu during take-off at 11 a.m. local time.\n\nKilled in No Time\n\nAccording to officials, the plane was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians who were traveling to Pokhara to repair another aircraft. The pilot was the only survivor, with officials reporting that 18 people died in the crash. Photos showed him being carried away from the wreckage.\n\nVideos from the crash site show firefighters working to extinguish the flames and thick black smoke billowing into the sky.\n\nOther footage shows rescue workers searching through the scorched debris of the plane, scattered across lush green fields.\n\nLocal media footage also shows bodies being transported to ambulances on stretchers, while nearby residents watched in shock.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nThe pilot has been transported to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital for treatment, according to a doctor at the hospital who requested anonymity.\n\nThe doctor said that the pilot has eye injuries but that his life is not in danger. Tribhuvan International Airport, Nepal's primary airport for both international and domestic flights, has been shut down while emergency crews respond to the incident.\n\nAlthough it is the monsoon season in Kathmandu, it was not raining at the time of the crash. However, visibility was poor throughout the capital, though it remains unclear if this factor or another issue caused the plane to skid off the runway.\n\nShocking Scenes\n\nSaurya Airlines operates two Bombardier CRJ 200 aircraft on domestic routes, both of which are around 20 years old, according to Flight Radar 24. Nepal has faced criticism for its poor air safety record, with nearly 350 fatalities resulting from plane or helicopter crashes in the Himalayan nation since 2000.\n\nThe deadliest incident occurred in 1992 when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, resulting in 167 deaths.\n\nThe most recent tragedy took place on July 11, 2023, when a helicopter crash in central Nepal killed six people. The helicopter, which had left Solukhumbu district -- home to Mount Everest and other high peaks -- carried five Mexican nationals and one Nepali pilot.\n\nEarlier in the year, a Yeti Airlines crash in January claimed 72 lives and was later attributed to the pilots accidentally cutting off power. This was the deadliest air crash in the country since 1992.", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.sg", "dataType": "news", "title": "International Business Times, Singapore Edition"}, "authors": [{"uri": "r_ghosh@ibtimes.sg", "name": "R. Pilot is lone survivor", "body": "KATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) -- A plane crashed Wednesday just after taking off from Nepal's capital, killing 18 people and injuring a pilot who was the lone survivor.\n\nPolice official Basanta Rajauri said authorities have pulled out all 18 bodies. The pilot has injuries to his eyes but his life is not in any danger, said a doctor at Kathmandu Medical College Hospital, where the pilot is being treated. The doctor spoke on condition of anonymity because she was not authorized to speak to media.\n\nA press statement issued by the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said the Saurya Airlines domestic plane, which was scheduled to head to the resort town of Pokhara, took off at 11:11 a.m. local time from Kathmandu airport and turned right but crashed moments later in the eastern section of the airport.\n\nIt is monsoon rain season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Visibility was low across the capital, however.\n\nThe Kathmandu airport, the main airport serving Nepal, is located inside a valley surrounded by mountains on most sides. It is considered a challenging airport for pilots and bigger planes have to come through an opening on the mountain to land. It is right next to the city, and is surrounded by houses and neighborhoods.\n\nThe bodies have been taken to the T.U. Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for autopsy. The airline manifest showed there were two pilots and 17 passengers on board. The crew and 16 passengers were Nepali nationals and one passenger was identified as a Yemeni national.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crew and investigators began their work.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. The only survivor was the pilot, who was taken to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital for treatment, said a doctor at the hospital who was not authorized to speak to media.\n\nThe pilot has injuries to the eyes but is not in any danger, the doctor said.\n\nThe bodies have been taken to the T.U. Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for autopsy. The airline manifest showed there were two pilots and 17 passengers on board, among them there was only one female. The crew and 16 passengers were Nepali nationals with one identified as foreigner but no nationality was disclosed.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines plane was heading from Kathmandu to the resort town of Pokhara.\n\nIt was not clear how it slipped.\n\nLocal media images showed smoke rising and plane wreckage scattered all over a ditch. A fire has been brought under control.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crew worked.\n\nIt is monsoon rainy season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Visibility was low across the capital, however.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes.\n\nThe Kathmandu airport, the main airport serving Nepal, is located inside a valley surrounded by mountains on most sides. It is considered a challenging airport for pilots and bigger planes have to come through an opening on the mountain to land. It is right next to the city. The airport is surrounded by houses and neighborhoods.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. {"uri": "8240768707", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "07:43:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T07:43:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T07:41:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.investing.com/news/stock-market-news/at-least-18-dead-in-nepal-plane-crash-officials-say-3532679", "title": "At least 18 dead in Nepal plane crash, officials say By Reuters", "body": "KATHMANDU (Reuters) - At least 18 people were killed when a small plane crashed and caught fire while it was taking off from Nepal's capital Kathmandu on Wednesday, officials said.\n\nThe plane was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians to Pokhara city to repair another aircraft, officials said.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nTelevision visuals showed fire fighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields.\n\nBodies were carried to ambulances on stretchers as local residents looked on, the television showed.\n\nThe plane was a Bombardier (OTC:BDRBF) , officials said, and media reported it belonged to local Saurya Airlines. The airport had been temporarily closed, the officials added.\n\nSaurya operates domestic flights in Nepal with two Bombardier CRJ-200 regional jets, both around 20 years old, according to Flight Radar 24.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, and nearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in the Himalayan country since 2000.\n\nThe deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nMost recently, at least 72 people were killed in a Yeti {"uri": "2024-07-431797152", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:26:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:26:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:05:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/plane-crashes-at-airport-in-nepals-capital-just-after-takeoff-killing-18-people-and-injuring/article_5dd3ae81-0130-5277-860c-da23ddc03cd6.html", "title": "Plane crashes at airport in Nepal's capital just after takeoff, killing 18 people and injuring pilot", "body": "KATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) -- A domestic plane crashed Wednesday just after taking off from the airport serving Nepal's capital, killing 18 people and injuring a pilot who was the lone survivor.\n\nPolice official Basanta Rajauri said authorities have pulled out all 18 bodies. The only survivor was the pilot, who was taken to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital for treatment, said a doctor at the hospital who was not authorized to speak to media.\n\nThe pilot has injuries to the eyes but is not in any danger, the doctor said.\n\nA press statement issued by the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said the Saurya Airlines plane had taken off at 11:11 a.m. from Kathmandu and was heading to resort town of Pokhara.\n\nThe plane had already taken off and turned right before it crashed in the eastern section of the airport, the statement said.\n\nThe bodies have been taken to the T.U. Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for autopsy. The airline manifest showed there were two pilots and 17 passengers on board, among them there was only one female. The crew and 16 passengers were Nepali nationals with one identified as foreigner but no nationality was disclosed.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crew and investigators began their work.\n\nIt is monsoon rainy season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Visibility was low across the capital, however.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes.\n\nThe Kathmandu airport, the main airport serving Nepal, is located inside a valley surrounded by mountains on most sides. It is considered a challenging airport for pilots and bigger planes have to come through an opening on the mountain to land. It is right next to the city. The airport is surrounded by houses and neighborhoods.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. The aircraft was carrying crew members and technicians to Pokhara. Nepal's air safety record has been under scrutiny following multiple crashes, including one in January 2023.\n\nAt least five people were killed when a small plane caught fire and skidded off the runway while taking off from Nepal's capital, Kathmandu, on Wednesday, according to media reports and officials.\n\nThe plane, operated by Saurya Airlines, was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians to Pokhara for maintenance checks, stated Airport Security Chief Arjun Chand Thakuri. Five bodies were recovered, reported The Kathmandu Post. Visuals showed firefighters attempting to control the blaze, with thick black smoke billowing into the sky.\n\n'The plane caught fire after skidding off the runway at Kathmandu airport and crashing into a field east of the runway,' Thakuri said. {"uri": "8240926659", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:24:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:24:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:22:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/business/3028096-nepalese-airline-tragedy-plane-crash-at-tribhuvan-airport-claims-18-lives", "title": "Nepalese Airline Tragedy: Plane Crash at Tribhuvan Airport Claims 18 Lives | Business", "body": "A Nepalese airline plane belonging to Saurya Airlines crashed during takeoff at Tribhuvan International Airport, killing 18, including a foreigner. The pilot survived with major injuries. The crash involved a Bombardier CRJ-200, leading to a temporary shutdown of the airport. Nepal has faced air safety scrutiny due to past incidents.\n\nA private Nepalese airline plane crashed during takeoff and caught fire at the Tribhuvan International Airport here on Wednesday, killing 18 people aboard, including a foreigner, while the pilot survived with major injuries.\n\nThe Nepalese domestic plane N9AME, belonging to Saurya Airlines, was bound for Pokhra for regular maintenance service when the accident occurred at 11.11 am.\n\nThe Bombardier CRJ-200 aircraft ''suffered a runway excursion and burst into massive flames immediately'', the Search and Rescue Centre of the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nVideos posted online showed the plane being enveloped in fire and smoke. Fire engines and ambulances were rushed to the spot after the incident.\n\nThe deceased were identified as co-pilot S Katuwal and 17 employees of the Saurya Airlines, including a Nepali female and a Yemeni national. Pilot captain Manish Shakya, 37, is undergoing treatment at Kathmandu Model Hospital.\n\nOf the deceased, 15 died on the spot while three died during treatment at a local hospital, authorities said.\n\nFollowing the accident, services at the Kathmandu airport were halted briefly before being resumed, the airport authorities said.\n\nSaruya Airlines operates flights to five tourist destinations within Nepal, with a fleet of three Bombardier CRJ-200 jets, according to the company's website.\n\nNepal has been criticised for its poor air safety record in recent years but the reasons also include partly sudden weather changes and partly airstrips located in hard-to-access rocky terrains apart from human error.\n\nAccording to Nepal's civil aviation body, 914 people have died in air crashes in the country since the first disaster was recorded in August 1955.\n\nIn January last year, all 72 people on board, including five Indians, were killed when a Yeti Airlines aircraft crashed in the resort city of Pokhara. The crash was attributed to a human error.\n\nYeti Airlines' 9N-ANC ATR-72 aircraft crashed on the bank of the Seti River between the old airport and the new airport minutes before landing on January 15, 2023, which was the 104th crash in Nepali skies and third biggest in terms of casualties.\n\nThe only incidents in which more people were killed took place in July and September 1992. Those crashes involved aircraft of Thai Airways and Pakistan International Airlines and left 113 and 167 people dead, respectively.\n\nOn May 29, 2022, all 22 people on board, including four members of an Indian family, were killed as a Tara Air plane crashed in Nepal's mountainous Mustang district.\n\nIn 2016, all 23 people aboard were killed when a plane of the same airline flying the same route crashed after takeoff.\n\nIn March 2018, a US-Bangla Air crash occurred at the Tribhuvan International Airport, killing 51 people on board.", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": The only survivor is the pilot, who is currently receiving medical treatment.\n\nThe aircraft, operated by Saurya Airlines, was conducting a technical or maintenance flight from Kathmandu to Pokhara. Among the passengers were two crew members and 17 airline staff. The plane caught fire around 11 am, shortly after skidding off the runway during takeoff. According to a Nepali police spokesman, Dan Bahadur Karki, the fire engulfed the plane after it slipped off the runway, fell down an embankment, and failed to gain altitude.\n\nThe CRJ200 aircraft, designed to seat 50 passengers, was engulfed in flames near the airport. Videos from the crash site show massive plumes of smoke rising from the wreckage. Firefighters and Nepal Army personnel quickly responded to the scene to control the blaze.\n\nThe cause of the fire remains unknown at this time. Tribhuvan International Airport, known for its challenging location atop a plateau surrounded by deep gorges and valleys, is considered one of the riskiest airports globally.\n\nNepal's aviation sector is notorious for its poor safety record, often attributed to inadequate training and maintenance. This latest crash follows the 2023 Yeti Airlines disaster, where 72 people, including five Indians, lost their lives. {"uri": "8241628956", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:37:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:37:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:36:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.the-star.co.ke/news/world/2024-07-24-pilot-only-survivor-of-nepal-plane-crash-that-claimed-18-lives/", "title": "Pilot only survivor of Nepal plane crash that claimed 18 lives", "body": "Eighteen people were killed after a plane crashed and caught fire while it was taking off from Nepal's capital, Kathmandu.\n\nThe pilot, who is currently receiving treatment in hospital, is the only survivor of Wednesday's fatal accident after being rescued from the burning wreckage.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight was carrying 17 company employees, including technical staff, as well as two crew members. It was bound for the Himalayan tourism hub of Pokhara in the country's west.\n\nNepal's aviation industry has a poor safety record that has been attributed to multiple factors over the years, from unpredictable weather to lax regulations.\n\nThe flight, which was heading for Pokhara as part of a routine maintenance check, crashed at about 11:15 local time (05:30 GMT), a few minutes after it took off from Tribhuvan International Airport, according to a statement by the Nepal Civil Aviation Authority's search and rescue co-ordination centre.\n\nPolice spokesperson Dan Bahadur Karki told BBC Nepali that the pilot sustained injuries to his eyes and forehead, but said his life was not in danger.\n\nOne man who was inside a nearby shop when the accident occurred said: \"There was a very loud noise, it sounded like maybe a truck had overturned on the road.\n\n\"We ran after we saw [the crash]. The plane then hit the ground and caught fire. We were about to run to the site but then there was an explosion so we ran away again,\" he told AFP news agency.\n\nAirport chief Jagannath Niraula told BBC Nepali that the accident \"happened as soon as it left the ground, in not even a minute\", though airport authorities have not been able to confirm the cause of the disaster.\n\nHowever, the head of Tribhuvan International Airport said that an initial assessment showed that the plane had flown in the wrong direction.\n\n\"As soon as it took off, it turned right, [when it] should have turned left,\" Mr Niraula told BBC Nepali.\n\nFootage of the incident showed the plane tilting above the runway before crashing into the ground, into flames. It quickly became enveloped in fire and smoke.\n\nPhotos showed rescue workers making their way through the wreckage, with large parts of the plane completely blackened and charred. Photos of the aftermath also appeared to show parts of the plane inside an air freight container.\n\nFire engines and ambulances were rushed to the spot after the incident.\n\nSeventeen of those who died were Nepali, while one was a Yemeni national, who was working as an engineer.\n\n\"The plane was scheduled to undergo maintenance for a month beginning Thursday... It is unclear why it crashed,\" said Saurya Airlines marketing head Mukesh Khanal, Reuters news agency reports.\n\nKathmandu's airport closed temporarily after the crash, but reopened within hours, Reuters said.\n\nNepal has been criticised for its poor air safety record. In January 2023, at least 72 people were killed in a Yeti Airlines crash that was later attributed to its pilots mistakenly cutting the power.\n\nIt was the deadliest air crash in Nepal since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach to Kathmandu Airport.\n\nSaruya Airlines operates flights to five destinations within Nepal, with a {"uri": "8240866201", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:59:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:59:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:45:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://rsoe-edis.org/eventList/details/671242/0", "title": "Airplane accident - Nepal - At least 18 dead in Nepal plane crash; pilot sole survivor, officials say", "body": "Tribhuvan International Airport, Kathmandu, Bagmati Province\n\nAt least 18 people were killed when a small plane crashed and caught fire while it was taking off from Nepal's capital Kathmandu on Wednesday, officials said.The plane was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians to Pokhara city to repair another aircraft, officials said.\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.Television visuals showed fire fighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting before it crashed.Other visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields.Bodies were carried to ambulances on stretchers as local residents looked on, the television showed.The plane was a Bombardier, officials said, and media reported it belonged to local Saurya Airlines. The airport had been temporarily closed, the officials added.Saurya operates domestic flights in Nepal with two Bombardier CRJ-200 regional jets, both around 20 years old, according to Flight Radar 24.Nepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, and nearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in the Himalayan country since 2000.The deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.Most recently, at least 72 people were killed in a Yeti airlines crash in January {"uri": "8240804583", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:06:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:06:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:06:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.euronews.com/2024/07/24/18-killed-in-nepal-after-plane-slips-off-runway-during-takeoff", "title": "18 killed after plane slips of runway in Nepal", "body": "It is monsoon rainy season in Kathmandu and although it was not raining at the time of the crash, visibility was low across the capital.\n\nA domestic plane crashed Wednesday while taking off from the airport serving Nepal's capital, killing 18 people and injuring a pilot who was the lone survivor.\n\nPolice official Basanta Rajauri said authorities have pulled out all 18 bodies.\n\nThe only survivor was the pilot, who was taken to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital for treatment. The pilot has injuries to the eyes but is not in any danger, a doctor at the hospital said.\n\nThe airline manifest showed there were two pilots and 17 passengers on board, among them there was only one female. The crew and 16 passengers were Nepali nationals with one identified as a foreigner but no nationality was disclosed.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines plane was heading from Kathmandu to the resort town of Pokhara.\n\nIt was not clear how it slipped.\n\nLocal media images showed smoke rising and plane wreckage scattered all over a ditch. A fire has been brought under control.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crew worked.\n\nIt is monsoon rainy season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Visibility was low across the capital, however.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes.\n\nThe Kathmandu airport, the main airport serving Nepal, is located inside a valley surrounded by mountains on most sides. It is considered a challenging airport for pilots and bigger planes have to come through an opening on the mountain to land. It is right next to the city. The airport is surrounded by houses and neighbourhoods.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. {"uri": "2024-07-432478101", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:01:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:01:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T07:25:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.waaytv.com/news/pilot-sole-survivor-of-nepal-plane-crash-that-killed-18/article_0eb9b93d-45ac-5e0e-986c-79be367e4309.html", "title": "Pilot sole survivor of Nepal plane crash that killed 18", "body": "Smoke rises from the Tribhuvan International Airport after a plane crashed during takeoff in Kathmandu, Nepal on July 24.\n\n(CNN) -- At least 18 people were killed after a small plane skidded off the runway in Nepal's capital Kathmandu on Wednesday, local officials said.\n\nThe pilot, who has been hospitalized, is the sole survivor of the Saurya Airlines crash, said Gyanendra Bhul, a spokesperson for Tribhuvan International Airport. All those on board - 18 Nepalis and a Yemeni citizen - were employees of the carrier, according to police.\n\nImages from Nepal police showed thick smoke billowing from the burning aircraft on the the airport runway.\n\nThe aircraft crashed during takeoff from Kathmandu to the city of Pokhara around 11 a.m. local time, Bhul said. The plane was en route for technical maintenance, he added.\n\n\"Rescue efforts were started immediately and the situation was brought under control,\" the aviation authority said.\n\nThe crash once again highlights the dangers of air travel in Nepal, a country often referred to as one of the riskiest places to fly due to multiple factors including its mountainous terrain.\n\nThe Himalayan country, home to eight of the world's 14 highest mountains including Everest, has a record of air accidents. Its weather can change suddenly, and airstrips are typically sited in difficult-to-reach, mountainous areas.\n\nAircraft with 19 seats or fewer are more likely to have accidents due to these difficulties, according to a 2019 safety report from the Civil Aviation Authority.\n\nWhile the country has made improvements in safety standards in recent years, challenges remain, and a lack of investment in aging aircraft only adds to the risks of flying.\n\nLast year, Nepal saw its worst plane crash in more than 30 years when at least 68 people died when a Yeti Airlines flight went down near Pokhara.\n\nIn May 2022, a Tara Air flight departing from Pokhara crashed into a mountain, killing 22 people.\n\nIn early 2018, a US-Bangla Airlines flight from Bangladesh's capital Dhaka to Kathmandu crashed on landing and caught fire, killing 51 people.\n\nAnd in 2016, a Tara Air flight crashed while flying the same route as the 2023 crash.\n\nThis story has been updated with additional information.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. The accident occurred around 11 am, as the Pokhara-bound Saurya Airlines plane took off.\n\nAmong the people on the plane, two were crew members and 17 were technicians, media reported quoting Airport Security Chief Arjun Chand Thakuri.\n\n\"It (the plane) caught fire after skidding off the runway at Kathmandu airport and crashing into a field east of the runway,\" the airport official added.\n\n\"The pilot of the aircraft has been taken to a hospital,\" a security official deployed at the airport told news agency PTI without giving further details.\n\n\"A fire that broke out from the aircraft has been put off,\" the official told the agency.\n\nSaurya Airlines, to which the plane belonged, flies domestic flights in Nepal with two Bombardier CRJ-200 regional jets, both around 20 years old, Flight Radar 24 data showed.\n\nNepal Plane Crash: A frequent occurrence\n\nIn January, a pilot error had led to a fatal plane crash in Nepal killing 72 on board.\n\nNepal, which attracts a lot of tourists, is seeing an aviaition boom as airlines fly to hard-to-reach zones while many foreign mountain climbers also take the planes.\n\nHowever, the hilly country has seen a number of deadly crashes in recent years that are attributed by experts to insufficient training and mainenance.\n\nNepal is also known to have some of the trickiest and most remote runways surrounded {"uri": "2024-07-432012850", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "11:27:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T11:27:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T11:26:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.ketv.com/article/deadly-plane-crash-nepal/61685618", "title": "Pilot lone survivor of plane crash that left 18 dead in Nepal", "body": "A plane crashed Wednesday just after taking off from Nepal's capital, killing 18 people and injuring a pilot who was the lone survivor.Police official Basanta Rajauri said authorities have pulled out all 18 bodies. The pilot has injuries to his eyes but his life is not in any danger, said a doctor at Kathmandu Medical College Hospital, where the pilot is being treated. The doctor spoke on condition of anonymity because she was not authorized to speak to media.A press statement issued by the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said the Saurya Airlines domestic plane, which was scheduled to head to the resort town of Pokhara, took off at 11:11 a.m. local time from Kathmandu airport and turned right but crashed moments later in the eastern section of the airport.It is monsoon rain season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Visibility was low across the capital, however.The Kathmandu airport, the main airport serving Nepal, is located inside a valley surrounded by mountains on most sides. It is considered a challenging airport for pilots and bigger planes have to come through an opening on the mountain to land. It is right next to the city, and is surrounded by houses and neighborhoods.The bodies have been taken to the T.U. Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for autopsy. The airline manifest showed there were two pilots and 17 passengers on board. The crew and 16 passengers were Nepali nationals and one passenger was identified as a Yemeni national.Tribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crew and investigators began their work.Saurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes.In 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.In 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. {"uri": "8240929771", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:25:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:25:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:24:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://en.tempo.co/read/1895294/nepal-plane-crash-at-kathmandu-airport-kills-18", "title": "Nepal Plane Crash at Kathmandu Airport Kills 18", "body": "TEMPO.CO, Kathmandu - At least 18 people were killed when a regional passenger plane belonging to Nepal's Saurya Airlines crashed and caught fire while taking off from the capital Kathmandu on Wednesday, July 24, officials said.\n\nThe plane, carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, was going for regular maintenance to Nepal's new Pokhara airport, which opened last January and is equipped with aircraft maintenance hangars, they said.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nTelevision visuals showed firefighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields. Bodies were carried to ambulances on stretchers as residents looked on, the television showed.\n\nOfficials said the airport was closed temporarily.\n\nA Saurya Airlines official said the plane was a 50-seater CRJ200 aircraft.\n\nAccording to Flight Radar 24 flight tracking, Saurya currently operates two CRJ-200 regional jets, a program owned by Canada's Bombardier but bought by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in 2020.\n\nSaurya says it has another CRJ200 in its fleet, but it has not flown for a long time.\n\nBombardier referred questions about the incident to Canada-based MHI RJ Aviation Group (MHIRJ), which did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nEstablished in 2014, Saurya says on its website that it has introduced the \"jet experience\" on Nepal's domestic routes and that it flies to five destinations.\n\nNepal has been criticized for a poor air safety record, and nearly 350 people have died in helicopter or plane crashes in the Himalayan country since 2000.\n\nThe deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nMost recently, at least 72 Wednesday morning, with fire crews working to douse the flaming wreckage.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines plane crashed at around 11:15 am (0530 GMT), Nepal's military said in a statement.\n\n\"Rescue work is going on\" with the army's quick response team lending assistance, the statement added.\n\nFurther details were \"still being confirmed\", Kathmandu airport general manager Jagannath Niroula told AFP.\n\nThe Kathmandu Post newspaper said 19 people including air crew were aboard the flight.\n\nNews portal Khabarhub reported that the airplane had caught fire after skidding on the runway and was \"releasing a significant plume of smoke\".\n\nThe plane was en route to Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nNepal's woeful record on aviation safety has been compounded by its treacherous geography.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a {"uri": "2024-07-431747373", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "07:41:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T07:41:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T06:09:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.aol.com/five-dead-nepal-plane-skids-060958176.html", "title": "At least 18 dead in Nepal plane crash, officials say", "body": "At least 18 dead in Nepal plane crash, officials say\n\nJuly 24, 2024 at 9:29 AM\n\nKATHMANDU (Reuters) - At least 18 people were killed when a small plane crashed and caught fire while it was taking off from Nepal's capital Kathmandu on Wednesday, officials said.\n\nThe plane was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians to Pokhara city to repair another aircraft, officials said.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nTelevision visuals showed fire fighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields.\n\nBodies were carried to ambulances on stretchers as local residents looked on, the television showed.\n\nThe plane was a Bombardier , officials said, and media reported it belonged to local Saurya Airlines. The airport had been temporarily closed, the officials added.\n\nSaurya operates domestic flights in Nepal with two Bombardier CRJ-200 regional jets, both around 20 years old, according to Flight Radar 24.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, and nearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in the Himalayan country since 2000.\n\nThe deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nMost recently, at least 72 people were killed in a Yeti The fire has since been extinguished.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines aircraft was carrying 19 people when it veered off the tarmac during takeoff at Tribhuvan Airport in Kathmandu. The incident was confirmed by the airport around 11am local time on Wednesday morning.\n\nREAD MORE: How Jay Slater case gripped the nation - five reasons missing teen had everyone talking\n\nClick here for the latest news from the Daily Star\n\nTragically, at least 18 passengers lost their lives in the crash, with all bodies being recovered from the wreckage, according to police reports. It's believed that only the pilot survived and is currently receiving treatment for injuries.\n\nThe aircraft, owned by domestic carrier Saurya Airlines, was en route from Kathmandu to the resort town of Pokhara, as reported by Nepal Television. The cause of the plane's skid remains unclear and the final casualty count is yet to be confirmed, reports the Mirror.\n\nAccording to the Himalayan Times, the 19 individuals on board were technical staff, with no commercial passengers present. Security officials at the airport have stated the pilot has been transported to hospital.\n\nDespite suffering eye injuries, the pilot is not in any immediate danger, a doctor at the hospital told media. The bodies have been taken to the T.U. Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for post-mortem examinations. Tribhuvan International Airport has been shut down, with emergency teams operating at the scene.\n\nA search operation is currently in progress, with concerns that the death toll may increase. Despite it being monsoon season in Kathmandu, there was no rain at the time of the crash. However, visibility across the capital was poor.\n\nSaurya Airlines uses the Bombardier CRJ 200 for domestic routes. Nepal has previously faced criticism for numerous incidents of poor air safety.\n\nAll 72 individuals aboard another domestic flight - including Brit Ruan Calum Crighton - perished in January last year when Yeti Airlines flight 691 stalled and crashed while landing at Pokhara.\n\nThe aircraft was making its final approach after departing from Kathmandu when it crashed into a river bank. This catastrophic event was live-streamed on Facebook by one passenger, showing that those onboard were oblivious until moments before impact.\n\nIt was later confirmed that the crash was caused by pilots mistakenly cutting power.\n\nIn September 1992, a Pakistani International Airlines flight also crashed into a hillside while coming in to land at Kathmandu, killing all 167 people on board. {"uri": "8241015016", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:15:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:15:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:15:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://easternmirrornagaland.com/18-killed-as-private-airline-plane-crashes-during-takeoff-at-kathmandu-pilot-survives/", "title": "18 Killed As Private Airline Plane Crashes During Takeoff At Kathmandu, Pilot Survives - Eastern Mirror", "body": "KATHMANDU -- A private Nepalese airline plane crashed during takeoff and caught fire at the Tribhuvan International Airport here on Wednesday, killing 18 people aboard, including a foreigner, while the pilot survived with major injuries.\n\nThe Nepalese domestic plane N9AME, belonging to Saurya Airlines, was bound for Pokhra for regular maintenance service when the accident occurred at 11.11 am.\n\nThe Bombardier CRJ-200 aircraft \"suffered a runway excursion and burst into massive flames immediately\", the Search and Rescue Centre of the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nVideos posted online showed the plane being enveloped in fire and smoke. Fire engines and ambulances were rushed to the spot after the incident.\n\nThe deceased were identified as co-pilot S Katuwal and 17 employees of the Saurya Airlines, including a Nepali female and a Yemeni national. Pilot captain Manish Shakya, 37, is undergoing treatment at Kathmandu Model Hospital.\n\nOf the deceased, 15 died on the spot while three died during treatment at a local hospital, authorities said.\n\nFollowing the accident, services at the Kathmandu airport were halted briefly before being resumed, the airport authorities said.\n\nSaruya Airlines operates flights to five tourist destinations within Nepal, with a fleet of three Bombardier CRJ-200 jets, according to the company's website.\n\nNepal has been criticised for its poor air safety record in recent years but the reasons also include partly sudden weather changes and partly airstrips located in hard-to-access rocky terrains apart from human error.\n\nAccording to Nepal's civil aviation body, 914 people have died in air crashes in the country since the first disaster was recorded in August 1955.\n\nIn January last year, all 72 people on board, including five Indians, were killed when a Yeti Airlines aircraft crashed in the resort city of Pokhara. The crash was attributed to a human error.\n\nYeti Airlines' 9N-ANC ATR-72 aircraft crashed on the bank of the Seti River between the old airport and the new airport minutes before landing on January 15, 2023, which was the 104th crash in Nepali skies and third biggest in terms of casualties.\n\nThe only incidents in which more people were killed took place in July and September 1992. Those crashes involved aircraft of Thai Airways and Pakistan International Airlines and left 113 and 167 people dead, respectively.\n\nOn May 29, 2022, all 22 people on board, including four members of an Indian family, were killed as a Tara Air plane crashed in Nepal's mountainous Mustang district.\n\nIn 2016, all 23 people aboard were killed when a plane of the same airline flying the same route crashed after takeoff.\n\nIn March 2018, a US-Bangla Air crash occurred at the Tribhuvan International Airport, killing 51 people on board.", "source": {"uri": "easternmirrornagaland.com", {"uri": "8240965489", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:46:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:46:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:45:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://albaniandailynews.com/news/pilot-only-survivor-of-nepal-plane-crash", "title": "Pilot only Survivor of Nepal Plane Crash", "body": "Some 18 people were killed after a plane crashed and caught fire while it was taking off from Nepal's capital of Kathmandu on Wednesday.\n\nThe pilot, who is currently receiving treatment in hospital, is the only survivor of the fatal accident.\n\nNineteen people were on the Saurya Airlines test flight, including technical staff members of the airline and two crew members.\n\nNepal's aviation industry has a poor safety record - that has been attributed to multiple factors over the years, from unpredictable weather to lax regulations.\n\nThe incident happened at around 11:15 local time (05:30 GMT), a few minutes after the plane took off from the Tribhuvan International Airport, according to a statement by the Nepal Civil Aviation Authority's search and rescue coordination centre.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines test flight on Wednesday was headed to Pokhara, a popular tourism destination.\n\nAirport chief Jagannath Niraula told BBC Nepali that the accident \"happened as soon as it left the ground, in not even a minute\", though airport authorities have not been able to confirm the cause of the accident.\n\nHowever, the head of the Tribhuvan International Airport said that an initial assessment showed that the plane had flown in the wrong direction.\n\n\"As soon as it took off, it turned right, [when it] should have turned left,\" airport chief Jagannath Niraula told BBC Nepali.\n\nPhotos show rescue workers making their way through the wreckage, with large planes of the plane completely blackened and charred.\n\nEarlier visuals showed the plane being enveloped in fire and smoke. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields. Bodies were carried to ambulances on stretchers as local residents looked on, the television showed.\n\nThe airport was closed temporarily, officials said.\n\nA Saurya Airlines official said the plane was a 50-seater CRJ200 aircraft.\n\nAccording to Flight Radar 24 flight tracking, Saurya currently operates two CRJ-200 regional jets, a program that was owned by Canada's Bombardier but which was bought by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in 2020.\n\nSaurya says it has another CRJ200 in its fleet, but it has not flown for a long time.\n\nBombardier referred questions about the incident to Canada-based MHI RJ Aviation Group (MHIRJ), which did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nEstablished in 2014, Saurya says on its website that it has introduced the \"jet experience\" on Nepal's domestic routes and that it flies to five destinations.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, and nearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in the Himalayan country since 2000.\n\nThe deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nMost {"uri": "8240831576", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:25:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:25:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:24:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/plane-crashes-in-nepal-with-18-dead-pilot-sole-survivor/article_f1337b58-5a1d-5505-af25-d32d5bcb8db7.html", "title": "Plane crashes in Nepal with 18 dead, pilot sole survivor", "body": "People stand at the site after a Saurya Airlines' plane crashed during takeoff at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu\n\nA passenger plane crashed on takeoff in Kathmandu on Wednesday, with the pilot rescued from the flaming wreckage but all 18 others aboard killed, police in the Nepali capital told AFP.\n\nNepal has a woeful track record on aviation safety and the Himalayan republic has seen a spate of deadly light plane and helicopter crashes over the decades.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight was carrying two crew and 17 of the company's staff members, Nepali police spokesman Dan Bahadur Karki told AFP.\n\n\"The pilot has been rescued and is being treated,\" he added. \"Eighteen bodies have been recovered, including one foreigner. We are in the process of taking them for post-mortem.\"\n\nThe flight was being conducted for either technical or maintenance purposes, Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority told AFP without giving further details.\n\nBahadur and Bhul were unable to confirm the nationality of the sole foreigner aboard.\n\nImages of the aftermath shared by Nepal's military showed the plane's fuselage split apart and burnt to a husk.\n\nAround a dozen soldiers in camouflage were standing on top of the wreckage with the surrounding earth coated in fire retardant.\n\nThe plane crashed at around 11:15 am (0530 GMT), the military said in a statement, adding that the army's quick response team had been lending assistance with rescue efforts.\n\nNews portal Khabarhub reported that the airplane had caught fire after skidding on the runway.\n\nThe plane was scheduled to fly on Nepal's busiest air route between Kathmandu and Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\n- Plagued by poor safety -\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance -- issues compounded by the mountainous republic's treacherous geography.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThat accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach to Kathmandu airport.\n\nEarlier that year a Thai Airways aircraft had crashed near the same airport, killing 113 people.\n\npm/gle/mtp", "source": {"uri": "ktbs.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KTBS"}, "authors": [{"uri": "paavan_mathema@ktbs.com", "name": "Paavan
