{"uri": "8241106635", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "11:10:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T11:10:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T11:08:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.newsdrum.in/international/18-killed-as-plane-crashes-after-takeoff-at-nepals-kathmandu-airport-pilot-survives-6676407", "title": "18 killed as plane crashes after takeoff at Nepal's Kathmandu airport, pilot survives", "body": "Kathmandu, Jul 24 (PTI) A Nepalese private plane crashed and caught fire shortly after taking off from the Tribhuvan International Airport here on Wednesday, killing 18 people aboard, including a child, and seriously injuring the pilot - the only survivor.\n\nThe Bombardier CRJ-200 aircraft of Saurya Airlines, carrying 19 people, including two crew members and technical staff of the airline, was bound for Pokhara International Airport for regular maintenance service when the accident occurred at 11.11 am (local time).\n\n\"Shortly after takeoff from runway 02, the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" said a statement issued by the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal.\n\nIt said rescue operations were initiated immediately and fire was brought under control.\n\n\"One injured person (Captain Manish Ratna Shakya) was rescued and taken to the hospital, and 18 People were found dead,\" it added.\n\nThe aviation authority identified one of the passengers as a child named Adhiraj Sharma, who was the son of Manu Raj Sharma, a technician of Saurya Airlines.\n\nSharma's wife Priza Khatiwada and their four-year old son Adhiraj died in the crash.\n\nA statement issued by the airline said that Priza and her son were initially identified as employees of the company, but it was later revealed that they were passengers.\n\nVideos posted online showed the plane being enveloped in fire and smoke. Fire engines and ambulances were rushed to the spot after the incident.\n\nThe deceased were identified as co-pilot S Katuwal and employees of Saurya Airlines and a Yemeni national (Aref Reda). Pilot Captain Manish Shakya, 37, is undergoing treatment at Kathmandu Model Hospital.\n\nOf the deceased, 15 died on the spot while three died during treatment at a local hospital, authorities said.\n\nPrime Minister KP Sharma Oli and Home Minister Ramesh Lekh separately visited the accident site to gather details about the incident and provide necessary directives.\n\nOli said he was deeply saddened by the tragic deaths in the crash and was at the site to inquire about the cause of the air crash with the Civil Aviation Authority's officials. He urged all for patience at this hour of grief.\n\nAccording to Tribhuvan International Airport chief Jagannath Niraula, the plane flying from Kathmandu to Pokhara turned in the wrong direction.\n\n\"As soon as it took off, it turned right instead of turning left,\" Niraula was quoted as saying by the BBC News Nepali.\n\nHowever, \"the cause of the accident has not been revealed yet,\" he said.\n\nThe accident happened less than a minute after the plane took off, Niraula said.\n\nThe aircraft \"suffered a runway excursion and burst into massive flames immediately\", the Search and Rescue Centre of the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal earlier said.\n\nThe aircraft, manufactured by the Canadian company Bombardier in April 2003, was the sixth of its kind purchased for use in Nepal, according to information from planesspotters.com.\n\nFollowing the accident, services at the Kathmandu airport were halted briefly before being resumed, the airport authorities said.\n\nAccording to the company's website, Saruya Airlines operates flights to five tourist destinations within Nepal, with a fleet of three Bombardier CRJ-200 jets.\n\nNepal has been criticised for its poor air safety record in recent years but the reasons also include partly sudden weather changes and partly airstrips located in hard-to-access rocky terrains apart from human error.\n\nAccording to Nepal's civil aviation body, 914 people have died in air crashes in the country since the first disaster was recorded in August 1955.\n\nIn January last year, all 72 people on board, including five Indians, were killed when a Yeti Airlines aircraft crashed in the resort city of Pokhara. The crash was attributed to a human error.\n\nYeti Airlines' 9N-ANC ATR-72 aircraft crashed on the bank of the Seti River between the old airport and the new airport minutes before landing on January 15, 2023, which was the 104th crash in Nepali skies and the third biggest in terms of casualties.\n\nThe only incidents in which more people were killed took place in July and September 1992. Those crashes involved aircraft of Thai Airways and Pakistan International Airlines and left 113 and 167 people dead, respectively.\n\nOn May 29, 2022, all 22 people on board, including four members of an Indian family, were killed as a Tara Air plane crashed in Nepal's mountainous Mustang district.\n\nIn 2016, all 23 people aboard were killed when a plane of the same airline flying the same route crashed after takeoff.\n\nIn March 2018, a US-Bangla Air crash occurred at the Tribhuvan International Airport, killing 51 people on board. {"uri": "8241487708", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:03:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:03:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:02:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/nepal-crash-terrifying-final-moments-33314994", "title": "Terrifying final moments of Nepal crash passengers as doomed plane went down", "body": "Following this morning's deadly plane crash in Nepal, the Mirror looks at the final terrifying moments of the 18 people who lost their lives in the horror incident\n\nDevastating footage shows the terrifying final moments of the 18 people who died aboard the Saurya Airlines jet in Nepal this morning (Wednesday, July 24).\n\nIn harrowing scenes captured on camera, the plane could be seen hurtling back down to earth mere moments after taking off at Tribhuvan Airport in Kathmandu. Out of the 19 people onboard, only one - the pilot - survived the horror crash. Images show the passenger plane erupting into flames, with plumes of thick black smoke filling the air. Airport staff on the tarmac could only look on in fear as the aircraft nosedived into a field, shouting out in terror.\n\nBrave individuals on the ground rushed to the smouldering wreckage, while rescue teams desperately tried to save crew and passengers who, just seconds before, had been flying through the air, en route to Nepal's tourist hotspot, Pokhara.\n\nEmergency services managed to extinguish the furious fire that had engulfed the plane and all those onboard, but it was too late. For the majority of those on the decimated jet, nothing could be done.\n\nPolice official Basanta Rajauri has since confirmed that sole survivor, named by The Sun as Captain MR Shakya, suffered injuries to his eyes, but otherwise escaped unscathed. He has since been taken to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital, in Sinamangal, for treatment. His co-pilot was amongst the deceased.\n\nHarrowing footage taken at the scene of the crash shows lifeless bodies being carried to ambulances on stretchers as locals looked on. The remains of all those who perished have since been taken to the T.U. Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu, where autopsies will be carried out.\n\nReuters reports that the plane had been carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, and had been travelling to Pokhara airport, for regular maintanence. The new airport, which only opened in January, is equipped with aircraft maintenance hangars. Out of the 19 individuas on the doomed flight, 18 were citizens of Nepal, while one engineer was from Yemen.\n\nIn a statement, the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said: \"Shortly after takeoff ... the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway.\" Meanwhile, Mukesh Khanal, Saurya Airlines' marketing chief, stated: \"The plane was scheduled to undergo maintenance for a month beginning Thursday ... It is unclear why it crashed.\"\n\nFollowing a temporary closure, Kathmandu airport reopened within hours of the tragedy, according to officials. A Saurya Airlines official has confirmed that the destroyed jet had been a 50-seater CRJ-200 aircraft with the registration 9N-AME\n\nNepal has previously faced criticism for its poor record when it comes to aircraft safety, with the country recording nearly 350 fatalities due to plane or helicopter crashes since 2000. The deadliest crashed occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus collided into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, resulting in the deaths of 167 people.\n\nDo you have a story to share? {"uri": "2024-07-432068566", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "12:14:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T12:14:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T07:32:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://www.wkyc.com/article/news/nation-world/plane-crashes-nepal-18-dead/507-aea94d65-0557-426a-8c19-0a4c1b8925af", "title": "18 dead, pilot is the lone survivor of plane crash in Nepal shortly after takeoff", "body": "The airport he flew out from is considered a particularly challenging one because bigger planes have to come through an opening in the nearby mountains to land.\n\nKATHMANDU, Nepal -- A plane crashed Wednesday just after taking off from Nepal's capital, killing 18 people and injuring a pilot who was the lone survivor.\n\nPolice official Basanta Rajauri said authorities have pulled out all 18 bodies. The pilot has injuries to his eyes but his life is not in any danger, said a doctor at Kathmandu Medical College Hospital, where the pilot is being treated. The doctor spoke on condition of anonymity because she was not authorized to speak to media.\n\nA press statement issued by the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said the Saurya Airlines domestic plane, which was scheduled to head to the resort town of Pokhara, took off at 11:11 a.m. local time from Kathmandu airport and turned right but crashed moments later in the eastern section of the airport.\n\nIt is monsoon rain season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Visibility was low across the capital, however.\n\nThe Kathmandu airport, the main airport serving Nepal, is located inside a valley surrounded by mountains on most sides. It is considered a challenging airport for pilots as bigger planes have to come through an opening on the mountain to land. It is right next to the city, and is surrounded by houses and neighborhoods.\n\nThe bodies have been taken to the T.U. Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for autopsy. The airline manifest showed there were two pilots and 17 passengers on board. The crew and 16 passengers were Nepali nationals and one passenger was identified as a Yemeni national.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crew and investigators began their work.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. {"uri": "8240846294", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:33:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:33:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:32:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.news9live.com/world/nepals-awful-civil-aviation-record-a-look-at-some-airplane-accidents-in-the-country-2629461", "title": "Nepal's awful civil aviation record: A look at some airplane accidents in the country", "body": "Kathmandu: Yet another plane crash took place in Nepal on Wednesday, killing 18 people. The pilot of the plane was rushed to hospital and is currently undergoing treatment. The plane crashed at the Tribhuvan International Airport in the country's capital Kathmandu. Reports said that the plane caught fire during take off.\n\nThe country holds the unwanted distinction of being one of the most dangerous places to fly. In fact the European Airlines has banned all Nepali airlines from entering its airspace since 2013, due to safety concerns. After Wednesday's crash in Kathmandu, it does not seem that this ban is going to be lifted any time soon.\n\nJuly 2024: The plane crash at the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu involved an airplane of the Saurya airlines. The plane was headed to Pokhara. There were 19 people onboard the plane, of which 18 are reportedly dead. The plane caught fire during take, said initial reports. Though how exactly did it catch fire, remains unknown.\n\nJanuary 2023: In January 2023, a Yeti Airlines plane flying from Kathmandu to Pokhara, crashed while landing. There were 72 people onboard the flight, all of whom lost their lives in the accident. The flight crashed on the banks of the Seti Gandak River. The crash reportedly happened in the Gandaki Province between the old Pokhara Airport and the new Pokhara International Airport. The airline blamed the pilot's error for the crash.\n\nMay 2022: A plane belonging to Tara Airways with 22 people onboard crashed in Nepal's mountainous Mustang district on May 29. There were 4 Indian onboard the aircraft. The bodies were recovered on Tuesday. All of those onboard the plane were killed. The probe revealed that bad weather caused the crash.\n\nFebruary 2019: An Air Dynasty helicopter crashed in the mountains, as it was flying back to Kathmandu. The then Tourism Minister of the country, Rabindra Adhikari was onboard the plane and died in the crash. A total of 7 people had been killed in the accident. Violations of operating procedure like wrong seating arrangement of passengers and disbalance of weights due to the positioning of the fuel tank were blamed for the airplane crash.\n\nMarch 2018: A US-Bangla Airline plane carrying 67 passengers and 4 crew members crashed at the Kathmandu Airport. The accident killed 49 people. The flight shot off the runway while attempting to land and caught fire. It was returning from Dhaka. The flight exploded in a nearby football field.\n\nFebruary 2016: The Air Kashthamandap aircraft crashed in the Kalikot district of Nepal. The accident killed 2 crew members, while all 9 passengers onboard were saved. They just suffered injuries.\n\nMay 2012: A Dornier plane with 21 people on board crashed into a hilltop in northern Nepal. This accident killed 15 persons, of whom 13 were Indians. The plane was flying from Pokhara Airport to Jomsom Airport.\n\nSeptember 2011: A Beechcraft 1900D aircraft operated by Buddha Air crashed in the mountains in September 2011. The aircradft had tourists onboard, who had gone on sightseeing trip around Mount Everest. Of the 19 people killed in the crash, 10 were Indians. At the time adverse weather was blamed for the crash.\n\nSeptember 2006: A Shree Air helicopter crashed in Eastern Nepal. There were 24 people onboard including the crew. All of them were killed in the accident.\n\nNovember 2001: A chartered helicopter which had Princess Prekshya Shah of Nepal onboard crashed in Western Nepal, killing all 6 occupants.", "source": In the accident, 18 people lost their lives, while the pilot survived with injuries.\n\nAn airplane carrying 19 passengers in Nepal veered off the runway and caught fire during takeoff.\n\n18 bodies were recovered from the wreckage of the 9N-AME (CRJ 200) plane belonging to Saurya Airlines, which crashed at Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA) in Kathmandu, Nepal. The plane was headed to Pokhara and had a total of 19 people on board.\n\nSmoke was seen rising from the plane after the crash. Police and firefighters were dispatched to the scene for rescue operations.\n\nPILOT INJURED\n\nThe 37-year-old pilot of the plane, Manish Shakya, was rescued from the wreckage and taken to a nearby hospital in Sinamangal for treatment. Gyanendra Bhul, the information officer of TIA, said that the airline's technical staff was on board the plane.\n\nThe airline was purchased by India-based Kuber Group for 630 million Nepalese rupees in 2019. There were reports that the company would change its name to Kuber Airlines in 2021, but this plan was put on hold.\n\nAccording to a report, Katmandu airport had suspended all flights of Saurya Airlines on December 6, 2018, due to its inability to pay off its debts. The pilot of the aircraft has been taken to a hospital, a security official deployed at the airport told news agency PTI.\n\nThe plane burst into flames after it skidded off the runway as it began to take off, a spokesperson of the airport told NDTV.\n\nThe CRJ200 plane, which can seat 50 passengers, did not gain any altitude on takeoff, slipped off the runway and fell down an embankment and caught fire. {"uri": "2024-07-432274097", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:16:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:16:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:09:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.seattletimes.com/nation-world/plane-slips-off-runway-and-crashes-at-kathmandu-airport-killing-18/", "title": "Plane slips off runway and crashes at Kathmandu airport, killing 18", "body": "KATHMANDU, Nepal -- A plane slipped off a runway and crashed during takeoff here on Wednesday morning, killing everyone on board except the pilot, according to Nepali police.\n\nRescue teams recovered 18 bodies after the Saurya Airlines passenger plane crashed at Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport, Dan Bahadur Karki, deputy inspector general of the Nepal Police, told The Washington Post. Seventeen of the passengers were Nepalis -- including one child -- while one passenger was Yemeni, the airport's rescue coordination center said in a news release.\n\nMost of those on board were airline maintenance workers, Karki said, adding that the pilot, the sole survivor, was admitted to a hospital in stable condition.\n\nThe Bombardier CRJ 200 was flying for maintenance to Pokhara, a resort town that is a 25-minute flight west of Kathmandu, said Subash Jha, a spokesman for Tribhuvan International Airport. The airport has been temporarily shut down.\n\nAirport workers who witnessed the crash told The Post that the plane was taking off from the southern end of the runway when it flipped and its right wing tip hit the ground.\n\nThe aircraft caught fire immediately and plunged into a gorge on the eastern side of the runway, said Mukesh Khanal, a spokesman for Saurya Airlines.\n\nIn surveillance video viewed by The Post, the aircraft can be seen flying low, then tilting toward the right and crashing in flames.\n\nThick plumes of smoke could be seen rising from the airport on Wednesday afternoon.\n\nIt is not yet clear how the plane slipped and crashed at 11:11 a.m. local time. Kathmandu was experiencing clear and sunny skies, without rainfall, on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"Everything was normal before the flight was ready to take off,\" Khanal said, adding that the crash would be investigated.\n\nSanjiv Gautam, the former director of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority, said in an interview that it appeared the flight had broken civil aviation rules, as planes being flown elsewhere for maintenance are not permitted to carry any passengers, including airline employees.\n\nNepal has a poor aviation safety record, with several deadly crashes in recent years. A January 2023 Yeti Airlines crash in Pokhara killed all 72 people aboard, while a March 2018 US-Bangla Airlines crash at Tribhuvan International Airport killed 51.\n\nThe European Union has banned air carriers certified in Nepal, including Saurya Airlines, from flying into the 27-nation bloc, citing safety concerns.\n\nCritics have accused the aviation industry of being beset with corruption and mismanagement. Aviation experts have also cited Nepal's mountainous terrain -- with high-elevation airports, short runways, strong winds and lower air pressures -- as factors that make flying difficult.", "source": {"uri": "8240731766", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "07:18:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T07:18:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T07:18:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.thehansindia.com/news/international/aircraft-crash-at-kathmandus-tribhuvan-international-airport-894094", "title": "Aircraft Crash At Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport", "body": "The Pokhara-bound flight, carrying 19 people, caught fire, leading to rescue operations.\n\nA Saurya Airlines aircraft crashed during takeoff at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal, on Wednesday, as reported by The Kathmandu Post. The Pokhara-bound plane, carrying 19 people, including the aircrew, encountered the accident around 11 am, according to TIA spokesperson Premnath Thakur.\n\nWitnesses reported seeing smoke rising from the airport following the crash. State television in Nepal confirmed that the plane had veered off the runway while attempting to take off. Rescue operations by police and firefighters are currently underway at the site of the accident.\n\nNews portal Khabarhub mentioned that the aircraft caught fire, producing a significant plume of smoke. The pilot has been taken to a hospital, according to a security official at the airport. The fire from the aircraft has been extinguished, but details about the condition of the passengers remain unknown.\n\nSaurya Airlines, which exclusively operates Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, was en route to Pokhara, a key tourism destination in Nepal. The country's aviation sector has expanded in recent years, transporting goods and passengers to remote areas, but it has been plagued by safety issues due to inadequate training and maintenance. Consequently, the European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nNepal has experienced about one flight disaster per year on average. Notable recent incidents include the January 2023 crash of a Yeti Airlines flight near Pokhara, which resulted in 72 fatalities, and the May 2022 crash of a Tara Air plane in Mustang district, killing all 22 people aboard. The incident occurred around 11:00 AM local time. The flight, which was bound for Pokhara, had 19 people on board, including aircrew. According to PTI, \"at least 18 people were killed\" in the accident.\n\nThe aircraft, a Mitsubishi CRJ-200ER, caught fire upon impact, with Khabarhub reporting that the plane was \"releasing a significant plume of smoke.\" Emergency responders quickly extinguished the blaze. Rescue operations are ongoing, conducted by police and firefighters. The pilot was taken to a nearby hospital, though there are no further details on their condition, as noted by a security official deployed at the airport.\n\nPolice and firefighters are actively engaged in rescue efforts. The pilot was transported to a nearby hospital, but no further details about their condition have been provided. TIA Spokesperson Subash Jha confirmed this information, stating, \"The accident occurred after the Pokhara-bound flight suffered a runway excursion during takeoff.\"\n\nTribhuvan International Airport is known for its challenging geography. Located on a plateau surrounded by deep gorges and valleys, it is considered one of the riskiest airports globally. The difficult terrain and unpredictable weather conditions add to the complexity of flying in and out of Kathmandu.\n\nNepal's aviation industry has faced ongoing safety challenges. The European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace due to safety concerns. The country's treacherous geography and rapid weather changes further complicate aviation safety.\n\nNepal has a troubling record of aviation accidents. In January 2023, a Yeti Airlines flight crashed near Pokhara, killing all 72 people on board. In May 2022, a Tara Air plane crashed in Mustang, resulting in 22 fatalities. {"uri": "8240959529", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:42:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:42:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:41:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.aninews.in/news/world/asia/heard-a-loud-bang-eyewitnesses-recount-nepal-plane-crash-that-claimed-18-lives20240724150601/", "title": "\"Heard a loud bang...\": Eyewitnesses recount Nepal Plane crash that claimed 18 lives", "body": "Kathmandu (Nepal) July 24 (ANI): Recounting the harrowing experience of witnessing the Nepal plane crash that claimed 18 lives, the eyewitnesses said that if the plane wouldn't have hit the container, it would have definitely hit the residential area.\n\nEyewitness, Aadesh Lama, who witnessed the crash, said, \"I was working here at my garage in the morning and then I heard a loud sound. We thought a tyre had burst but we came to know that a plane had crashed. It had knocked a container, if it wasn't the container then it surely would have slid down and hit the residential area. The container saved us. It struck the container and came to the ground and got engulfed by fire.\"\n\nAnother witness, Krishna Bahadur Thapa, detailed his initial reaction.\n\n\"I heard a loud bang, about three to four of us were here. We first assumed it to be a vehicle accident but it turned out to be an aircraft that had crashed. The plane slid down and stopped, at first there was the sound, then after the smoke billowed and then it was engulfed by fire. I rushed near to the site where the plane crashed and there again was an explosion and then I ran backwards with fear,\" Thapa said while speaking to ANI.\n\nAn aircraft of Saurya Airlines crashed during take-off at the Tribhuvan International Airport on Wednesday, Nepal-based daily, The Himalayan Times reported. The plane was scheduled to leave for Pokhara from Kathmandu when the accident happened.\n\nThe Tribhuvan International Airport, in an official release, said that 18 dead bodies were recovered from the site and only 1 person survived the crash.\n\nThe TIA said \"CRJ7 (Reg-9NAME) of Sourya Airlines took off from Kathmandu at 11:11 am local time during the flight to Pokhara, turned right and crashed at a place on the east side of the runway. It is reported that the fire was brought under control and the rescue work was started immediately. The dead bodies of 18 people were recovered and 1 injured person was rescued and taken to the hospital.\"\n\nThe Pilot of the Saurya Airline plane that crashed at the Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA) in Kathmandu is the lone survivor of the crash.\n\nThe plane 9N-AME (CRJ 200) was only carrying technical staff of the airline, with no passengers on board. Gyanendra Bhul, information officer at TIA, confirmed that the plane was carrying a few technical staff members.\n\nThe plane crashed shortly after taking off from the runway, at around 11:00 AM today. Following the crash, smoke was seen coming from the plane. Firefighters and security personnel, including Nepal Police and the Nepali Army, were deployed to the crash site. "body": "A passenger plane carrying 19 individuals, including aircrew, crashed during takeoff at Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport on Wednesday morning.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight was en route to Pokhara, a significant tourism hub in the Himalayan nation when it met with the accident at around 11:15 am local time (0530 GMT).\n\nNepal's military confirmed the incident in a statement, highlighting that rescue operations are ongoing with the assistance of the army's quick response team.\n\nThe plane reportedly caught fire after skidding on the runway, producing a substantial plume of smoke, as reported by local news portal, Khabarhub.\n\nThe General Manager of Kathmandu Airport, Jagannath Niroula, stated that further details regarding the crash are still being confirmed.\n\nThe Kathmandu Post reported that the aircraft was a Bombardier CRJ 200 jet, a model exclusively flown by Saurya Airlines.\n\nNepal's air industry has seen rapid growth in recent years, serving as a critical link between remote areas and catering to foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nHowever, the industry has been marred by safety concerns attributed to insufficient training and maintenance, leading to the European Union banning all Nepali carriers from its airspace.\n\nThe country's challenging geography, marked by some of the world's most difficult runways flanked by snow-capped peaks, adds to the complexity of aviation safety.\n\nThe weather in these mountainous regions can also change abruptly, creating hazardous flying conditions.\n\nThis crash follows Nepal's last major commercial flight accident in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines flight crashed while landing in Pokhara, resulting in the deaths of all 72 individuals on board.\n\nThe deadliest accident in Nepal's aviation history occurred in 1992 when a Pakistan International Airlines plane crashed on approach to Kathmandu airport, killing all 167 people on board.\n\nAnother tragic incident earlier that year involved a Thai Airways aircraft crash near the same airport, resulting in 113 fatalities.\n\nAuthorities have yet to release the identities of those aboard the Saurya Airlines flight. {"uri": "8240742797", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "07:26:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T07:26:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T07:25:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://newsable.asianetnews.com/world/caught-on-camera-dramatic-moment-when-saurya-airlines-plane-with-19-onboard-crashed-in-kathmandu-watch-snt-sh49u1", "title": "Caught on camera: Dramatic moment when Saurya Airlines plane with 19 onboard crashed in Kathmandu (WATCH)", "body": "Fifteen people were killed and four survived when a Saurya Airlines flight crashed at Nepal's Kathmandu airport on Wednesday. Dramatic footage of the moment the tragedy struck has gone viral on social media.\n\nDramatic footage of a Saurya Airlines plane crash at Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA) in Kathmandu, Nepal, has gone viral, capturing the harrowing moment the aircraft, carrying 19 people, slipped off the runway during takeoff on Wednesday.\n\nThe flight, heading to Pokhara, suffered a runway excursion, flipping with its wing tip hitting the ground, eyewitnesses reported. The plane then caught fire and plunged into a gorge between the Buddha Air hangar and the radar station on the eastern side of the runway. The scene, recorded by bystanders, shows thick billows of smoke rising from the crash site.\n\nThe accident occurred after the Pokhara-bound flight suffered a runway excursion during takeoff, said TIA Spokesperson Subash Jha. As per latest update from Nepal police, of the 19 people on board, 15 have been confirmed dead, while 4 survivors have been rescued.\n\nThe survivors include Captain MR Shakya, who was rushed to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital for treatment. A doctor at the hospital, who was not authorized to speak to the media, stated that the pilot sustained injuries to his eyes but is not in any danger.\n\nThe cause of the crash remains unclear, and an investigation is underway to determine how the plane slipped off the runway. The accident happened despite the weather being dry at the time, although visibility was low across the capital.\n\nLocal media images and videos show the devastating aftermath, with wreckage scattered in a ditch and emergency responders, including police and firefighters, working to control the fire and rescue any survivors. Tribhuvan International Airport, Nepal's main hub for both international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crews continue their efforts.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes and has yet to release an official statement regarding the incident.\n\nIn 2019, a tragic incident at Tribhuvan International Airport involved a Bangladeshi airliner that crashed, resulting in the loss of 51 lives while 20 people on board survived. The investigation revealed that the plane was misaligned with the runway, and the pilot, disoriented, attempted to land in \"sheer desperation,\" leading to the crash.\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet encountered difficulties while landing in dense fog and skidded off a slippery runway at the same airport. More info\n\nA plane has crashed at an airport in Nepal after skidding off the runway.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines aircraft was carrying 19 passengers when it skidded off the runway during take off at Tribhuvan Airport in the Nepalese capital Kathmandu. The airport has confirmed the incident on Wednesday morning, July 24, reports the Mirror.\n\nThe plane belongs to the domestic Saurya airline and was heading from Kathmandu to the resort town of Pokhara, Nepal Television confirmed. The reason for the plane skidding or whether there have been any casualties is not currently clear.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport has been closed and emergency crews were working at the scene. Dramatic video shows thick black smoke billowing from the airport's runway and plane wreckage scattered all over a ditch as members of the public flood a nearby road, watching in horror.\n\nAnother shot shows flames burning by an outbuilding at the airport, which serves Nepal's capital. The fire has since been brought under control, Associated Press reports.\n\nIt is monsoon rainy season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Fire engines and ambulances were rushed to the spot after the incident.\n\nThe deceased were identified as co-pilot S Katuwal and 17 employees of the Saurya Airlines, including a Nepali female and a Yemeni national. Pilot captain Manish Shakya, 37, is undergoing treatment at Kathmandu Model Hospital.\n\nOf the deceased, 15 died on the spot while three died during treatment at a local hospital, authorities said.\n\nFollowing the accident, services at the Kathmandu airport were halted briefly before being resumed, the airport authorities said.\n\nSaruya Airlines operates flights to five tourist destinations within Nepal, with a fleet of three Bombardier CRJ-200 jets, according to the company's website.\n\nNepal has been criticised for its poor air safety record in recent years but the reasons also include partly sudden weather changes and partly airstrips located in hard-to-access rocky terrains apart from human error.\n\nAccording to Nepal's civil aviation body, 914 people have died in air crashes in the country since the first disaster was recorded in August 1955.\n\nIn January last year, all 72 people on board, including five Indians, were killed when a Yeti Airlines aircraft crashed in the resort city of Pokhara. The crash was attributed to a human error.\n\nYeti Airlines' 9N-ANC ATR-72 aircraft crashed on the bank of the Seti River between the old airport and the new airport minutes before landing on January 15, 2023, which was the 104th crash in Nepali skies and third biggest in terms of casualties.\n\nThe only incidents in which more people were killed took place in July and September 1992. Those crashes involved aircraft of Thai Airways and Pakistan International Airlines and left 113 and 167 people dead, respectively.\n\nOn May 29, 2022, all 22 people on board, including four members of an Indian family, were killed as a Tara Air plane crashed in Nepal's mountainous Mustang district.\n\nIn 2016, all 23 people aboard were killed when a plane of the same airline flying the same route crashed after takeoff.\n\nIn March 2018, a US-Bangla Air crash occurred at the Tribhuvan International Airport, killing 51 people on board. The TIA said \"CRJ7 (Reg-9NAME) of Sourya Airlines took off from Kathmandu at 11:11 am local time during the flight to Pokhara, turned right and crashed at a place on the east side of the runway. It is reported that the fire was brought under control and the rescue work was started immediately. The dead bodies of 18 people were recovered and 1 injured person was rescued and taken to the hospital.\"\n\nEarlier, the Nepal Police informed that 15 bodies were recovered from the crash site. All of the passengers were staff members of the Saurya Airlines. The aircraft was being taken to Pokhara for maintenance.\n\nAlso Read | Nepal Plane Crash: Aircraft Crashes During Takeoff at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu (Watch Videos).\n\nThe pilot, 37-year-old Manish Shakya was rescued from the plane and was rushed to the KMC Hospital in Sinamangal.\n\nThe plane 9N-AME (CRJ 200) was only carrying technical staff of the airline, with no passengers on board. Gyanendra Bhul, information officer at TIA, confirmed that the plane was carrying a few technical staff members.\n\nThe plane crashed shortly after taking off from the runway, at around 11:00 AM today. Following the crash, smoke was seen coming from the plane. Firefighters and security personnel, including Nepal Police and the Nepali Army, have been deployed to the crash site and are currently trying to control the situation.\n\nMeanwhile, the Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA) has been closed following the crash on Wednesday morning, affecting dozens of flights. The shutdown includes all outbound and inbound flights to the Airport.\n\nThe Himalayan Times reported that domestic flights have been stopped at various domestic airports, while international flights have been put on hold or diverted to other airports. The airport will remain closed until the rescue operation is completed. The TIA said \"CRJ7 (Reg-9NAME) of Sourya Airlines took off from Kathmandu at 11:11 am local time during the flight to Pokhara, turned right and crashed at a place on the east side of the runway. It is reported that the fire was brought under control and the rescue work was started immediately. The dead bodies of 18 people were recovered and 1 injured person was rescued and taken to the hospital.\"\n\nEarlier, the Nepal Police informed that 15 bodies were recovered from the crash site. All of the passengers were staff members of the Saurya Airlines. The aircraft was being taken to Pokhara for maintenance.\n\nThe pilot, 37-year-old Manish Shakya was rescued from the plane and was rushed to the KMC Hospital in Sinamangal.\n\nThe plane 9N-AME (CRJ 200) was only carrying technical staff of the airline, with no passengers on board. Gyanendra Bhul, information officer at TIA, confirmed that the plane was carrying a few technical staff members.\n\nThe plane crashed shortly after taking off from the runway, at around 11:00 AM today. Following the crash, smoke was seen coming from the plane. Firefighters and security personnel, including Nepal Police and the Nepali Army, have been deployed to the crash site and are currently trying to control the situation.\n\nMeanwhile, the Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA) has been closed following the crash on Wednesday morning, affecting dozens of flights. The shutdown includes all outbound and inbound flights to the Airport.\n\nThe Himalayan Times reported that domestic flights have been stopped at various domestic airports, while international flights have been put on hold or diverted to other airports. The airport will remain closed until the rescue operation is completed. {"uri": "2024-07-431825503", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:50:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:50:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T07:40:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/plane-crashes-in-nepal-with-18-dead-pilot-sole-survivor/article_fcc90ef7-14ce-5081-bb98-d5058bfdc48f.html", "title": "Plane crashes in Nepal with 18 dead, pilot sole survivor", "body": "People stand at the site after a Saurya Airlines' plane crashed during takeoff at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu\n\nA passenger plane crashed on takeoff in Kathmandu on Wednesday, with the pilot rescued from the flaming wreckage but all 18 others aboard killed, police in the Nepali capital told AFP.\n\nNepal has a woeful track record on aviation safety and the Himalayan republic has seen a spate of deadly light plane and helicopter crashes over the decades.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight was carrying two crew and 17 of the company's staff members, Nepali police spokesman Dan Bahadur Karki told AFP.\n\n\"The pilot has been rescued and is being treated,\" he added. \"Eighteen bodies have been recovered, including one foreigner. We are in the process of taking them for post-mortem.\"\n\nThe flight was being conducted for either technical or maintenance purposes, Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority told AFP without giving further details.\n\nBahadur and Bhul were unable to confirm the nationality of the sole foreigner aboard.\n\nImages of the aftermath shared by Nepal's military showed the plane's fuselage split apart and burnt to a husk.\n\nAround a dozen soldiers in camouflage were standing on top of the wreckage with the surrounding earth coated in fire retardant.\n\nThe plane crashed at around 11:15 am (0530 GMT), the military said in a statement, adding that the army's quick response team had been lending assistance with rescue efforts.\n\nNews portal Khabarhub reported that the airplane had caught fire after skidding on the runway.\n\nThe plane was scheduled to fly on Nepal's busiest air route between Kathmandu and Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\n- Plagued by poor safety -\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance -- issues compounded by the mountainous republic's treacherous geography.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThat accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach to Kathmandu airport.\n\nEarlier that year a Thai Airways aircraft had crashed near the same airport, killing 113 people.\n\npm/gle/mtp\n\nMore from this section\n\nOptimal Blue Launches New Generative AI Assistant Capabilities\n\nSecret Service director steps down after industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance -- issues compounded by the mountainous republic's treacherous geography.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThat accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach to Kathmandu airport.\n\nEarlier that year a Thai Airways aircraft had crashed near the same airport, killing 113 people.\n\npm/gle/mtp", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro {"uri": "8241498968", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:10:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:10:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:09:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://jamaica-gleaner.com/article/world-news/20240724/plane-crashes-just-after-takeoff-nepals-capital-killing-18-people", "title": "Plane crashes just after takeoff from Nepal's capital, killing 18 people", "body": "KATHMANDU, Nepal (AP) -- A plane crashed Wednesday just after taking off from Nepal's capital, killing 18 people and injuring a pilot who was the lone survivor.\n\nAll the people aboard the Saurya Airlines flight including the co-pilot were Nepali except for one passenger, who was a Yemeni national, the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said. Authorities have pulled all 18 bodies from the wreckage, police official Basanta Rajauri said.\n\nThe Bombardier CRJ 200 plane was heading to Nepal's second-most populous city of Pokhara for maintenance work and most of the passengers aboard were either mechanics or airline employees, airport officials said. They were speaking on condition of anonymity because they were not authorised to speak to reporters.\n\nThe pilot has injuries to his eyes but his life is not in any danger, said a doctor at Kathmandu Medical College Hospital, where the pilot is being treated. The doctor spoke on condition of anonymity because she was not authorised to speak to reporters.\n\nThe plane took off from the Kathmandu airport at 11:11 a.m. local time and turned right but crashed moments later in the eastern section of the airport, the Civil Aviation Authority said in a statement.\n\n\"I came out and saw a plane had crashed and there was huge smoke and fire coming out,\" said Ram Kumar Khatri Chetri, who own a car parts store barely 100 metres (330 feet) from the crash site. \"There was chaos and confusion.\"\n\n\"It was just horrible and there was no way that anyone could just go near the plane and help out when there was so much fire and even explosions,\" he said.\n\nIt is the monsoon rain season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Visibility was low across the capital, however.\n\nThe Kathmandu airport, the main airport serving Nepal, is inside a valley surrounded by mountains that make takeoffs and landings challenging for pilots. The airport is right next to the city, and is surrounded by houses and neighbourhoods.\n\nThe bodies have been taken to the TU Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for autopsy. The airline manifest showed there were two pilots and 17 passengers on board.\n\nGrieving relatives gathered at the hospital forensics department to collect the bodies of their loved ones, though they are not likely to be released for a day or two.\n\nThe co-pilot Sasant Katuwal had been flying only for the past three years after completing training in France, his uncle Dhyan Bahadur Khadka said at the hospital. He had just received a visa to go to Germany for further training and was excited about that, Khadka said.\n\nKhadka said his nephew had a bright future in aviation. \"His parents are grieving the loss of their only child,\" Khadka said. \"He was unmarried. He was not just tall and handsome, but he was well behaved,\"\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, was closed for hours as emergency crew and investigators began their work.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. {"uri": "8240786787", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "07:55:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T07:55:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T07:54:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.withinnigeria.com/news/2024/07/24/just-in-tragedy-strikes-nepal-as-plane-carrying-19-crashes-on-takeoff/", "title": "JUST-IN: Tragedy strikes Nepal as plane carrying 19 crashes on takeoff", "body": "This is the latest in a series of fatal plane crashes in Nepal, including a 2023 accident that killed 72 people.\n\nA tragic accident occurred in Kathmandu, Nepal, on Wednesday morning, when a Saurya Airlines passenger plane carrying 19 people crashed during takeoff, erupting into a massive fire.\n\nEmergency responders swiftly sprang into action, battling to extinguish the blaze and rescue those on board.\n\nThe incident happened at approximately 11:15 am local time (0530 GMT), according to a statement released by Nepal's military.\n\n\"Rescue work is going on\" with the army's quick response team lending assistance, the statement added.\n\nFurther details were \"still being confirmed\", Kathmandu airport general manager Jagannath Niroula told AFP.\n\nThe Kathmandu Post newspaper said 19 people including air crew were aboard the flight.\n\nNews portal Khabarhub reported that the airplane had caught fire after skidding on the runway and was \"releasing a significant plume of smoke\".\n\nThe plane was en route to Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\nNepal's aviation sector has experienced rapid growth, facilitating transportation to remote regions and catering to adventure seekers.\n\nHowever, this expansion has been marred by a poor safety record, attributed to inadequate training and maintenance.\n\nAs a result, the European Union has imposed a ban on Nepali airlines from operating in its airspace.\n\nThe country's challenging terrain has further exacerbated its struggles with aviation safety, making it a pressing concern.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThat accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach to Kathmandu airport.\n\nEarlier that year a Thai Airways aircraft had crashed near the same airport, killing 113 people.\n\nAuthorities have yet to release the identity of those aboard.", "source": {"uri": "withinnigeria.com", "dataType": "news", "title": A fire has been brought under control.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crew worked.\n\nIt is monsoon rainy season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. {"uri": "2024-07-431835148", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:59:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:59:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:37:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/least-18-dead-plane-crashes-083732780.html", "title": "At least 18 dead after plane crashes in Nepal", "body": "At least 18 dead after plane crashes in Nepal\n\nOur Foreign Staff\n\n24 July 2024 at 10:37 am\n\nAt least 18 people have been killed after a small plane crashed and caught fire while it was taking off from Nepal's capital Kathmandu.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight was carrying two crew and 17 of the company's staff members, Dan Bahadur Karki, a Nepali police spokesman, said.\n\n\"The pilot has been rescued and is being treated. It is not possible to confirm the status of others on board right now. Many have not survived,\" he added.\n\nEighteen Nepalis and one foreigner were aboard the flight, Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority told AFP, adding he did not have any details on the latter's nationality.\n\nThe flight was being conducted for either technical or maintenance purposes, he added.\n\nImages of the aftermath shared by Nepal's military showed the plane's fuselage split apart and burnt to a husk.\n\nAround a dozen soldiers in camouflage were standing on top of the wreckage with the surrounding earth coated in fire retardant.\n\nThe plane crashed at around 11:15 am (05:30 GMT), the military said in a statement, adding that the army's quick response team had been lending assistance with rescue efforts.\n\nNews site Khabarhub reported that the aircraft had caught fire after skidding on the runway.\n\nThe plane was scheduled to fly on Nepal's busiest air route between Kathmandu and Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\nNepal has a woeful track record on aviation safety and the Himalayan republic has seen a spate of deadly light plane and helicopter crashes over the decades.\n\nThe country's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers. But insufficient staff training and maintenance compounded by the mountainous republic's treacherous geography has led to several incidents.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThat accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992 when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach to Kathmandu airport.\n\nEarlier that year a Thai Airways aircraft had crashed near the same airport, killing 113 people.", "source": {"uri": "aol.co.uk", "dataType": "news", The status of the others on board is uncertain, but many have not survived,\" he added.\n\nImages shared by Nepal's military show the plane's fuselage split apart and burned. About a dozen soldiers in camouflage were seen on the wreckage, surrounded by fire retardant.\n\nThe crash occurred at around 11:15 am (0530 GMT), with the army's quick response team assisting in the rescue efforts. {"uri": "8241415074", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:19:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:19:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:16:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://wtop.com/asia/2024/07/a-plane-with-19-people-on-board-slips-off-the-runway-and-crashes-at-nepal-airport/", "title": "Plane crashes just after takeoff from Nepal's capital, killing 18 people. Pilot is lone survivor - WTOP News", "body": "Police official Basanta Rajauri said authorities have pulled out all 18 bodies. The pilot has injuries to his eyes but his life is not in any danger, said a doctor at Kathmandu Medical College Hospital, where the pilot is being treated. The doctor spoke on condition of anonymity because she was not authorized to speak to media.\n\nA press statement issued by the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said the Saurya Airlines domestic plane, which was scheduled to head to the resort town of Pokhara, took off at 11:11 a.m. local time from Kathmandu airport and turned right but crashed moments later in the eastern section of the airport.\n\nIt is monsoon rain season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Visibility was low across the capital, however.\n\nThe Kathmandu airport, the main airport serving Nepal, is located inside a valley surrounded by mountains on most sides. It is considered a challenging airport for pilots and bigger planes have to come through an opening on the mountain to land. It is right next to the city, and is surrounded by houses and neighborhoods.\n\nThe bodies have been taken to the T.U. Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for autopsy. The airline manifest showed there were two pilots and 17 passengers on board. The crew and 16 passengers were Nepali nationals and one passenger was identified as a Yemeni national.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, has been closed as emergency crew and investigators began their work.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, killing 51 people while 20 on board survived. An investigation confirmed the plane was misaligned with the runway and its pilot was disoriented and tried to land in \"sheer desperation\" when the plane crashed.\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet landing in dense fog skidded off a slippery runway at the airport. The plane was carrying 238 people but there were no serious injuries.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. AFP PHOTO\n\n\"The pilot has been rescued and is being treated,\" he added. \"Eighteen bodies have been recovered, including one foreigner. We are in the process of taking them for postmortem [examination].\"\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nThe flight was being conducted for either technical or maintenance purposes, Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority told AFP without giving further details.\n\nBahadur and Bhul were unable to confirm the nationality of the sole foreigner aboard.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nImages of the aftermath shared by Nepal's military showed the plane's fuselage split apart and burnt to a husk.\n\nAbout a dozen soldiers in camouflage were standing on top of the wreckage with the surrounding earth coated in fire retardant.\n\nThe plane crashed at about 11:15 a.m., the military said in a statement, adding that the army's quick response team had been lending assistance with rescue efforts.\n\nNews portal Khabarhub reported that the airplane had caught fire after skidding on the runway.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe plane was scheduled to fly on Nepal's busiest air route between Kathmandu and Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan nation.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance -- issues compounded by the mountainous country's treacherous geography.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nThe country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThat accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach to Kathmandu's Tribhuvan {"uri": "8240947509", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:34:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:34:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:34:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.greaterkashmir.com/latest-news/18-killed-in-saurya-airlines-plane-crash-in-kathmandu/", "title": "18 killed in Saurya Airlines plane crash in Kathmandu - Greater Kashmir", "body": "New Delhi, July 24: A tragic accident occurred on Wednesday when a Saurya Airlines plane crashed and caught fire at Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA) in Kathmandu during takeoff. The flight, bound for Pokhara, was carrying only the airline's technical staff.\n\nThe crash resulted in the deaths of 18 people, with the pilot, who is currently receiving medical treatment in the hospital, being the sole survivor.\n\nThere were 19 individuals on board, including technical staff members and two crew members.\n\nThe incident happened at around 11:15 local time just a few minutes after the plane took off. According to a statement by the Nepal Civil Aviation Authority's search and rescue coordination centre, the plane suffered a runway excursion, leading to the fatal crash.\n\nVisuals from the site show rescue workers navigating through the wreckage, with large sections of the plane completely blackened and charred. Initial images depicted the aircraft enveloped in fire and smoke. Fire engines and ambulances were promptly dispatched to the scene.\n\nAmong the deceased, 17 were Nepali nationals, and one was a Yemeni engineer working with the airline. TIA Spokesperson Subash Jha confirmed the details, stating that thick smoke was seen billowing from the airport as police and firefighters carried out rescue operations.\n\nPreliminary reports indicated that five bodies were initially recovered from the crash site.\n\nNepal has been criticized for its poor air safety record, averaging about one flight disaster annually. Since 2010, the country has witnessed at least 12 fatal plane crashes, including this latest incident. In January 2023, a Yeti Airlines flight tragically crashed near Pokhara, killing all 72 people on board.\n\nSaurya Airlines is a moderate local airline that operates flights to five destinations within Nepal, using a fleet of three Bombardier CRJ-200 jets.", "source": {"uri": "greaterkashmir.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Greater Kashmir"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The plane was en route for technical maintenance, he added.\n\n\"Rescue efforts were started immediately and the situation was brought under control,\" the aviation authority said.\n\nThe crash once again highlights the dangers of air travel in Nepal, a country often referred to as one of the riskiest places to fly due to multiple factors including its mountainous terrain.\n\nThe Himalayan country, home to eight of the world's 14 highest mountains including Everest, has a record of air accidents. Its weather can change suddenly, and airstrips are typically sited in difficult-to-reach, mountainous areas.\n\nAircraft with 19 seats or fewer are more likely to have accidents due to these difficulties, according to a 2019 safety report from the Civil Aviation Authority.\n\nWhile the country has made improvements in safety standards in recent years, challenges remain, and a lack of {"uri": "8240999438", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:08:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:08:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:06:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/nepal-plane-crash-at-kathmandu-airport-kills-18/84820638", "title": "Nepal plane crash at Kathmandu airport kills 18", "body": "KATHMANDU (Reuters) -At least 18 people were killed when a regional passenger plane belonging to Nepal's Saurya Airlines crashed and caught fire while taking off from the capital Kathmandu on Wednesday, officials said.\n\nThe plane, carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, was going for regular maintenance to Nepal's new Pokhara airport, which opened last January and is equipped with aircraft maintenance hangars, they said.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nTelevision visuals showed fire fighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields. Bodies were carried to ambulances on stretchers as local residents looked on, the television showed.\n\nThe airport was closed temporarily, officials said.\n\nA Saurya Airlines official said the plane was a 50-seater CRJ200 aircraft.\n\nAccording to Flight Radar 24 flight tracking, Saurya currently operates two CRJ-200 regional jets, a programme that was owned by Canada's Bombardier but which was bought by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in 2020.\n\nSaurya says it has another CRJ200 in its fleet, but it has not flown for a long time.\n\nBombardier referred questions about the incident to Canada-based MHI RJ Aviation Group (MHIRJ), which did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nEstablished in 2014, Saurya says on its website that it has introduced the \"jet experience\" on Nepal's domestic routes and that it flies to five destinations.\n\nNepal has been criticised for a poor air safety record, and nearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in the Himalayan country since 2000.\n\nThe deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nMost recently, at least 72 people were killed in a Yeti airlines crash in January 2023 that was later attributed to the pilots mistakenly cutting off power.\n\n(Reporting by Kathmandu newsroom; Additional The aircraft, a Bombardier CRJ 200, was en route to the resort town of Pokhara when it suffered a runway excursion and slipped off the runway.\n\nThe accident occurred amid low visibility conditions in the capital, although it was not raining at the time. Emergency responders, including police and firefighters, quickly arrived at the scene to carry out rescue operations. Images from local media showed thick smoke rising from the crash site, with plane wreckage scattered in a ditch adjacent to the runway.\n\nSubash Jha, spokesperson for TIA, confirmed that the crash resulted in casualties. "https://static-ai.asianetnews.com/images/01j3hqg6asam7ara0wd6zf6mp7/whatsapp-image-2024-07-24-at-12-02-01.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9758495", "eventUri": "eng-9758495", {"uri": "8241154490", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "11:38:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T11:38:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T11:38:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/kathmandu-plane-crash-one-aircraft-accident-every-year-why-flying-is-risky-13796525.html", "title": "At least one plane crash a year, why flying in Nepal is so risky", "body": "Another year, another plane crash in Nepal. On Wednesday (July 24), 18 people died in a Saurya Airlines accident when the Pokhara-bound aircraft suffered a runaway excursion during takeoff from Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nThere were a total of 19 people, including two crew members, in the flight when it took off around 11 am on Wednesday to get its broken engine repaired at Pokhara, but only the pilot of the aircraft could be saved while all others have died.\n\nNepal is known for its picturesque landscape that lures tourists but the country's air transport sector has been plagued by multiple accidents and crashes.\n\nSince 2000, as many as 360 people have been killed in Nepal in at least 19 air crashes. Wednesday's crash at Kathmandu's TIA has added to the long list.\n\nNepal and its bitter history of plane crashes\n\nOn January 15, 2023, Nepal witnessed its worst aviation disaster since 1992 after a Yeti Airlines twin-engine ATR 72-500 aircraft which took off from Tribhuvan International Airport with 72 people, including four crew members, on board crashed on the Seti River gorge between the old and new airport in central city of Pokhara.\n\nFor the unversed, in 1992, all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines (PIA) plane were killed when it ploughed into a hill as it tried to land in Kathmandu.\n\nRescue officials could only manage to recover 71 bodies with the other missing passenger presumed to be dead. Among those who were killed in the accident, five were Indians.\n\nAlso Read: 18 dead as plane with 'broken' engine crashes during takeoff in Nepal's Kathmandu\n\nAs per the earlier reports the Yeti airplane had crashed just '10 to 20 seconds' before landing. An analysis of the cockpit voice recorder and flight data recorder had shown the propellers of both engines went into \"feather in the base leg of descending.\"\n\nHowever, in December last year, a government-appointed investigation panel revealed that the Yeti Airlines crash in 2023 was due to \"pilot error\".\n\nWhy are there so many plane crashes in Nepal?\n\nThere are a host of reasons why flying in Nepal is not just tricky but dangerous. The top-most being the country's topography.\n\nNepal, situated between India and China, boasts of having eight of the world's 14 highest mountains, including Mt Everest, and the country's beautiful rugged landscapes make it a popular tourist destination for trekkers.\n\nBut as much as it is good for tourism, it is risky for airplanes. An earlier report by ANI quoted Captain Amit Singh, a commercial pilot and founder of Safety Matters Foundation, as saying that Kathmandu is a valley, it is like a bowl and the airport in the city is in between, surrounded by mountains, high mountains on all sides. \"So it is a very challenging airfield,\" he added.\n\nAirports in the country are built in mountainous regions and therefore, have shorter runways.\n\nIn 2019, Nepal's civil aviation authority released a safety report where it admitted that the country's \"diversity of weather patterns together with hostile topography are the main challenges surrounding aircraft operations in Nepal due to which the number of accidents related to small aircraft... seems comparatively higher\".\n\nThe take-off and landing statistically are more dangerous in Nepal than other parts of flight as it has to be done at high altitudes. The low air density decreases the performance of a flight and makes it more difficult to slow down.\n\nNot just this, Nepal also experiences sudden changes in weather. Also, with odd weather conditions, visibility becomes a major hurdle for pilots flying in the region.\n\nPilots, earlier, have even voiced concerns saying that the smaller aircraft used in the region aren't equipped with the technology to detect the unpredictable conditions, making flying an even riskier proposition.\n\nAging fleet\n\nNepal, one of the poorer countries in the world, depends heavily on aging airplanes for its domestic flights. Surprisingly, almost all of these aircrafts are not equipped with the mandatory modern devices including radar and GPS technology that can help mitigate problems with visibility or weather.\n\nThe Yeti Airlines plane which crashed in January 2023 was 15 years old.\n\nNepali airlines banned by EU\n\nSince 1960, Nepal has been a member of the UN's International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) which obliges the country to abide by the international conventions, regulations, standards, and recommended practices in aviation safety.\n\nDespite making significant efforts to enhance safety, Nepal aviation industry's safety record still does not match up with the requirements of other civil aviation authorities.\n\nTherefore, Nepali airlines have been banned from operating in the European Union's airspace since 2013 and Nepal, till date, remains on the EU Air Safety list.\n\nA look at Nepal plane & helicopter crashes history\n\nJuly 24, 2024\n\nAt least 18 people were killed when a Bombardier CRJ 200 plane crashed and caught fire while taking off from Kathmandu.\n\nJuly 11, 2023\n\nSix people were killed in a helicopter crash in central Nepal. The chopper, which departed from Solukhunvhu district, home to Mount Everest and other high mountain peaks, had five Mexican nationals and one Nepali pilot on board.\n\nJanuary 15, 2023\n\nA twin-engine ATR 72 aircraft carrying 72 people, operated by Nepal's Yeti Airlines, crashed in Pokhara, killing all on board.\n\nMay 29, 2022\n\nSixteen Nepalis, four Indians and two Germans died on a De Havilland Canada DHC-6-300 Twin Otter aircraft that crashed within 15 minutes after take off from Pokhara.\n\nFebruary 27, 2019\n\nAll seven people, including the country's tourism minister, on board a helicopter died after it crashed in bad weather in eastern Nepal.\n\nMarch 12, 2018\n\nFifty-one of 71 people on a Bangladeshi airliner operated by US-Bangla Airlines died when it crashed in cloudy weather as it came in to land at the Kathmandu airport.\n\nFebruary 26, 2016\n\nTwo people were feared dead after a small plane crashed in western Nepal's Kalikot district. It was operated by Kasthamandap Airlines.\n\nFebruary 24, 2016\n\nA small plane, with 23 people on board, crashed in bad weather, killing everyone. The Twin Otter aircraft, operated by Tara Air, was on a flight from Pokhara to Jomsom in western Nepal.\n\nFebruary 16, 2014\n\nAll 18 people on a small plane that crashed in bad weather were killed. The Twin Otter aircraft was operated by state-run Nepal Airlines Corp.\n\nSeptember 28, 2012\n\nA small propeller-driven Dornier aircraft struck a bird and crashed shortly after takeoff from Kathmandu, killing 19 people, including seven British and five Chinese passengers.\n\nSeptember 25, 2011\n\nA small plane carrying foreign tourists to view Mount Everest crashed in bad weather near Kathmandu, killing all 19 people on board. The Beech aircraft was operated by private airline Buddha Air.\n\nDecember 16, 2010\n\nA small plane crashed in the Himalayan foothills of remote east Nepal, killing all 22 people onboard. The Twin Otter aircraft was operated by Tara Air.\n\nAugust 24, 2010\n\nFourteen people - including four Americans, a Japanese and British national - were killed when their small plane crashed in bad weather in Nepal. It was operated by privately held Agni Air.\n\nOctober 8, 2008\n\nA small Twin Otter plane crashed in the remote mountains of northeast Nepal, killing at least 18 people, mostly foreigners.\n\nMarch 4, 2008\n\nFour UN arms monitors were among at least 10 people killed in a helicopter crash in Nepal.\n\nJune 21, 2006\n\nA Twin Otter passenger plane operated by Yeti Airlines crashed minutes before landing in the west of the country, killing all nine people on board.\n\nMay 25, 2004\n\nA Twin Otter cargo plane crashed in the Mount Everest region, killing its three crew. It was operated by Yeti Airlines.\n\nAugust 22, 2002\n\nAnother Twin Otter plane, carrying foreign tourists, slammed into a mountain in bad weather in Nepal, killing all 18 people on board. It was operated by Shangrila Air.\n\nJuly 17, 2002\n\nFour people were feared dead after a twin-engined aircraft crashed into a mountain in west Nepal minutes before it was due to land.\n\nJuly 27, The aircraft, operated by Saurya Airlines, was en route from Kathmandu to Pokhara when it crashed shortly after takeoff. Videos of the incident have also emerged. The plane had 19 people on board, and only one pilot survived. It has now been reported that three members of the same family were among those who lost their lives in the crash.\n\nAccording to a statement from the airline, the ill-fated flight was carrying flight maintenance staff Manuraj Sharma, his wife Prija Khatiwada, and their four-year-old son Adhiraj Sharma. All three perished in the crash. The statement added that Prija was also a government employee, working as an assistant computer operator in the Ministry of Energy. Notably, 17 of the deceased were staff members of Saurya Airlines.\n\nCaptain M.R. Shakya, 37, was the sole survivor of the crash and has been rescued from the crash site. He is currently receiving treatment at the hospital. The aircraft involved was a Bombardier CRJ-200ER, built in 2003, and was being transported for maintenance. The airline stated that the plane was heading to Pokhara for a technical inspection after repairs. The plane took off from Runway 2 but crashed on Runway 20.\n\nAlso Read: Watch: CCTV Footage Captures Plane Crash At Kathmandu Airport\n\nPlane crashes are not a new issue in Nepal. The country has seen numerous reports of such accidents. Various factors contribute to these incidents, including mountainous terrain, unpredictable weather, outdated aircraft, inadequate infrastructure, and the prolonged use of older planes. According to reports, Nepal has experienced around 28 plane crashes over the past 30 years. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers rummaging through the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields.\n\nBodies were carried to ambulances on stretchers as local residents looked on, the television showed.\n\nThe officials added that the plane was a Bombardier, officials said, and media reported it belonged to local Saurya Airlines.
