The plane was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians to Pokhara city to repair another aircraft, officials said.\n\nThe pilot was the only one onboard to survive, as officials said that 18 people had died in the crash. Seventeen of those who died are Nepali while one is a Yemeni national, who was working as an engineer.\n\nVideos shared online shows the Bombardier CRJ 200 plane flying low above the runway before suddenly tilting sideways and quickly heading nose-first towards the ground. The aircraft exploded into a fireball, with black smoke filling the sky as horrified bystanders watched on from an airport shuttle bus.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nIt is not yet clear what caused the crash with investigations currently undergoing. An airport official said \"some cracking noises were heard\" from the plane.\n\nNepal is a country often referred to as one of the riskiest places to fly due to multiple factors including its mountainous terrain. "body": "A plane carrying nineteen people crashed after takeoff in Kathmandu, the capital of Nepal, on Wednesday morning, according to a local newspaper, which cited an airport official.\n\nThe publication stated that rescue efforts by police and firefighters were underway when the Saurya Airlines plane crashed at approximately 11:00 am (05:15 GMT).\n\nAccording to airport spokesman Premnath Thakur, \"nineteen people, including aircrew, were aboard.\"\n\nNews portal Khabarhub reported that the airplane had caught fire and was \"releasing a significant plume of smoke\".\n\nThe flight was en-route to Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThat accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach to Kathmandu airport.\n\nEarlier that year a Thai Airways aircraft had crashed near the same airport, killing 113 people.\n\nAuthorities have yet to release the identity of those The head of airport security in Kathmandu reported that rescue teams are on-site, dealing with the charred remains of the aircraft.\n\nThe plane, operated by Saurya Airlines, was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians. As per preliminary information, eighteen bodies have been recovered from the crash site. The passengers were en route to the city of Pokhara for maintenance inspection work. {"uri": "8241806323", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:56:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:56:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:55:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://kuwaittimes.com/article/17055/world/subcontinent/nepal-plane-crash-kills-18-pilot-survives/", "title": "Nepal plane crash kills 18, pilot survives", "body": "KATHMANDU: A passenger plane crashed on take-off in Kathmandu on Wednesday, with the pilot rescued from the wreckage but all 18 others aboard killed, police in the Nepali capital told AFP. Nepal has a woeful track record on aviation safety and the Himalayan republic has seen a spate of deadly light plane and helicopter crashes over the decades.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight was carrying two crew and 17 of the company's staff members, Nepali police spokesman Dan Bahadur Karki said. \"The pilot has been rescued and is being treated,\" he said. \"Eighteen bodies have been recovered, including one foreigner. We are in the process of taking them for post-mortem.\" The Civil Aviation Authority said the dead foreigner was a Yemeni engineer.\n\nA news release from the airport said the aircraft \"veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway\" shortly after take-off. The survivor was in serious condition in hospital, it said. Ram Kumar K C, who runs a tyre store near the crash site, told AFP the plane caught fire after hitting the ground. \"We were about to run to the site but then there was an explosion so we ran away again,\" the 48-year-old said.\n\nNepal's Prime Minister K P Sharma Oli visited the crash site and asked people to \"be patient\" in a social media post, without elaborating. An emergency cabinet meeting was called to form a panel to investigate the incident, a government spokesman said.\n\nThe flight was being conducted for either technical or maintenance purposes, Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority told AFP, without giving further details. Images of the aftermath shared by Nepal's military showed the plane's fuselage split apart and burnt to a husk. Around a dozen soldiers in camouflage gear stood on top of the wreckage, the surrounding earth coated in fire retardant.\n\nDozens of grieving relatives gathered later outside a nearby hospital where the bodies were transported from the crash scene. \"I am heartbroken,\" Rajan Acharya, the brother of a safety officer aboard the flight, told AFP. \"He was my brother, but even more than that, we were best friends.\" The plane was scheduled to fly on Nepal's busiest air route between Kathmandu and Pokhara, an important tourism hub. Saurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers. But it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance, issues compounded by mountainous Nepal's treacherous geography. The European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nNepal has some of the world's trickiest runways on which to land, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots. The weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions. Nepal's last major incident involving a commercial flight was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard. That was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane were killed when it crashed on approach to Kathmandu airport. A Thai Airways aircraft crashed near the same airport earlier that year, killing 113 people. - Agencies", "source": {"uri": "kuwaittimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Kuwait Times"}, "authors": {"uri": "8240959523", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:42:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:42:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:41:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.unilad.com/news/world-news/nepal-plane-crash-18-dead-footage-665685-20240724", "title": "Devastating footage shows the moment passenger plane nose dives and explodes killing 18 people", "body": "At least 18 people have died after a small plane crashed on an airport runway in Nepal.\n\nOnly one person - the pilot - survived the crash which took place as the plane attempted to take off from Tribhuvan International Airport, in the capital city of Kathmandu, at approximately 11:11am local time today (July 24).\n\nWarning: Distressing Content:\n\nThe aircraft had been bound for the city of Pokhara, and was carrying 18 Nepalis and a Yemeni citizen. The passengers included two crew members and 17 technicians, all of whom were employees of Saurya Airlines; the carrier operating the flight.\n\nFootage and images of the crash show the plane careering back towards the Earth just moments after its wheels left the ground, heading towards the eastern section of the airport.\n\nA flash of light and a huge cloud of black smoke could then be seen billowing from the direction of the crash site.\n\nSpeaking to BBC Nepali, airport chief Jagannath Niraula said the accident 'happened as soon as [the plane] left the ground, in not even a minute'.\n\nNiraula told the publication the plane appeared to begin its flight in the wrong direction.\n\n\"As soon as it took off, it turned right, [when it] should have turned left,\" he said.\n\nGyanendra Bhul, an information officer at Tribhuvan International Airport, told CNN the aircraft had been on its way to undergo technical maintenance when it crashed.\n\nThe aviation authority has also commented on the incident, saying: \"Rescue efforts were started immediately and the situation was brought under control.\"\n\nFire engines and ambulances rushed to the scene, with footage showing responding firefighters working to put out the fire which broke out amid the crash.\n\nOnce the fire was brought under control, rescue workers began searching through the wreckage of the plane for the passengers.\n\nAccording to Sky News, police official Basanta Rajauri said authorities have now pulled out the bodies of all 18 people who died.\n\nTej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesperson for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport, said: \"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital.\"\n\nThe pilot suffered eye injuries in the crash but was not in a life-threatening condition. He was taken to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital to receive treatment.\n\nAuthorities are now investigating what caused the plane to crash. It was not raining when the plane went down, though visibility in the capital was generally low at the time.", "source": {"uri": "unilad.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UNILAD"}, "authors": [], It is not possible to confirm the status of others on board right now. Many have not survived,\" he added.\n\nEighteen Nepalis and one foreigner were aboard the flight, Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority told AFP, adding he did not have any details on the tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\n- Plagued by poor safety -\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThat accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach to Kathmandu airport.\n\nEarlier that This flight was a test run, so no regular passengers were present; the occupants included company employees and engineers.\n\nFollowing the mishap, the plane caught fire, sending up a large plume of smoke. {"uri": "8241081385", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:55:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:55:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:54:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://ktbb.com/post/?p=1341087", "title": "Title of the Page", "body": "(NEW YORK) -- At least 18 people were killed when a plane crashed during takeoff in Nepal on Wednesday, aviation officials said.\n\nNineteen people were on board when the Saurya Airlines flight went down at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, according to a notice from the Search and Rescue Coordination Center of the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal, which was posted online by the airport.\n\nThe domestic flight to Pokhara took off at 11:11 a.m., then \"turned right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" aviation officials said.\n\n\"It is reported that the fire was brought under control and the rescue work was started immediately and the dead bodies of 18 people were collected and 1 injured person was rescued and taken to the hospital,\" the statement said.\n\nThe flight's pilot survived, the aviation authority said, identifying him as Captain Manish Rana Shakya. He was transported to a local hospital with critical injuries, officials said.\n\nOfficials released the flight's manifest, which included 16 Nepali passengers and one Yemeni passenger. Officials said all were killed, along with the co-pilot, whose nationality was not listed.\n\nA video streamed live on Facebook from the airport appeared to show people waiting at their departure gate watching in horror as plumes of dark smoke rise near the airport perimeter.\n\nThe plane, which aviation officials identified as a CRJ-200, was registered in Nepal as 9N-AME.\n\nThe European Commission includes all of Nepal's air carriers, including Saurya, on its \"Air Safety List,\" banning them from operating within the European Union because of safety concerns.\n\nA Yeti Airlines passenger plane crashed in Nepal in January 2023, killing all 72 people onboard, including two Americans, officials said.\n\nThat flight, which had also been traveling from Kathmandu to Pokhara, was {"uri": "8240855728", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:38:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:38:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:38:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/south-asia/article/3271699/plane-crashes-nepal-after-take-killing-18-pilot-sole-survivor", "title": "18 killed in Nepal plane crash, pilot sole survivor", "body": "The plane had already taken off and turned right before it crashed in the eastern section of the airport, a statement said\n\nA passenger plane crashed on take-off in Kathmandu on Wednesday, with the pilot rescued from the flaming wreckage, but all 18 others aboard killed, police in the Nepali capital said.\n\nNepal has a woeful track record on aviation safety, and the Himalayan republic has seen a spate of deadly light plane and helicopter crashes over the decades.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight was carrying two crew and 17 of the company\u2019s staff members, said Nepali police spokesman Dan Bahadur Karki.\n\n\u201cThe pilot has been rescued and is being treated,\u201d he added. \u201cEighteen bodies have been recovered, including one foreigner. We are in the process of taking them for postmortem.\u201d\n\nThe flight was being conducted for either technical or maintenance purposes, Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal\u2019s Civil Aviation Authority said, without giving further details.\n\nBahadur and Bhul were unable to confirm the nationality of the sole foreigner aboard.\n\nImages of the aftermath shared by Nepal\u2019s military showed the plane\u2019s fuselage split apart and burnt to a husk.\n\nAround a dozen soldiers in camouflage were standing on top of the wreckage, with the surrounding earth coated in fire retardant.\n\nThe plane crashed at around 11:15am,, the military said in a statement, adding that the army\u2019s quick response team had been lending help with rescue efforts.\n\nNews portal Khabarhub reported that the aeroplane had caught fire after skidding on the runway.\n\nThe plane was scheduled to fly on Nepal\u2019s busiest air route between Kathmandu and Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\nNepal\u2019s air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas, as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance \u2013 issues compounded by the mountainous republic\u2019s treacherous geography.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world\u2019s trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal\u2019s last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThat accident was {"uri": "8240926655", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:23:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:23:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:22:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.opinionnigeria.com/18-dead-pilot-sole-survivor-in-nepal-plane-crash/", "title": "18 dead, pilot sole survivor in Nepal plane crash", "body": "17 employees and two crew members were on board the Saurya Airlines aircraft, a spokeswoman for the Nepali police told AFP.\n\nAll 18 people on board were murdered when a passenger plane crashed on takeoff in Kathmandu on Wednesday; the pilot was saved from the flaming wreckage, according to authorities in the Nepali capital, who spoke to AFP.\n\nNepal's aviation safety record is appalling; over the years, the Himalayan nation has experienced a number of fatal light aircraft and helicopter incidents.\n\n17 employees and two crew members were on board the Saurya Airlines aircraft, a spokeswoman for the Nepali police told AFP.\n\n\"The pilot has been rescued and is being treated,\" he added. \"Eighteen bodies have been recovered, including one foreigner. We are in the process of taking them for post-mortem.\"\n\nThe flight was being conducted for either technical or maintenance purposes, Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority told AFP without giving further details.\n\nBahadur and Bhul were unable to confirm the nationality of the sole foreigner aboard.\n\nImages of the aftermath shared by Nepal's military showed the plane's fuselage split apart and burnt to a husk.\n\nAround a dozen soldiers in camouflage were standing on top of the wreckage with the surrounding earth coated in fire retardant.\n\nThe plane crashed at around 11:15 am (0530 GMT), the military said in a statement, adding that the army's quick response team had been lending assistance with rescue efforts.\n\nNews portal Khabarhub reported that the airplane had caught fire after skidding on the runway.\n\nThe plane was scheduled to fly on Nepal's busiest air route between Kathmandu and Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance -- issues compounded by the mountainous republic's treacherous geography.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThat accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach to Kathmandu airport.\n\nEarlier that year a Thai Airways aircraft had crashed near the same airport, killing {"uri": "8240866884", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:46:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:46:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:45:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.opindia.com/2024/07/18-died-in-saurya-airlines-crash-at-kathmandu-airport-in-nepal-pilot-is-the-lone-survivor/", "title": "18 died in Saurya Airlines crash at Kathmandu airport in Nepal, pilot is the lone survivor", "body": "Pilot 37-year-old Manish Shakya was rescued from the wreckage, while the bodies of 18 others were recovered from the crash site.\n\nA Saurya Airlines flight carrying 19 people crashed during take-off at Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA) in Kathmandu, Nepal, on Wednesday. Bodies of 18 people onboard flight 9N-AME have been confirmed dead, as per reports.\n\nThe pilot of the plane, Captain Manish Shakya, is the lone survivor who has been rushed to KMC Hospital in Sinamangal, as per TIA Spokesperson Subash Jha.\n\nThe TIA said \"CRJ7 (Reg-9NAME) of Sourya Airlines took off from Kathmandu at 11:11 am local time during the flight to Pokhara, turned right and crashed at a place on the east side of the runway. It is reported that the fire was brought under control and the rescue work was started immediately. The dead bodies of 18 people were recovered and 1 injured person was rescued and taken to the hospital.\"\n\nNotably, this was a test flight, hence there were no regular passengers on the aircraft. The people on the plane included technicians and staff of the airline. The plane was departing from Kathmandu to Pokhara.\n\nAccording to officials at Tribhuvan International Airport, the Bombardier CRJ-200 aircraft crashed during take-off at around 11.11 AM, causing it to skid off the runway and catch fire. A team of firefighters was deployed to extinguish the fire that released a huge plume of smoke.\n\nThe plane was taking off from the Southern-end of the runway (Koteshwor side). Videos of the crash have appeared on social media, which show that the plane suddenly make a sharp right turn right immediately after take-off and its wing tip hit the ground.\n\nThe plane caught fire immediately, and then plunged into a gorge on the eastern side of the runway. Photos show that the aircraft's fuselage in severely damaged condition on the airport grounds.\n\nPilot 37-year-old Manish Shakya was rescued from the wreckage, while the bodies of 18 others were recovered from the crash site.\n\nThe Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA) was closed following the crash on Wednesday morning, affecting dozens of flights. However later the operations were resumed as the runway and other infrastructure was not damaged due to the crash. The closure had impacted both domestic and international flights, with domestic flights halted at various domestic airports and international flights either put on hold or diverted to other airports.\n\nAs per planespotters.net, the Bombardier CRJ-200 plane was manufactured in April 2003, and was delivered to Saurya Airlines in 2017 after it changed several owners after the first user {"uri": "2024-07-431807800", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:37:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:37:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T07:25:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.wxow.com/news/crime/plane-crashes-during-takeoff-in-nepal-killing-at-least-18/article_e1b673d2-bfd8-55b1-8978-f058a9035a50.html", "title": "Plane crashes during takeoff in Nepal, killing at least 18", "body": "(CNN) -- At least 18 people were killed after a small plane skidded off the runway in Nepal's capital on Wednesday, according to local officials.\n\nOne person survived the Saurya Airlines crash, the Civil Aviation Authority said in a statement. All aboard - 18 Nepalis and a Yemeni citizen - were employees of the carrier, according to police.\n\nImages from Nepal police showed thick smoke billowing from the burning aircraft on the the airport runway.\n\nThe aircraft crashed during takeoff from Kathmandu to the city of Pokhara around 11 a.m. local time, Gyanendra Bhul, an information officer at Tribhuvan International Airport told CNN.\n\nThe plane was en route for technical maintenance, he added.\n\n\"Rescue efforts were started immediately and the situation was brought under control,\" the aviation authority said.\n\nThe crash once again highlights the dangers of air travel in Nepal, a country often referred to as one of the riskiest places to fly due to multiple factors including its mountainous terrain.\n\nThe Himalayan country, home to eight of the world's 14 highest mountains including Everest, has a record of air accidents. Its weather can change suddenly, and airstrips are typically sited in difficult-to-reach, mountainous areas.\n\nAircraft with 19 seats or fewer are more likely to have accidents due to these difficulties, according to a 2019 safety report from the Civil Aviation Authority.\n\nWhile the country has made improvements in safety standards in recent years, challenges remain, and a lack of investment in aging aircraft only adds to the risks of flying.\n\nLast year, Nepal saw its worst plane crash in more than 30 years when at least 68 people died when a Yeti Airlines flight went down near Pokhara.\n\nIn May 2022, a Tara Air flight departing from Pokhara crashed into a mountain, killing 22 people.\n\nIn early 2018, a US-Bangla Airlines flight from Bangladesh's capital Dhaka to Kathmandu crashed on landing and caught fire, killing 51 people.\n\nAnd in 2016, a Tara Air flight crashed while flying the same route as the 2023 crash.\n\nThis is a developing story and will be updated.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "8240862438", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:43:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:43:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:42:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://gulfnews.com/world/asia/video-saurya-airline-plane-crashes-in-nepal-with-18-dead-pilot-sole-survivor-1.1721802463000", "title": "Video: Saurya Airline plane crashes in Nepal with 18 dead, pilot sole survivor", "body": "Kathmandu: A passenger plane crashed on takeoff in Kathmandu on Wednesday, with the pilot rescued from the flaming wreckage but all 18 others aboard killed, police in the Nepali capital told AFP.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight was carrying two crew and 17 of the company's staff members, Nepali police spokesman Dan Bahadur Karki told AFP.\n\n\"The pilot has been rescued and is being treated,\" he added. \"Eighteen bodies have been recovered, including one foreigner. We are in the process of taking them for post-mortem.\"\n\nThe flight was being conducted for either technical or maintenance purposes, Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority told AFP without giving further details.\n\nBahadur and Bhul were unable to confirm the nationality of the sole foreigner aboard.\n\nImages of the aftermath shared by Nepal's military showed the plane's fuselage split apart and burnt to a husk.\n\nAround a dozen soldiers in camouflage were standing on top of the wreckage with the surrounding earth coated in fire retardant.\n\nThe plane crashed at around 11:15 am (0530 GMT), the military said in a statement, adding that the army's quick response team had been lending assistance with rescue efforts.\n\nNews portal Khabarhub reported that the airplane had caught fire after skidding on the runway.\n\nThe plane was scheduled to fly on Nepal's busiest air route between Kathmandu and Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\nPlagued by poor safety\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance - issues compounded by the mountainous republic's treacherous geography.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThat accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach to Kathmandu airport.\n\nEarlier that year a Thai Airways aircraft had crashed at around 11:15am (0530 GMT).\n\n\"Rescue work is going on\" with the army's quick response team lending assistance, the statement added.\n\nFurther details were \"still being confirmed\", Kathmandu airport general manager Jagannath Niroula told AFP.\n\nThe Kathmandu Post newspaper said 19 people including air crew were aboard the flight.\n\nAccording to Khabarhub, the airplane had comes after a commercial flight accident in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThe January incident was Nepal's deadliest since {"uri": "8240859383", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:41:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:41:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:40:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/world/story/kathmandu-airport-nepal-airports-aviation-accidents-crash-explained-why-terrain-pilots-landing-most-dangerous-lukla-terrain-2571122-2024-07-24", "title": "Why Nepal airports are tricky for pilots. No, it's not just the terrain", "body": "Over 40 international carriers use its only international airport served by a lone bumpy runway\n\nOn Wednesday morning, a passenger aircraft with 19 onboard crashed moments after taking off from Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport, killing 18 people. The pilot of the Nepal-based Saurya Airlines was the sole survivor. Videos showed the plane turning into a ball of fire.\n\nThe aircraft was bound for Pokhra, 150 kilometres east of the capital city of Kathmandu.\n\nWhile taking off from the southern end of the runway, the aircraft suddenly flipped with the wing tip hitting the ground, and immediately caught fire. The Bombardier regional jet then plunged into a gorge on the eastern side of the runway.\n\nThe plane crash comes a little more than a year of a major aviation accident in Nepal.\n\nIn January 2023, a turboprop aircraft stalled and crashed while landing at Pokhara. All 72 people on board died on impact.\n\nThe Himalayan kingdom saw 72 fatal air accidents between 1962 and January 2023, according a Nepali Times report. These crashes resulted in the loss of 935 lives.\n\nThe recent crash of a Saurya Airlines aircraft at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu is not an isolated event, as Nepal has a history of aviation accidents.\n\nNepal, otherwise known for its breathtaking Himalayan landscape, however has long been a challenging terrain for pilots.\n\nThe challenges of flying in Nepal are multifold.\n\nThe country's rugged terrain, with towering mountains and deep valleys, creates unique challenges for pilots.\n\nAnd it's not just the terrain, it is the weather conditions and the air that makes Nepal airports tricky for aviators.\n\nWeather conditions, too, can be highly unpredictable, with sudden changes in wind direction and speed, making it difficult for pilots to maintain control of their aircraft.\n\nAdditionally, given the high altitude and thin air, some aircraft engines might fail to provide the required lift.\n\nKathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport itself has seen hundreds of casualties from plane crashes either during landing or take-off.\n\nThe most fatal of them was the crash of a Thai Airways International aircraft in 1992, which crashed into a mountain while approaching Kathmandu, killing all 113 people on board.\n\nMonths later, another Pakistan International Airlines (PIA) aircraft crashed the same way, while approaching Kathmandu.\n\nIt's smack in the middle of the city, which isn't the best choice due to the surrounding mountains. However, this might be the only flat land available for such a facility. Despite this, the runway is over 3,000 metres long, which is adequate for most airliners.\n\nThe Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, although acts as a gateway to the Himalayan nation. Despite being the only operational international airport in Nepal, the Kathmandu airport terminal is not very big and is serviced by a lone bumpy runway.\n\nThe single runway struggles to keep up with the volume of traffic flying in and out.\n\nThe airport is known for long lines, inadequate facilities, and poor cleanliness, as highlighted in a survey by SleepinginAirports.net, a website for stranded airport travellers.\n\nThe airport also faces significant limitations due to its central location. It is right in the middle of the city in the Kathmandu Valley. Expansion and development of the infrastructure has been largely proved ineffective.\n\nFrom planes skidding off the runway to fog-related incidents, Kathmandu Airport has seen more than 20 major and minor plane mishaps, resulting in a toll of over 400.\n\nIf the Kathmandu Airport is dangerous, another airport in the higher reaches of the Himalayas is among the \"most dangerous airports in the world\".\n\nThe notorious Tenzing-Hillary Airport in Lukla is often referred to as the \"most dangerous airport in the world\", by a bunch of avgeeks, is located at an altitude of 2,860 metres.\n\nThe airport is the gateway to the Mount Everest base camp, and is known for its steep and short runway, and unpredictable weather conditions.\n\nThe table-top-slant runway at Lukla's Tenzing-Hillary Airport is in fact a bit longer than a standard soccer field. In tricky airports such as Lukla, the pilots require special training to operate there.\n\nNepal's aviation safety record has been a concern for flyers and regulators for years. So much so that the Nepal-based airlines came under the scanner of international regulators as well.\n\nIn December 2013, the European Commission imposed a blanket ban on all Nepali airlines from flying into the 28-nation bloc due to safety concerns. The ban still exists.\n\nBetween November 1960 and May 2022, a total of 106 aircraft crashed in Nepal, resulting in 590 deaths, according to the country's Civil Aviation Authority.\n\nMany of these accidents involved twin-engine planes, which are commonly used in Nepal to reach remote airstrips.\n\nThough it is more than the terrain that makes Nepal tricky for pilots, there is much that the Himalayan kingdom can do to make its aviation record better.", "source": {"uri": "indiatoday.in", "dataType": "news", "title": "India Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": The incident occurred as the aircraft, carrying 19 people, caught fire shortly after skidding off the runway. The dramatic event was captured on video and shared on social media, though the authenticity of the footage remains unverified. Other footage displayed rescue workers sifting through the burned wreckage scattered across green fields, with bodies being transported to ambulances on stretchers as local residents observed. Officials reported that the airport was temporarily closed.\n\nThe plane was transporting two crew members and 17 technicians to Pokhara for aircraft repairs. \"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" stated Tej Bahadur Poudyal, spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport. Television broadcasts depicted firefighters battling the blaze and thick smoke, along with visuals of the plane flying low and tilting before crashing.\n\nRescue workers were seen combing through the charred wreckage in green fields, with bodies being transported to ambulances on stretchers. Local residents watched the rescue operations unfold. The crashed aircraft was identified as a Bombardier, operated by Saurya Airlines, which has two Bombardier CRJ-200 jets in its fleet, both around 20 years old. A Saurya Airlines representative identified the plane as a 50-seater CRJ200. According to Flight Radar 24, Saurya operates two CRJ-200 regional jets, with one being inactive for an extended period.\n\nNepal's air safety record has faced criticism, with nearly 350 fatalities in aviation accidents since 2000. The deadliest crash occurred in 1992 when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus collided with a hillside, killing 167 people. the airplane had caught fire and was \"releasing a significant plume of smoke\".\n\nThe flight was en route to Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety {"uri": "8240920028", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:19:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:19:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:18:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.news18.com/explainers/with-at-least-68-plane-accidents-what-makes-nepal-prone-to-aviation-disasters-8976849.html", "title": "With At Least 68 Plane Accidents So Far, What Makes Nepal Prone To Aviation Disasters? - News18", "body": "The weather in the Himalayan region, corruption in the aviation sector, old aircraft have made Nepal prone to some deadly aviation disasters\n\nNearly 19 people died in a plane crash in Nepal on Wednesday morning, not a first in the Himalayan country. The Saurya Airlines plane crashed around 11.15 am after it skidded off the runway during take-off from the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu.\n\nThe airline pilot was the sole survivor in the crash, who was transported to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital for treatment. According to a doctor cited by Associated Press, the pilot sustained injuries to the eyes but is not in any danger.\n\nAccording to airport security, the airport was en route to Pokhara city carrying two crew members and 17 technicians for maintenance checks.\n\n\"The plane skidded off the runway and crashed into a field east of the runway,\" airport security chief Arjun Chand Thakuri said as quoted by Reuters.\n\nIn January 2023, a Yeti Airlines aircraft carrying 72 people, including four crew members, crashed a few kilometers away from Pokhara International Airport. Fifty-seven of those on board the aircraft were Nepalis and 15 were foreigners.\n\nIn May 2022, a Tara airplane crashed killing all 22 on board. In the last decade alone, there have been 20 crashes.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan airport, causing 51 fatalities while 20 survived. An investigation revealed that the plane was misaligned with the runway and the pilot was disoriented, attempting to land in \"sheer desperation\".\n\nIn 2015, a Turkish Airlines jet skidded off a slippery runway at the same airport while landing in dense fog. Although the plane was carrying 238 people, no serious injuries were reported.\n\nThe Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal (CAAN) has recorded at least 68 plane accidents in the country since 1955, about 44 of them deadly, including Yeti Airlines passenger plane crash.\n\nWeather\n\nThe weather changes quickly due to the mighty Himalayas, which makes it tricky for even the seasoned pilots to fly the plane. That is why Nepal's aviation largely depends on a limited type of aircraft such as Twin Otters, Let-L 410s and Dorniers.\n\nThese planes require shorter takeoff and landing (STOL) airfields in high-terrain areas, as opposed to the so-called trunk sector -- the region with better airports where bigger planes can fly.\n\nA senior pilot of national carrier Nepal Airlines said the \"high terrains are difficult and on top of that we lack good equipment and facilities\", a senior pilot of Nepal Airlines quoted Al Jazeera as saying.\n\nPoor Aircraft and Pilot Indiscipline\n\nAs per an article by The Diplomat, Nepali aircraft operators cannot afford to buy new aircraft, forcing many to opt for cheaper used aircraft. These flight operators have close links to influential political leaders who shield them from scrutiny, even when they flout the safety regulations. Some airports lack simple fencing, parking, and emergency vehicle standards, as per the report.\n\nThe report also mentioned the lack of discipline of the local pilots. Three Nepal Airlines Corporation (NAC) pilots were barred from flying after they disobeyed instructions from the air traffic control (ATC) specialists in Hong Kong. Two more pilots have been grounded for failure to adhere to ATC's instructions.\n\nAn investigation by Al Jazeera reported that most of the aircraft operating in Nepal are not brand new. They cost a lot and flying them may not be viable in an economically backward nation.\n\nBefore an aircraft is bought, a standard process of \"type certification\" is carried out by the civil aviation authorities such as the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA), Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) or any contracting state authority before it receives a certificate of airworthiness for operations.\n\nCorruption\n\nThe Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal (CAAN) is the service provider and regulator of the aviation sector in Nepal. Ironically, the Ministry of Culture, Tourism and Civil Aviation has not complied with about half the accident investigation recommendations directed to the ministry, as per a report by The Diplomat.\n\nThese risks have made it the European Union to impose a blanket ban on Nepali airlines flying in European airspace.\n\nTwo aviation-related bills calling for a split in CAAN's duties and a restructuring of the national aviation sector are pending before the Nepalese parliament since 2020.\n\nOnce they are separated, one part will be responsible for aviation regulatory issues such as safety and inspections while the service provider will venture towards managing infrastructure and airports.", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News18"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-07-431948553", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:32:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:32:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:07:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.lancasterguardian.co.uk/watch-this/plane-crash-18-killed-nepal-video-4714657", "title": "Video shows plane in flames with 18 killed and only pilot 'rescued alive' in crash", "body": "Video shows a plane in flames with black smoke billowing into the air as 18 people are killed in a crash during take-off.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines plane was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians to the city of Pokhara for maintenance checks, airport security chief Arjun Chand Thakuri said. Mr Thakuri also told local media the plane \"caught fire\" after it left the runway at Tribhuvan International Airport in the capital Kathmandu.\n\nThe airport has confirmed the incident at around 11am local time this morning (Wednesday 24 July). TV channels have shown the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting before it crashed. They also showed firefighters trying to put out the fire and thick black smoke rising into the sky.\n\nPolice official Basanta Rajauri said authorities have pulled out the bodies of all 18 people who died. \"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport. The bodies have been taken to the T.U. Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for autopsy.\n\nThe pilot was taken to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital with eye injuries but his condition is not life-threatening, said a doctor at the hospital who was not authorised to speak to media. It is not yet clear what caused the crash.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport has been closed and emergency crew were working at the scene. It is monsoon rainy season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. {"uri": "2024-07-431943535", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:29:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:29:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:32:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.lemonde.fr/en/asia-and-pacific/article/2024/07/24/nepal-plane-crash-18-killed-pilot-sole-survivor_6696582_153.html", "title": "Nepal plane crash: 18 killed, pilot sole survivor", "body": "A passenger plane crashed on take-off in Kathmandu on Wednesday, July 24, with the pilot rescued from the flaming wreckage but all 18 others aboard killed, police in the Nepali capital told Agence France-Presse (AFP). Nepal has a woeful track record on aviation safety and the Himalayan republic has seen a spate of deadly light plane and helicopter crashes over the decades.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight was carrying two crew and 17 of the company's staff members, Nepali police spokesman Dan Bahadur Karki told Agence France-Presse (AFP). \"The pilot has been rescued and is being treated,\" he added. \"Eighteen bodies have been recovered, including one foreigner. We are in the process of taking them for post-mortem.\" The Civil Aviation Authority said the dead foreigner was a Yemeni citizen.\n\nA press release from the airport said the aircraft \"veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway\" shortly after take-off. The survivor was in serious condition in hospital, it added. The flight was being conducted for either technical or maintenance purposes, Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority told AFP without giving further details.\n\nImages of the aftermath shared by Nepal's military showed the plane's fuselage split apart and burnt to a husk. Around a dozen soldiers in camouflage were standing on top of the wreckage with the surrounding earth coated in fire retardant.\n\nThe aircraft crashed at around 11:15 am (0530 GMT), the military said in a statement, adding that the army's quick response team had been lending assistance with rescue efforts. The plane was scheduled to fly on Nepal's busiest air route between Kathmandu and Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic. Saurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\nPlagued by poor safety\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers. But it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance -- issues compounded by the mountainous republic's treacherous geography.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns. The Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots. The weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard. That accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach to Kathmandu airport. Earlier that year a Thai Airways aircraft had crashed near the same airport, killing 113 people.", "source": {"uri": "lemonde.fr", "dataType": "news", "title": "Le Monde.fr"}, "authors": [{"uri": The committee will be led by former Director-General of the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal Ratish Chandra Lal Suman. It includes captain Deepu Jwarchan from Nepal Airlines, engineer Sanjay Adhikari from Shree Airlines, assistant professor Sudip Bhattarai from Pulchowk Engineering Campus, and technical officer Mukesh Dangol from the Ministry of Culture, Tourism and Civil Aviation,\" Gurung confirmed ANI.\n\nGurung, also the Minister for Communications and Information Technology, informed that the committee has been mandated to submit the report within 45 days.\n\nA total of 18 people died when a Saurya Airlines aircraft crashed at the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu on Wednesday. Nineteen people, including two crew members, were on the Pokhara-bound flight, with registration number 9NAME, which took off from Kathmandu at 11:11 am.\n\nNepal Police said Captain MR Shakya was rescued from the crash site and has been admitted to the KMC Hospital in Sinamangal for treatment. Most passengers were airline staff, travelling to Pokhara for aircraft maintenance.\n\nThe Tribhuvan International Airport stated that the flights crashed at a place on the east side of the runway.\n\n\"CRJ7 (Reg-9NAME) of Sourya Airlines took off from Kathmandu at 11:11 am local time during the flight to Pokhara, turned right, and crashed at the east side of the runway. It is reported that the fire was brought under control and the rescue work was started immediately,\" they said.\n\n\"The dead bodies of 18 people were recovered, and 1 injured person was rescued and taken to the hospital,\" the airport added.\n\nThe Pilot of the Saurya Airline plane that crashed at the Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA) in Kathmandu is the lone survivor of the crash.\n\nThe plane 9N-AME (CRJ 200) was only carrying technical staff of the airline, with no passengers on board. Gyanendra Bhul, information officer at TIA, confirmed that the plane was carrying a few technical staff members too. {"uri": "8241726899", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:51:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:51:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:50:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://howafrica.com/18-dead-in-nepal-plane-crash-pilot-sole-survivor/", "title": "18 Dead In Nepal Plane Crash, Pilot Sole Survivor | HowAfrica Latest news, views, gossip, photos and video", "body": "A passenger plane crashed on takeoff in Kathmandu on Wednesday, killing all 18 people on board, according to police in Nepal's capital.\n\nNepal has a poor track record in aviation safety, with a number of tragic light plane and helicopter crashes throughout the years.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight was carrying two crew members and 17 employees, Nepali police spokesman Dan Bahadur Karki said AFP.\n\n\"The pilot has been rescued and is being treated,\" she said. \"Eighteen bodies have been found, including one foreigner. We are in the process of transporting them for post-mortem.\"\n\nGyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority told AFP that the flight was for technical or maintenance purposes.\n\nBahadur and Bhul were unable to confirm the nationality of the only foreigner on board.\n\nThe Nepalese military published images of the aftermath, which showed the plane's fuselage torn apart and burned to a husk.\n\nAround a dozen soldiers in camouflage stood on top of the debris, with the surrounding ground doused in fire retardant.\n\nAccording to a military statement, the jet crashed around 11:15 a.m. (0530 GMT), and the army's quick response team was assisting with rescue efforts.\n\nKhabarhub said that the plane caught fire after skidding on the runway.\n\nThe jet was scheduled to fly between Kathmandu and Pokhara, Nepal's busiest air route and a major tourist destination.\n\nAccording to its website, Saurya Airlines exclusively operates Bombardier CRJ 200 planes.\n\nNepal's air industry has expanded in recent years, transporting goods and people between remote places, as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nHowever, limited training and upkeep have resulted in poor safety, which is exacerbated by the mountainous republic's dangerous topography.\n\nDue to safety concerns, the European Union has barred all Nepali carriers from its airspace.\n\nThe Himalayan country features some of the world's most difficult runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks and approaches that provide a challenge even for experienced pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the highlands, making flying hazardous.\n\nNepal's latest major commercial flight accident occurred in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed on landing in Pokhara, killing all 72 people on board.\n\nThat was Nepal's bloodiest accident since 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines plane crashed on its approach to Kathmandu airport, killing all 167 persons on board.\n\nEarlier that {"uri": "8240960953", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:43:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:43:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:42:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.news9live.com/world/high-mountains-inclement-weather-why-is-flying-so-dangerous-in-nepal-2629574", "title": "High mountains, inclement weather: Why is flying so dangerous in Nepal?", "body": "New Delhi: As many as 18 people were killed after a plane crashed during takeoff in Nepal's capital Kathmandu on Wednesday. The pilot of the private Nepalese domestic plane carrying 19 people survived the crash and was admitted to hospital with injuries. The Saurya Airlines plane bound for Pokhara, a popular tourist destination in the Himalayan republic, crashed at the Tribhuvan International Airport after it veered off the runway and burst into flames.\n\nNepal, which is home to several high mountain ranges, including Mount Everest, the world's highest peak, has recorded at least 69 plane accidents in the country since 1955, - 45 fatal ones - including today's crash of the Pokhara-bound plane, according to the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal (CAAN). These crashes claimed more than 900 lives. The last deadly commercial flight accident was reported in the country in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing in Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThe latest plane mishap has stoked debates around air travel safety in the Himalayan nation, hugely popular among foreign tourists, mountaineers and skiers. According to aviation experts, factors like mountainous terrain, weather condition, lack of investment in the aviation industry have possibly made the country prone to air disasters.\n\nNews9 details 4 possible factors that are behind frequent plane crashes in Nepal.\n\nChallenging mountainous terrain is one of the key reasons for the rampant incidents of plane crash in Nepal. Nepal is home to eight of the world's 14 highest mountains, including Mount Everest, Kanchenjunga and Annapurna. More than half of the country is surrounded by mountains and several airlines fly to small airports in remote hills shrouded in clouds and cut off from roads. The country's topography, with its mountain peaks and narrow valleys, raises the risk of accidents and sometimes requires pilots to fly by sight rather than relying on instruments.\n\nThe erratic weather of Nepal is one of the reasons for the plane tragedies. The country's \"diverse weather patterns\" were the major challenges, according to a 2019 safety report from Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority, also resulting in a \"number of accidents\" to small aircraft. The weather changes quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions. Most of the plane accidents reported in the country in the past were attributed to bad and cloudy weather. According to an aviation expert, most of the plane accidents happen in the country owing to the sudden change in the unpredictable weather in the high terrains between takeoff and landing.\n\nMost of the airports in Nepal, including its main Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu -- located in a narrow valley at an altitude of 4,390 feet -- have tricky topography, making it difficult for the pilots to turn and navigate in very tight space. Experts have long blamed airstrips located in rugged mountainous terrain as the reasons for the deadly air disasters in the country. The Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe Tenzing Hillary Airport also known as Lukla airport, is situated at an altitude of nearly 9,500 feet. It has a single runway. The Pokhara airport, where the Saurya Airlines plane was to land today, Pokhara, sits at an elevation of some 2,700 feet.\n\nLack of proper maintenance of equipment and aircraft training, and lax enforcement of regulations blight Nepal's aviation industry. Ageing aircraft are also one of the factors that raise the risk of plane crashes in Nepal. According to aviation experts, Nepal's air industry has a poor track record for safety due to insufficient training and maintenance.\n\nNotably, all Nepali carriers have been banned from flying into European airspace since December 2013. The European Union barred all Nepal airlines from operating in its airspace citing significant safety concerns. \"On the basis of safety information from various sources and a hearing both with the Nepalese aviation authorities as well as with a number of Nepalese carriers, the Commission decided to put all airlines from Nepal on the EU air safety list,\" the European Commission had stated in 2013.", "source": {"uri": "news9live.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News9live"}, "authors": [{"uri": "siddhi_gaharwar@news9live.com", "name": "Siddhi Gaharwar", "type": "author", "isAgency": {"uri": "8241015243", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:15:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:15:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:15:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.thaipbsworld.com/plane-crashes-in-nepal-with-18-dead-pilot-sole-survivor/", "title": "Plane crashes in Nepal with 18 dead, pilot sole survivor - Thai PBS World", "body": "Nepal has a woeful track record on aviation safety and the Himalayan republic has seen a spate of deadly light plane and helicopter crashes over the decades.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight was carrying two crew and 17 of the company's staff members, Nepali police spokesman Dan Bahadur Karki told AFP.\n\n\"The pilot has been rescued and is being treated,\" he added. \"Eighteen bodies have been recovered, including one foreigner. We are in the process of taking them for post-mortem.\"\n\nThe Civil Aviation Authority said the dead foreigner was a Yemeni citizen.\n\nA press release from the airport said the aircraft \"veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway\" shortly after take-off.\n\nThe survivor was in serious condition in hospital, it added.\n\nRam Kumar K.C., who runs a tyre store near the accident site, told AFP the plane caught fire after hitting the ground.\n\n\"We were about to run to the site but then there was an explosion so we ran away again,\" the 48-year-old said.\n\nThe flight was being conducted for either technical or maintenance purposes, Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority told AFP without giving further details.\n\nImages of the aftermath shared by Nepal's military showed the plane's fuselage split apart and burnt to a husk.\n\nAround a dozen soldiers in camouflage were standing on top of the wreckage with the surrounding earth coated in fire retardant.\n\nThe aircraft crashed at around 11:15 am (0530 GMT), the military said in a statement, adding that the army's quick response team had been lending assistance with rescue efforts.\n\nThe plane was scheduled to fly on Nepal's busiest air route between Kathmandu and Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance -- issues compounded by the mountainous republic's treacherous geography.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines in Nepal's capital Kathmandu on Wednesday morning, with fire crew working to douse the flaming wreckage.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines plane crashed at around 11:15 am (0530 GMT), Nepal's military said in a statement.\n\n\"Rescue work is going on\" with the army's quick response team lending assistance, the statement added.\n\nFurther details were \"still being confirmed\", Kathmandu airport general manager Jagannath Niroula told AFP.\n\nThe Kathmandu Post newspaper said 19 people including air crew were aboard the flight.\n\nNews portal Khabarhub reported that the airplane had caught fire after skidding on the runway and was \"releasing a significant plume of smoke\".\n\nThe plane was en route to Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nNepal's woeful record on aviation safety has been compounded by its treacherous geography.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThat accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach The incident occurred around 11:00 AM local time. The flight, which was bound for Pokhara, had 19 people on board, including aircrew. According to PTI, \"at least 18 people were killed\" in the accident. Nepal Plane Crash: What we know about the crash\n\nThe aircraft, a Mitsubishi CRJ-200ER, caught fire upon impact, with Khabarhub reporting that the plane was \"releasing a significant plume of smoke.\" Emergency responders quickly extinguished the blaze. Rescue operations are ongoing, conducted by police and firefighters. The pilot was taken to a nearby hospital, though there are no further details on their condition, as noted by a security official deployed at the airport.\n\nPolice and firefighters are actively engaged in rescue efforts. The pilot was transported to a nearby hospital, but no further details about their condition have been provided. According to PTI, \"The plane caught fire upon impact, but the blaze was quickly extinguished by emergency responders.\"\n\nThe Kathmandu Post reported that the crash was caused by a runway excursion during takeoff. TIA Spokesperson Subash Jha confirmed this information, stating, \"The accident occurred after the Pokhara-bound flight suffered a runway excursion during takeoff.\"\n\nNepal Plane Crash: Challenges of Tribhuvan International Airport\n\nTribhuvan International Airport is known for its challenging geography. Located on a plateau surrounded by deep gorges and valleys, it is considered one of the riskiest airports globally. The difficult terrain and unpredictable weather conditions add to the complexity of flying in and out of Kathmandu.\n\nNepal Plane Crash: Background on Nepal's Aviation Safety\n\nNepal's aviation industry has faced ongoing safety challenges. The European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace due to safety concerns. The country's treacherous geography and rapid weather changes further complicate aviation safety.Nepal has a troubling record of aviation accidents. In January 2023, a Yeti Airlines flight crashed near Pokhara, killing all 72 people on board. In May 2022, a Tara Air plane crashed in Mustang, resulting in 22 fatalities. All those on board - 18 Nepalis and a Yemeni citizen - were employees of the carrier, according to police.\n\nImages from Nepal police showed thick smoke billowing from the burning aircraft on the the airport runway.\n\nThe aircraft crashed during takeoff from Kathmandu to the city of Pokhara around 11 a.m. local time, Bhul said. The plane was en route for technical maintenance, he added.\n\n\"Rescue efforts were started immediately and the situation was brought under control,\" the aviation authority said.\n\nThe crash once again highlights the dangers of air travel in Nepal, a country often referred to as one of the riskiest places to fly due to multiple factors including its mountainous terrain.\n\nThe Himalayan country, home to eight of the world's 14 highest mountains including Everest, has a record of air accidents. Its weather can change suddenly, and airstrips are typically sited in difficult-to-reach, mountainous areas.\n\nAircraft with 19 seats or fewer are more likely to have accidents due to these difficulties, according to a 2019 safety report from the Civil Aviation Authority.\n\nWhile the country has made improvements in safety standards in recent years, challenges remain, and a lack of investment in aging aircraft only adds to the risks of flying.\n\nIn early 2018, a US-Bangla Airlines flight from Bangladesh's capital Dhaka to Kathmandu crashed on landing and caught fire, killing 51 {"uri": "8241247710", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "12:36:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T12:36:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T12:34:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/24/18-people-killed-in-plane-crash-in-nepal/", "title": "18 People Killed in Plane Crash in Nepal", "body": "A small plane crashed while taking off from an airport in Kathmandu, Nepal, on Wednesday, killing 18 people on board, officials said.\n\nThe pilot of the Saurya Airlines flight was the only survivor and was seriously injured, the authorities said. The plane took off at 11:11 a.m. from Tribhuvan International Airport and was headed toward Pokhara, Nepal's second biggest city and a Himalayan tourist destination, the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nThe plane then veered to the right before crashing on the east side of the runway and catching fire, the statement said. Officials said that the cause was not immediately clear and that there would be an investigation.\n\nAmong the dead were the plane's co-pilot and one child, the aviation authority said. One passenger was from Yemen, while the others were Nepalese. Photos of the crash site from local media showed the charred wreckage of the plane scattered in pieces.\n\nNepal's aviation sector has a poor safety record, with a string of crashes in recent years killing dozens. Tough, mountainous topography and unpredictable weather conditions are responsible in part for the country's frequent plane crashes, according to experts.\n\nSome experts also say the government has failed to properly regulate the industry. The Nepalese government is responsible for both regulating aircrafts and operating airports, which critics say presents a conflict of interest.\n\nIn January last year, a Yeti Airlines flight crashed in Pokhara while attempting to land at a newly built airport, killing all 72 people on board. Investigators later said the crash was caused by the pilot pulling the wrong levers while trying to land, changing the propeller angle instead of that of the wing flaps.\n\nIn May 2022, another aircraft belonging to Tara Air, a subsidiary of Yeti Airlines, crashed in a mountainous region while flying from Pokhara to Jomsom, a village high in the Himalayas, killing all 22 passengers on board. The flight, operated by Saurya Airlines, was en route to Pokhara when the plane \"skidded off the runway\" in the eastern section of the airport.\n\nThe plane was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians to Pokhara city in the Himalayas for maintenance checks. Authorities have recovered the bodies of all 18 victims.\n\nFootage showed firefighters battling the flames as thick black smoke rises into the sky, engulfing the airport while rescue operations continued. The cause of the crash remains unclear, though visibility was low due to monsoon conditions.\n\nTej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport, told the Evening Standard:\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital.\"\n\nSince 1955, the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal (CAAN) has reported 68 plane accidents, with 44 being fatal.\n\nIt was a Bombardier CRJ 200 jet which crashed and burned during take-off in Kathmandu. It follows the deadly January 2023 crash of a Yeti Airlines plane in Pokhara, which killed 72 passengers. Nepal's treacherous terrain, including the narrow valley and tabletop runway of Tribhuvan International Airport, contributes to these frequent disasters.\n\nOver the past three decades, Nepal has seen 27 deadly plane crashes, killing more than 600 people. Notably, in 1992, a Pakistan International Airlines crash near Kathmandu killed a shocking 167 people. All Nepali airports, including Tribhuvan International in Kathmandu and the newly opened Pokhara airport, possess a challenging landscape which makes navigating difficult.\n\nIn 2019, a Bangladeshi airliner crashed at Tribhuvan Airport, killing 51 people. In this instance, investigators did confirm that it was a misalignment with the runway as the disoriented pilot desperately tried to land before crashing. The Pokhara airport is set against the Annapurna Mountain range. This adds to the risk in Nepal's dangerous aviation environment.\n\nNepal relies on small aircraft like Twin Otters and Dorniers for their short runways and high altitudes. Plus, the mountainous environment and low air density proves a challenge for aircraft performance. This makes landing and take-off extremely risky.\n\nThe pilots face limited manoeuvring space and often rely on visual flight rules (VFR), which are difficult to follow in changing weather. For instance, in 2018, 51 out of 71 passengers died in a Bangladeshi airliner crash due to cloudy weather. But that cannot be the only blame as the country's aging fleet lacks modern technology and sees operators even ignoring safety regulations.\n\nNepal's aviation safety reputation suffers from several issues. The country deals with outdated infrastructure, including old aircrafts and subpar airports. Not to mentions the challenging mountainous terrain and unpredictable weather which may create a hazardous environment for pilots. But this would be less severe with the correct pilot training, something Nepali airlines lacks. Evidently, there is a shortage of experienced pilots which leaves Nepal with less skilled crews.\n\nMoreover, limited investment in modern technology and regulatory oversight exacerbates these problems. This could be due to economic constraints impeding effective enforcement of safety protocols. Therefore, Nepal's aviation sector still faces major safety challenges.\n\nHarsh Vardhan, a Delhi-based aviation expert, has stated the link between Nepal's deadly air disasters to privatisation in 1992 and inadequate infrastructure. He claims that safety was relatively good before privatisation, but the rapid growth outpaced regulatory organisation. He said that:\n\nThe moment you have pilots who gain some experience on their craft and the machines, they immediately get picked up by bigger airlines ... so these aircraft or operations have become virtually a training ground for them. In terrain like Nepal, pilots require longer experience\" to cope with the demands of the weather and associated events\n\nAs Nepal relies on a struggling aviation sector, improving safety standards and investing in infrastructure must be a top priority to prevent future disasters.\n\nConsequently, it is believed that the ongoing issues with Nepal's aviation safety is potentially one of the causes of the crash on the 24 July 2024.\n\nThe lack of modern technology and experienced pilots remains critical. {"uri": "8240780097", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "07:50:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T07:50:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T07:49:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://newsable.asianetnews.com/world/saurya-airlines-aircraft-crashes-in-kathmandu-revisiting-history-of-fatal-plane-crashes-in-nepal-gcw-sh4aqy", "title": "Saurya Airlines aircraft crashes in Kathmandu: Revisiting history of fatal plane crashes in Nepal", "body": "Nepal has a long history of plane crashes. The rugged mountainous terrain, unpredictable weather, dearth of investment in new planes and infrastructure and poor regulation have contributed to these unfortunate incidents. A Saurya Airlines aircraft crashed during takeoff at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu on Wednesday. According to Nepal Police, at least 15 people have died while four others were rescued. The Pokhara-bound plane, carrying nineteen people including the aircrew, slipped off the runway and crashed at around 11 am.\n\nLet's take a look at the history of plane crashes:\n\nJanuary 2023: At least 68 people died after an ATR 72 aircraft belonging to Yeti Airlines carrying 72 people crashed in Nepal's Pokhara at 11 am on January 15. The plane, carrying 68 passengers and four crew members, crashed a few miles from Pokhara, just 20 minutes after it took off from Kathmandu, according to early reports.\n\nMay 2022: On May 29, Sunday, a Tara aircraft carrying 22 people -- including four Indians from Thane -- crashed in Nepal's rugged Mustang province. All of the passengers' bodies were found on Tuesday, three days later. In their investigative report, the Nepali authorities found that the tragedy could have been caused by the terrible weather.\n\nFebruary 2019: In gloomy weather in February 2019, an Air Dynasty chopper attempted to make its way back into Kathmandu and collided with a hill. Rabindra Adhikari, the minister of tourism for Nepal, was one of the seven victims of the accident. According to the investigation's preliminary assessment, there were operational procedure infractions, including weight imbalances brought on by the fuel tank's location and improper passenger seating arrangements.\n\nMarch 2018: On March 12, 2018, a US-Bangla plane carrying 67 passengers and 4 crew members crashed at Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International airport, resulting in the deaths of 49 people. The aircraft returning from Dhaka burst into flames after it skidded off the runway upon landing, landed on a football pitch close to the airport, and burst into flames. A panel tasked with investigating the incident determined that the pilot's bewilderment was possibly the accident's most likely cause.\n\nFebruary 2016: An Air Kashthamandap plane carrying eleven passengers crashed in Nepal's Kalikot area. Nine passengers were hurt in the event, while two crew members died.\n\nMay 2015: All eight people on board a US Marine Corps squadron perished in the accident in the country's Charikot area. While en route to provide relief to victims of two earthquakes, the UH-1Y Huey carrying two Nepali troops and six US marines vanished from sight.\n\nMay 2012: A Dornier jet carrying twenty-one passengers crashed into a mountaintop in northern Nepal while trying to land at a high-altitude airstrip, killing fifteen people, including thirteen Indian pilgrims. The plane was travelling from Jomsom Airport to Pokhara Airport.\n\nSeptember 2011: A Buddha Air Beechcraft 1900D transporting passengers on a sightseeing flight over Mount Everest struck a hill. All 19 passengers, including 10 Indians, perished on board. The disaster was caused by unfavourable weather circumstances since heavy monsoon clouds were engulfing the Kathmandu airport and the surrounding region at the time of the crash.\n\nSeptember 2006: All 24 passengers and crew members were killed when a Shree Air helicopter crashed during a chartered flight in Eastern Nepal. A World Wide Fund for Nature expedition was returning by helicopter from a conservation event.\n\nJune 2006: A Yeti aircraft with six passengers including crew members crashed on the ground.", The committee will be led by former Director-General of the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal Ratish Chandra Lal Suman. It includes captain Deepu Jwarchan from Nepal Airlines, engineer Sanjay Adhikari from Shree Airlines, assistant professor Sudip Bhattarai from Pulchowk Engineering Campus, and technical officer Mukesh Dangol from the Ministry of Culture, Tourism and Civil Aviation,\" Gurung confirmed ANI.\n\nGurung, also the Minister for Communications and Information Technology, informed that the committee has been mandated to submit the report within 45 days.\n\nA total of 18 people died when a Saurya Airlines aircraft crashed at the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu on Wednesday. Nineteen people, including two crew members, were on the Pokhara-bound flight, with registration number 9NAME, which took off from Kathmandu at 11:11 am.\n\nNepal Police said Captain MR Shakya was rescued from the crash site and has been admitted to the KMC Hospital in Sinamangal for treatment. Most passengers were airline staff, travelling to Pokhara for aircraft maintenance.\n\nThe Tribhuvan International Airport stated that the flights crashed at a place on the east side of the runway.\n\n\"CRJ7 (Reg-9NAME) of Sourya Airlines took off from Kathmandu at 11:11 am local time during the flight to Pokhara, turned right, and crashed at the east side of the runway. It is reported that the fire was brought under control and the rescue work was started immediately,\" they said.\n\n\"The dead bodies of 18 people were recovered, and 1 injured person was rescued and taken to the hospital,\" the airport added.\n\nThe Pilot of the Saurya Airline plane that crashed at the Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA) in Kathmandu is the lone survivor of the crash.\n\nThe plane 9N-AME (CRJ 200) was only carrying technical staff of the airline, with no passengers on board.
