Here is a list of some of the deadliest aircraft mishaps and incidents in Nepal in recent years:\n\nJuly 24, 2024: At least 18 people were killed when a Bombardier CRJ 200 plane operated by Nepal's Saurya Airlines crashed and caught fire while taking off from the airport in the capital city of Kathmandu. Only the pilot of the ill-fated passenger aircraft, which was carrying 19 people, including the cabin crew, survived the crash.\n\nJuly 11, 2023: A helicopter crashed in central Nepal, killing all six people onboard. The chopper had taken off from the country's Solukhunvhu district, home to Mount Everest and other high mountain peaks. The fatalities included five Mexican nationals and one Nepali pilot.\n\nJanuary 15, 2023: A twin-engine ATR 72 aircraft belonging to Nepal's Yeti Airlines crashed in Pokhara, killing all 72 people onboard. It was the worst air crash in the country since 1992 when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane were killed when it ploughed into a hill as it tried to land in Kathmandu.\n\nMay 29, 2022: Sixteen Nepalis, four Indians and two Germans died on a De Havilland Canada DHC-6-300 Twin Otter aircraft that crashed 15 minutes after taking off from Pokhara, 125 km west of Kathmandu.\n\nFebruary 27, 2019: A helicopter crashed in bad weather in eastern Nepal, killing all seven people on board, including the country's then-tourism minister, Rabindra Prasad Adhikari.\n\nMarch 12, 2018: Out of 71 people onboard a flight operated by Bangladesh-based US-Bangla Airlines, 51 died when the aircraft crashed in cloudy weather while approaching the landing strip {"uri": "8241451077", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:43:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:43:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:39:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-18-killed-as-plane-crashes-after-takeoff-at-nepals-kathmandu-airport-pilot-survives-6134756.html", "title": "World News | 18 Killed as Plane Crashes After Takeoff at Nepal's Kathmandu Airport, Pilot Survives | LatestLY", "body": "Kathmandu, Jul 24 (PTI) A Nepalese airliner crashed and caught fire shortly after taking off from the Tribhuvan International Airport here on Wednesday, killing 18 people aboard, including a child, and seriously injuring the pilot - the lone survivor, in the latest aviation disaster to hit the Himalayan nation.\n\nThe Bombardier CRJ-200 aircraft of Saurya Airlines, carrying 19 people, including two crew members and technical staff of the airline, was bound for Pokhara International Airport for regular maintenance service when the accident occurred at 11.11 am (local time).\n\nAlso Read | US Shocker: Woman Jumps to Death out of Moving Car in Arizona During Police Chase After Boyfriend Allegedly Takes 20 Fentanyl Pills and Drives Vehicle up Mount Lemmon.\n\n\"Shortly after takeoff from runway 02, the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" said a statement issued by the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal.\n\nIt said rescue operations were initiated immediately and fire was brought under control.\n\nAlso Read | Indian Navy Successfully Evacuates Critically Injured Chinese Mariner From Bulk Carrier Zhong Shan Men off Mumbai Coast (See Pics and Video).\n\n\"One injured person (Captain Manish Ratna Shakya) was rescued and taken to the hospital, and 18 People were found dead,\" it added.\n\nThe deceased were identified as co-pilot S Katuwal, the employees of Saurya Airlines and a Yemeni national (Aref Reda).\n\nManu Raj Sharma, a technician of the airline, his wife Priza Khatiwada and their four-year-old son Adhi Raj Sharma, were among the deceased.\n\nPriza worked as an assistant computer operator at the Ministry of Energy, Water Resources, and Irrigation.\n\nA statement issued by the airline said that Priza and her son were initially identified as employees of the company, but it was later revealed that they were passengers.\n\nVideos posted online showed the plane being enveloped in fire and smoke. Fire engines and ambulances were rushed to the spot after the incident.\n\nOf the deceased, 15 died on the spot while three died during treatment at a local hospital, authorities said.\n\nThe bodies of the deceased have been shifted to Tribhuvan University Teaching Hospital for post-mortem. The relatives of the victims are gathered outside the hospital, mourning their loss.\n\nPilot Captain Shakya, the 37-year-old who is the lone survivor in the crash, is undergoing treatment at Kathmandu Model Hospital.\n\nOfficials at the Kathmandu Medical Hospital (KMC) said that Captain Shakya remains in critical condition following injuries sustained in the accident.\n\nCaptain Shakya is currently undergoing a crucial eye and spinal cord surgery and is admitted to the Neuro-Intensive Care Unit (ICU), as reported by the KMC Hospital.\n\nPrime Minister KP Sharma Oli and Home Minister Ramesh Lekh separately visited the accident site to gather details about the incident and provide necessary directives.\n\nOli said he was deeply saddened by the tragic deaths in the crash and was at the site to inquire about the cause of the air crash with the Civil Aviation Authority's officials. He urged all for patience at this hour of grief.\n\nAccording to Tribhuvan International Airport chief Jagannath Niraula, the plane flying from Kathmandu to Pokhara turned in the wrong direction.\n\n\"As soon as it took off, it turned right instead of turning left,\" Niraula was quoted as saying by the BBC News Nepali.\n\nHowever, \"the cause of the accident has not been revealed yet,\" he said.\n\nThe accident happened less than a minute after the plane took off, Niraula said.\n\nA Cabinet meeting held in Singhadurbar decided to form a five-member committee led by former director-general of the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal Ratish Chandra Lal Suman to investigate the crash.\n\nThe committee includes Captain Deepu Jwarchan from Nepal Airlines, engineer Sanjay Adhikari from Shree Airlines, assistant professor Sudip Bhattarai from Pulchowk Engineering Campus, and technical officer Mukesh Dangol from the Ministry of Culture, Tourism and Civil Aviation.\n\nThe committee has been given 45 days to submit a report.\n\nThe aircraft, manufactured by the Canadian company Bombardier in April 2003, was the sixth of its kind purchased for use in Nepal, according to information from planesspotters.com.\n\nFollowing the accident, services at the Kathmandu airport were halted briefly before being resumed, the airport authorities said.\n\nAccording to the company's website, Saruya Airlines operates flights to five tourist destinations within Nepal, with a fleet of three Bombardier CRJ-200 jets.\n\nNepal has been criticised for its poor air safety record in recent years but the reasons also include partly sudden weather changes and partly airstrips located in hard-to-access rocky terrains apart from human error.\n\nAccording to Nepal's civil aviation body, 914 people have died in air crashes in the country since the first disaster was recorded in August 1955.\n\nIn January last year, all 72 people on board, including five Indians, were killed when a Yeti Airlines aircraft crashed in the resort city of Pokhara. The crash was attributed to a human error.\n\nYeti Airlines' 9N-ANC ATR-72 aircraft crashed on the bank of the Seti River between the old airport and the new airport minutes before landing on January 15, 2023, which was the 104th crash in Nepali skies and the third biggest in terms of casualties.\n\nThe only incidents in which more people were killed took place in July and September 1992. Those crashes involved aircraft of Thai Airways and Pakistan International Airlines and left 113 and 167 people dead, respectively.\n\nOn May 29, 2022, all 22 people on board, including four members of an Indian family, were killed as a Tara Air plane crashed in Nepal's mountainous Mustang district. In 2016, all 23 people aboard were killed when a plane of the same airline flying the same route crashed after takeoff.\n\nIn March 2018, a US-Bangla Air crash occurred at the Tribhuvan International Airport, killing 51 people on board.", "source": {"uri": "latestly.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "LatestLY"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shakya", "type": {"uri": "8241037584", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:30:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:30:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:28:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://www.ibtimes.com/plane-crashes-nepal-18-dead-pilot-sole-survivor-3737877", "title": "Plane Crashes In Nepal With 18 Dead, Pilot Sole Survivor", "body": "A passenger plane crashed on take-off in Kathmandu on Wednesday, with the pilot rescued from the flaming wreckage but all 18 others aboard killed, police in the Nepali capital told AFP.\n\nNepal has a woeful track record on aviation safety and the Himalayan republic has seen a spate of deadly light plane and helicopter crashes over the decades.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight was carrying two crew and 17 of the company's staff members, Nepali police spokesman Dan Bahadur Karki told AFP.\n\n\"The pilot has been rescued and is being treated,\" he added. \"Eighteen bodies have been recovered, including one foreigner. We are in the process of taking them for post-mortem.\"\n\nThe Civil Aviation Authority said the dead foreigner was a Yemeni citizen.\n\nA press release from the airport said the aircraft \"veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway\" shortly after take-off.\n\nThe survivor was in serious condition in hospital, it added.\n\nRam Kumar K.C., who runs a tyre store near the accident site, told AFP the plane caught fire after hitting the ground.\n\n\"We were about to run to the site but then there was an explosion so we ran away again,\" the 48-year-old said.\n\nThe flight was being conducted for either technical or maintenance purposes, Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority told AFP without giving further details.\n\nImages of the aftermath shared by Nepal's military showed the plane's fuselage split apart and burnt to a husk.\n\nAround a dozen soldiers in camouflage were standing on top of the wreckage with the surrounding earth coated in fire retardant.\n\nThe aircraft crashed at around 11:15 am (0530 GMT), the military said in a statement, adding that the army's quick response team had been lending assistance with rescue efforts.\n\nThe plane was scheduled to fly on Nepal's busiest air route between Kathmandu and Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance -- issues compounded by the mountainous republic's treacherous geography.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nEarlier that year a Thai Airways aircraft had crashed near the same airport, killing 113 people.", "source": {"uri": "ibtimes.com", We are in the process of taking them for post-mortem.\"\n\nThe flight was being conducted for either technical or maintenance purposes, Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority told AFP without giving further details.\n\nBahadur and Bhul were unable to confirm the nationality of the sole foreigner aboard.\n\nImages of the aftermath shared by Nepal's military showed the plane's fuselage split apart and burnt to a husk.\n\nAround a dozen soldiers in camouflage were standing on top of the wreckage with the surrounding earth coated in fire retardant.\n\nThe plane crashed at around 11:15 am , the military said in a statement, adding that the army's quick response team had been lending assistance with rescue efforts.\n\nNews portal Khabarhub reported that the airplane had caught fire after skidding on the runway.\n\nThe plane was scheduled to fly on Nepal's busiest air route between Kathmandu and Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers.\n\nBut it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance issues compounded by the mountainous republic's treacherous geography.\n\nThe European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThat accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane died when it crashed on approach to Kathmandu airport.\n\nEarlier that year a Thai Airways aircraft had crashed near the same airport, killing 113 people.", {"uri": "8241766558", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:21:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:21:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:19:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://thewhistler.ng/plane-crash-at-nepal-airport-kills-18/", "title": "Plane Crash At Nepal Airport Kills 18", "body": "Tragedy struck at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal today when a small passenger plane belonging to Saurya Airlines crashed and caught fire during takeoff, killing 18 people on board.\n\nThe captain, identified as Manish Shakya, is the sole survivor and is receiving treatment for eye injuries at a local hospital, the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\n\"On 24 July 2024 (2081/04/09), Wednesday, Saurya Airlines Aircraft (CRJ200, Registration 9N-AME) took off from Tribhuvan International Airport (VNKT) at 11:11 Nepali Standard Time (NST) to Pokhara International Airport (VNPR).\n\n\"Shortly after takeoff from runway 02, the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway. Rescue operations were initiated immediately.\n\n\"The fire was brought under control, one injured person (Captain Manish Ratna Shakya) was rescued and taken to the hospital, and 18 People were found dead,\" the statement from the Rescue Coordination Centre read.\n\nFootage shows firefighters battling the blaze and rescue workers examining the charred remains of the 50-seater Bombardier CRJ-200 aircraft.\n\nThe victims include 17 Nepali citizens and one Yemeni national. The cause of the crash is yet to be determined, but an investigation is underway. An emergency cabinet meeting has been called to form a panel to probe the incident.\n\nThis latest tragedy highlights Nepal's poor air safety record, with nearly 360 people dying in plane or helicopter crashes in the country since 2000. The airport was temporarily closed following the crash but has since reopened.", "source": {"uri": "thewhistler.ng", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Whistler Nigeria"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8241035438", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:28:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:28:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:27:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/19-plane-crashes-360-dead-since-2000-a-timeline-of-air-mishaps-in-nepal-13796514.html", "title": "19 plane crashes, 360 dead since 2000: A timeline of air mishaps in Nepal", "body": "Nepal army personnel cordon off a plane crash site at Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal. AP\n\nMountainous Nepal, where a small plane carrying 19 passengers caught fire during takeoff in the capital on Wednesday, has a sorry history of deadly air crashes.\n\nBefore Wednesday's crash, nearly 360 people had been killed in the country in 19 air crashes since 2000.\n\nHere are details of plane and helicopter crashes this century in the Himalayan country, where several airlines fly to small airports in remote hills and mountains shrouded in clouds and cut off from roads.\n\nJuly 24, 2024\n\nAt least 18 people were killed when a Bombardier CRJ 200 plane crashed and caught fire while it was taking off from Nepal's capital Kathmandu.\n\nJuly 11, 2023\n\nSix people were killed in a helicopter crash in central Nepal. The chopper, which departed from Solukhunvhu district, home to Mount Everest and other high mountain peaks, had five Mexican nationals and one Nepali pilot on board.\n\nJan 15, 2023\n\nA twin-engine ATR 72 aircraft carrying 72 people, operated by Nepal's Yeti Airlines, crashed in Pokhara, killing all on board.\n\nIt was the worst air crash in the country since 1992 when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane were killed when it ploughed into a hill as it tried to land in Kathmandu.\n\nMay 29, 2022\n\nSixteen Nepalis, four Indians and two Germans died on a De Havilland Canada DHC-6-300 Twin Otter aircraft that crashed 15 minutes after taking off from Pokhara, 125 km (80 miles) west of Kathmandu.\n\nFeb 27, 2019\n\nA helicopter crashed in bad weather in eastern Nepal, killing all seven people on board, including the tourism minister.\n\nMarch 12, 2018\n\nFifty-one of 71 people on a Bangladeshi airliner operated by US-Bangla Airlines died when it crashed in cloudy weather as it came in to land at the Nepalese capital's hill-ringed airport.\n\nFeb 26, 2016\n\nTwo people were feared dead after a small plane crashed in western Nepal's Kalikot district. It was operated by Kasthamandap Airlines.\n\nFeb 24, 2016\n\nA small plane crashed in bad weather, killing all 23 people on board. The Twin Otter aircraft, operated by Tara Air, was on a flight from Pokhara to Jomsom in western Nepal.\n\nFeb 16, 2014\n\nAll 18 people on a small plane that crashed in bad weather were killed. The Twin Otter aircraft was operated by state-run Nepal Airlines Corp.\n\nSept 28, 2012\n\nA small propeller-driven Dornier aircraft struck a bird and crashed shortly after takeoff from Kathmandu, killing 19 people, including seven British and five Chinese passengers.\n\nSept 25, 2011\n\nA small plane carrying foreign tourists to view Mount Everest crashed in bad weather near Kathmandu, killing all 19 people on board.\n\nThe Beech aircraft was operated by private airline Buddha Air.\n\nDec 16, 2010\n\nA small plane crashed in the Himalayan foothills of remote east Nepal, killing all 22 people onboard. The Twin Otter aircraft was operated by Tara Air.\n\nAug 24, 2010\n\nFourteen people - including four Americans, a Japanese and British national - were killed when their small plane crashed in bad weather in Nepal. It was operated by privately held Agni Air.\n\nOct 8, 2008\n\nA small Twin Otter plane crashed in the remote mountains of northeast Nepal, killing at least 18 people, mostly foreigners.\n\nMarch 4, 2008\n\nFour U.N. arms monitors were among at least 10 people killed in a helicopter crash in Nepal.\n\nJune 21, 2006\n\nA Twin Otter passenger plane operated by Yeti Airlines crashed minutes before landing in the west of the country, killing all nine people on board.\n\nMay 25, 2004\n\nA Twin Otter cargo plane crashed in the Mount Everest region, killing its three crew. It was operated by Yeti Airlines.\n\nAug 22, 2002\n\nAnother Twin Otter plane, carrying foreign tourists, slammed into a mountain in bad weather in Nepal, killing all 18 people on board. It was operated by Shangrila Air.\n\nJuly 17, 2002\n\nFour people were feared dead after a twin-engined aircraft crashed into a mountain in west Nepal minutes before it was due to land.\n\nJuly 27, 2000\n\nA Canadian-built Twin Otter passenger plane crashed in western Nepal, killing all 25 people on board. {"uri": "8240858385", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:41:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:41:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:39:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://statetimes.in/18-killed-as-plane-crashes-during-takeoff-at-kathmandu-airport/", "title": "18 killed as plane crashes during takeoff at Kathmandu airport", "body": "KATHMANDU: A private Nepalese domestic plane bound for Pokhara crashed during takeoff at the Tribhuvan International Airport here on Wednesday, killing 18 technical staff and injuring the pilot of the aircraft carrying 19 people.\n\nThe pilot of the Saurya Airlines plane survived the crash and was taken to hospital, officials said. The crash took place around 11 am when the aircraft veered off the runway and burst into flames.\n\nFootage from the spot showed dramatic scenes of the plane speeding down the runway before a fire breaks out with high flames and thick black smoke billowing from the wreckage.\n\nThe Bombardier CRJ200 aircraft was only carrying technical staff of the airline, The Himalayan Times newspaper reported.\n\n\"There were no passengers on board but the plane was carrying few technical staff,\" Gyanendra Bhul, information officer at the TIA, said.\n\nThe Kathmandu Post newspaper reported that 18 bodies have been recovered from the crash site.\n\n\"The accident occurred after the Pokhara-bound flight suffered a runway excursion during takeoff,\" said TIA Spokesperson Subash Jha.\n\nThe pilot of the aircraft has been taken to a hospital, a security official deployed at the airport told PTI without giving further details.\n\nA fire that broke out from the aircraft has been put off, he added. Police and firefighters are carrying out rescue operations at the accident site. Authorities have shut down the TIA following the plane crash, the MyRepublica news portal reported. Dozens of international and domestic flights have been affected due to the airport closure. {"uri": "8241466276", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:48:59", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:48:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:48:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://thesun.my/world/mountainous-nepal-s-sad-history-of-air-crashes-AD12771045", "title": "Mountainous Nepal's sad history of air crashes", "body": "Officials from the airport stand near the wreckage of a Saurya Airlines plane that caught fire after skidding off the runway while taking off at Tribhuvan International Airport, in Kathmandu - REUTERSpix\n\nMOUNTAINOUS Nepal, where a small plane carrying 19 passengers caught fire during takeoff in the capital on Wednesday, has a sorry history of deadly air crashes.\n\nBefore Wednesday's crash, nearly 360 people had been killed in the country in 19 air crashes since 2000.\n\nHere are details of plane and helicopter crashes this century in the Himalayan country, where several airlines fly to small airports in remote hills and mountains shrouded in clouds and cut off from roads.\n\nJULY 24, 2024 - At least 18 people were killed when a Bombardier CRJ 200 plane crashed and caught fire while it was taking off from Nepal's capital Kathmandu.\n\nJULY 11, 2023 - Six people were killed in a helicopter crash in central Nepal. The chopper, which departed from Solukhunvhu district, home to Mount Everest and other high mountain peaks, had five Mexican nationals and one Nepali pilot on board.\n\nJAN 15, 2023 - A twin-engine ATR 72 aircraft carrying 72 people, operated by Nepal's Yeti Airlines, crashed in Pokhara, killing all on board. It was the worst air crash in the country since 1992 when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane were killed when it ploughed into a hill as it tried to land in Kathmandu.\n\nMAY 29, 2022 - Sixteen Nepalis, four Indians and two Germans died on a De Havilland Canada DHC-6-300 Twin Otter aircraft that crashed 15 minutes after taking off from Pokhara, 125 km (80 miles) west of Kathmandu.\n\nFEB 27, 2019 - A helicopter crashed in bad weather in eastern Nepal, killing all seven people on board, including the tourism minister.\n\nMARCH 12, 2018 - Fifty-one of 71 people on a Bangladeshi airliner operated by US-Bangla Airlines died when it crashed in cloudy weather as it came in to land at the Nepalese capital's hill-ringed airport.\n\nFEB 26, 2016 - Two people were feared dead after a small plane crashed in western Nepal's Kalikot district. It was operated by Kasthamandap Airlines.\n\nFEB 24, 2016 - A small plane crashed in bad weather, killing all 23 people on board. The Twin Otter aircraft, operated by Tara Air, was on a flight from Pokhara to Jomsom in western Nepal.\n\nFEB 16, 2014 - All 18 people on a small plane that crashed in bad weather were killed. The Twin Otter aircraft was operated by state-run Nepal Airlines Corp.\n\nSEPT 28, 2012 - A small propeller-driven Dornier aircraft struck a bird and crashed shortly after takeoff from Kathmandu, killing 19 people, including seven British and five Chinese passengers.\n\nSEPT 25, 2011 - A small plane carrying foreign tourists to view Mount Everest crashed in bad weather near Kathmandu, killing all 19 people on board. The Beech aircraft was operated by private airline Buddha Air.\n\nDEC 16, 2010 - A small plane crashed in the Himalayan foothills of remote east Nepal, killing all 22 people onboard. The Twin Otter aircraft was operated by Tara Air.\n\nAUG 24, 2010 - Fourteen people - including four Americans, a Japanese and British national - were killed when their small plane crashed in bad weather in Nepal. It was operated by privately held Agni Air.\n\nOCT 8, 2008 - A small Twin Otter plane crashed in the remote mountains of northeast Nepal, killing at least 18 people, mostly foreigners.\n\nMARCH 4, 2008 - Four U.N. arms monitors were among at least 10 people killed in a helicopter crash in Nepal.\n\nJUNE 21, 2006 - A Twin Otter passenger plane operated by Yeti Airlines crashed minutes before landing in the west of the country, killing all nine people on board.\n\nMAY 25, 2004 - A Twin Otter cargo plane crashed in the Mount Everest region, killing its three crew. It was operated by Yeti Airlines.\n\nAUG 22, 2002 - Another Twin Otter plane, carrying foreign tourists, slammed into a mountain in bad weather in Nepal, killing all 18 people on board. It was operated by Shangrila Air.\n\nJULY 17, 2002 - Four people were feared dead after a twin-engined aircraft crashed into a mountain in west Nepal minutes before it was due to land.\n\nJULY 27, 2000 - A Canadian-built Twin Otter passenger plane crashed in western Nepal, killing all 25 people on board. The Bombardier CRJ200 aircraft veered off the runway and burst into flames. Authorities shut down the airport, affecting numerous flights.\n\nA private Nepalese domestic plane bound for Pokhara crashed during takeoff at Tribhuvan International Airport on Wednesday, resulting in the deaths of 18 technical staff and injuring the pilot of the aircraft, which was carrying 19 people in total.\n\nThe pilot of the Saurya Airlines plane survived the incident and has been transported to a hospital, officials reported. The crash occurred around 11 a.m. when the aircraft veered off the runway and erupted in flames.\n\nFootage from the scene captured dramatic visuals of the plane speeding down the runway before a fire ignited, producing high flames and thick black smoke from the wreckage.\n\nThe Bombardier CRJ200 was only carrying airline technical staff, according to The Himalayan Times.\n\n\"There were no passengers on board but the plane was carrying a few technical staff members,\" stated Gyanendra Bhul, information officer at TIA.\n\nThe Kathmandu Post reported that 18 bodies have been recovered from the crash site. \"The accident happened after the Pokhara-bound flight suffered a runway excursion during takeoff,\" explained TIA Spokesperson Subash Jha.\n\nThe injured pilot has been taken to a hospital, a security official at the airport informed PTI without further details. The fire from the aircraft has been extinguished, with police and firefighters conducting rescue operations at the scene.\n\nAuthorities have shut down the TIA following the crash, as reported by the MyRepublica news portal. Fire engines and ambulances were rushed to the spot after the incident.\n\nThe deceased were identified as co-pilot S Katuwal and 17 employees of the Saurya Airlines, including a Nepali female and a Yemeni national. Pilot captain Manish Shakya, 37, is undergoing treatment at Kathmandu Model Hospital.\n\nOf the deceased, 15 died on the spot while three died during treatment at a local hospital, authorities said.\n\nFollowing the accident, services at the Kathmandu airport were halted briefly before being resumed, the airport authorities said.\n\nSaruya Airlines operates flights to five tourist destinations within Nepal, with a fleet of three Bombardier CRJ-200 jets, according to the company's website.\n\nNepal has been criticised for its poor air safety record in recent years but the reasons also include partly sudden weather changes and partly airstrips located in hard-to-access rocky terrains apart from human error.\n\nAccording to Nepal's civil aviation body, 914 people have died in air crashes in the country since the first disaster was recorded in August 1955.\n\nIn January last year, all 72 people on board, including five Indians, were killed when a Yeti Airlines aircraft crashed in the resort city of Pokhara. The crash was attributed to a human error.\n\nYeti Airlines' 9N-ANC ATR-72 aircraft crashed on the bank of the Seti River between the old airport and the new airport minutes before landing on January 15, 2023, which was the 104th crash in Nepali skies and third biggest in terms of casualties.\n\nThe only incidents in which more people were killed took place in July and September 1992. Those crashes involved aircraft of Thai Airways and Pakistan International Airlines and left 113 and 167 people dead, respectively.\n\nOn May 29, 2022, all 22 people on board, including four members of an Indian family, were killed as a Tara Air plane crashed in Nepal's mountainous Mustang district.\n\nIn 2016, all 23 people aboard were killed when a plane of the same airline flying the same route crashed after takeoff.\n\nIn March 2018, a US-Bangla Air crash occurred at the Tribhuvan International Airport, killing 51 people on board. after a plane crashed during take-off in the Nepali capital of Kathmandu on Wednesday, officials have confirmed.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight, heading to Pokhara, was carrying two crew and 17 of the company's staff for a test flight, Nepali police spokesman Dan Bahadur Karki told AFP.\n\nThe plane slipped off the runway during takeoff, witnesses told the Kathmandu Post, before immediately catching fire and plunging into a gorge.\n\nPolice confirmed 18 bodies were removed from the crash site, where local media photographed rescue crews surrounding the fragmented wreckage.\n\nA doctor said the pilot suffered eye injuries and is not in a serious condition.\n\nNepal has a poor aviation record and has seen a spate of deadly flight disasters in recent years.\n\nIn December, the European Union extended a decade-long ban on Nepali airlines in its airspace, saying they do not meet international aviation safety standards.\n\nIn January 2023, 72 people were killed when a Yeti Airlines flight crashed near the city of Pokhara.\n\nThat flight also plunged into a 300-metre gorge shortly before it was due to land, and was the country's deadliest plane crash since since 1992, The footage captures the jet's final seconds before impact.\n\nThe video begins shortly after take-off, with the plane already out of control and only a few hundred feet above the ground. Within moments, the Saurya Airlines flight to Pokhara, which was tilting to the right, suddenly veers left and crashes, erupting into flames.\n\nAuthorities have confirmed that there were 19 people on board -- two crew members and 17 passengers. Tragically, 18 people have died. The sole survivor, the pilot, has been taken to a local hospital, according to an airport security official.\n\nThe cause of the crash remains unknown at this time.\n\nEarlier today, another shocking video captured the exact moment the plane hit the ground.\n\nVIDEO | Exact Moment Saurya Airlines Plane Crashed At Kathmandu Airport\n\nThis 18-second video, recorded by a CCTV camera at the airport, shows the plane slamming into the runway, skidding across the ground, and bursting into flames.\n\nNepal's aviation sector has seen rapid growth recently but is plagued by poor safety standards, inadequate training, and maintenance issues. Consequently, the European Union has banned Nepali airlines from entering its airspace. The country's challenging topography, featuring high-altitude runways surrounded by mountainous terrain, poses significant risks even for experienced pilots.\n\nThe weather in these regions is also notoriously unpredictable, further complicating aviation safety.\n\nREAD | Kathmandu Crash: Nepal Home To Some Of World's Trickiest Runways\n\nIn January last year, a Yeti Airlines plane crashed while landing in Pokhara, killing all 72 people on board. That incident was Nepal's deadliest plane crash since 1992 when a Pakistani jet crashed in Kathmandu, killing all 167 passengers. That same year, a Thai Airways flight also crashed, resulting in 113 fatalities.\n\nThis recent crash has also drawn attention to the dangers of tabletop runways in India.\n\nTabletop runways are located on top of hills or elevated terrain, creating a steep drop on one or more sides and leaving very little room for error if a plane overshoots the runway.\n\nREAD | Nepal Crash Red-Flags Table-Top Runways Risk, India Has 5\n\nIndia has five airports with tabletop runways -- Shimla, Kozhikode, Mangaluru, Lengpui (in Mizoram), and Pakyong (in Sikkim). Notably, both Kozhikode and Mangaluru have experienced major crashes.\n\nNDTV is now available on WhatsApp channels. Pokhara when it crashed on Wednesday morning, say Nepal Television.\n\nShocked witnesses say the plane suddenly flipped midair as the wing collided with the ground - instantly catching on fire.\n\nMoments later it was seen spiralling into a gorge on the eastern side of the runway.\n\nOnlookers were seen scrambling across a field where the plane was left to help the military, rescuers and firefighters find any survivors.\n\nTragically, 18 people have been reported as dead with only one other miraculously surviving the death plunge, officials say.\n\nMost of the 19 people onboard were airline employees, they added.\n\nOne of the survivors, Captain MR Shakya, has been rushed to the Kathmandu Medical College Hospital, says TIA spokesperson Subash Jha.\n\nHe injured his eye in the crash but his injuries are not life-threatening.\n\nInvestigations into what caused the plane to skid off the runway are ongoing.\n\nInitial reports point towards the flight suffering a runway {"uri": "8241081047", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:55:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:55:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:54:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/india-news/tyre-burst-or-accident-eyewitnesses-recount-nepal-plane-crash-horror-101721814563374.html", "title": "'Tyre burst or accident?': Eyewitnesses recount Nepal plane crash horror", "body": "Eyewitnesses of the Saurya Airlines plane crash at Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport said they thought the loud sound was caused by a\n\nAt least 18 people were killed in the crash after the plane caught fire while taking off from Nepal's capital Kathmandu on July 24.\n\nThe Search and Rescue Centre of the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement that the Bombardier CRJ-200 aircraft suffered a runway excursion and burst into massive flames immediately.\n\n\"I was working here at my garage in the morning and then I heard a loud sound. We thought a tyre burst but we came to know that a plane had crashed. It had knocked a container, if it wasn't the container then it surely would have slid down and hit the residential area. The container saved us. It struck the container and came to the ground and got engulfed by fire,\" ANI quoted an eye-witness, Aadesh Lama, as saying.\n\nFollow Live Updates on Nepal plane crash\n\nAuthorities said, fifteen people died at the spot, while three others succumbed to injuries later in the hospital. Airport services in Kathmandu were stopped briefly after the accident but have now restarted.\n\n\"I heard a loud bang, about three to four of us were here. We first assumed it to be a vehicle accident but it turned out to be an aircraft that had crashed. The plane slid down and stopped, at first there was the sound, then after the smoke billowed and then it was engulfed by fire. I rushed near to the site where the plane crashed and there again was an explosion,\" another eye-witness, Krishna Bahadur Thapa told ANI.\n\nSaurya operates domestic flights in Nepal with two The chopper, which departed from Solukhunvhu district, home to Mount Everest and other high mountain peaks, had five Mexican nationals and one Nepali pilot on board.\n\nA twin-engine ATR 72 aircraft carrying 72 people, operated by Nepal's Yeti Airlines, crashed in Pokhara, killing all on board.\n\nIt was the worst air crash in the country since 1992 when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane were killed when it ploughed into a hill as it tried to land in Kathmandu.\n\nSixteen Nepalis, four Indians and two Germans died on a De Havilland Canada DHC-6-300 Twin Otter aircraft that crashed 15 minutes after taking off from Pokhara, 125km west of Kathmandu.\n\nA helicopter crashed in bad weather in eastern Nepal, killing all seven people on board, including the tourism minister.\n\nFifty-one of 71 people on a Bangladeshi airliner operated by US-Bangla Airlines died when it crashed in cloudy weather as it came in to land at the Nepalese capital's hill-ringed airport.\n\nTwo people were feared dead after a small plane crashed in western Nepal's Kalikot district. strips perched on mountainsides and aging fleets in one of Southeast Asia's poorest countries all contribute to making it one of the most difficult places for aircraft to operate.\n\nNepal has seen {"uri": "8240851334", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:36:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:36:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:35:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/saurya-airlines-plane-crash-kathmandu-nepal-averages-1-flight-disaster-every-year-why-is-the-number-so-high-101721805002940.html", "title": "Plane crashes: Nepal averages 1 flight disaster every year. Why is the number so high?", "body": "The plane was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians to Pokhara city to repair another aircraft, officials said. Television visuals showed fire fighters trying to put out the blaze and thick black smoke rising into the sky. They also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting before it crashed.\n\nNepal averages about one flight disaster a year. Nepal has seen an unusually high number of plane crashes in the last decade. The deadliest plane crash in the country took place on January 16, 2023, in Pokhara, where 72 people died. In the last 12 years, the Kathmandu plane crash is the 13th plane crash reported in Nepal.\n\nOne of the most common reasons why Nepal has seen over a dozen aircraft accidents in the last decade is because of the lack of proper maintenance and aircraft training. Nepal is a struggling economy, and there is a lack of infrastructure for proper maintenance of aircrafts, and proper training of staff.\n\nNepal also has a tricky topography which makes it difficult for pilots to navigate to the small and remote airports in the country. Nepal also lacks the infrastructure for accurate weather forecasts, especially in remote areas and mountainous terrains, where some of the most deadly plane crashes of the country have taken place.\n\nThe weather in Nepal is unpredictable and changes quickly in many areas due to the hilly terrain, and can make for dangerous conditions for a flight.\n\nIt is currently the monsoon season in Nepal but it was not raining at the time of the plane crash in Kathmandu today. However, weather agencies said that there was low visibility in the area.\n\nThe Kathmandu airport, the main airport serving Nepal, is located inside a valley surrounded by mountains on most sides. It is considered a challenging airport for pilots and bigger planes have to come through an opening on the mountain to land. It is right next to the city. Currently, there are no reports of any casualties in this incident. {"uri": "8241566158", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:57:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:57:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:53:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/plane-crash-at-nepals-kathmandu-airport-kills-18-captain-survives/2189650/", "title": "Plane crash at Nepal's Kathmandu airport kills 18; captain survives", "body": "The 50-seater plane, carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, was heading for regular maintenance to Nepal's new Pokhara airport, which is equipped with aircraft maintenance hangars, the officials said.\n\nEighteen of those on board the CRJ-200 aircraft were Nepali citizens, with one engineer from Yemen, Saurya said.\n\n\"Shortly after takeoff ... the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nThe crash again focused attention on the poor air safety record of the impoverished, landlocked Himalayan nation that is wedged between India and China and is heavily dependent upon air connectivity due to its limited road network.\n\nNearly 360 people have died in plane or helicopter crashes in the country since 2000.\n\nNepal's prime minister, K.P. Sharma Oli, visited the crash site and asked people to \"be patient\" in a social media post, without elaborating.\n\nAn emergency cabinet meeting was called to form a panel to investigate the incident, a government spokesman said.\n\nTelevision footage showed fire fighters trying to put out the blaze as thick black smoke rose into the sky. Images also showed the plane flying a little above the runway and then tilting to its right before it crashed.\n\nOther visuals showed rescue workers examining the charred remains of the plane, strewn in lush green fields, and bodies being carried to ambulances on stretchers.\n\nKathmandu airport was closed temporarily following the crash but reopened within hours, officials said.\n\nAccording to Flightradar24 flight tracking, Saurya currently operates two CRJ-200 regional jets, a programme that was owned by Canada's Bombardier but which was bought by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries in 2020.\n\nBombardier referred questions about the incident to Canada-based MHI RJ Aviation Group.\n\n\"We are committed to cooperate with the authorities in the investigation to get an understanding of the cause of this accident,\" MHI said in a statement to Reuters.\n\nNepal has been criticised for its poor air safety record, where many airlines fly to small airports in remote hills and near peaks shrouded in clouds. The country is home to eight of the world's 14 tallest mountain peaks.\n\nThe country's main airport is ringed by mountains, affecting wind direction and intensity and making takeoff and landing a challenge for pilots.\n\nThe deadliest incident occurred in 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines Airbus crashed into a hillside while approaching Kathmandu, killing 167 people.\n\nMore recently, at least 72 people were killed in a Yeti airlines crash in January 2023 that was later attributed to the pilots mistakenly cutting off power.\n\n(Reporting by Kathmandu newsroom; Additional Many have not survived,\" he added.\n\nImages of the aftermath shared by Nepal's military showed the plane's fuselage split apart and burnt to a husk.\n\nAround a dozen soldiers in camouflage were standing on top of the wreckage, with the surrounding earth coated in fire retardant.\n\nThe plane crashed at around 11:15 am (0530 GMT), the military said in a statement, adding that the army's quick response team had been lending assistance with rescue efforts.\n\nNews portal Khabarhub reported that the airplane had caught fire after skidding on the runway.\n\nThe plane was scheduled to fly on Nepal's most-trafficked air route between Kathmandu and Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its website.\n\nNepal's air industry has boomed in recent years, carrying goods and people between hard-to-reach areas as well as foreign trekkers and climbers. But it has been plagued by poor safety due to insufficient training and maintenance -- issues compounded by the mountainous republic's treacherous geography.\n\nNotably, the European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace over safety concerns.\n\nThe Himalayan country has some of the world's trickiest runways to land on, flanked by snow-capped peaks with approaches that pose a challenge even for accomplished pilots.\n\nThe weather can also change quickly in the mountains, creating treacherous flying conditions.\n\nNepal's last major commercial flight accident was in January 2023, when a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, killing all 72 aboard.\n\nThat accident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International {"uri": "8240813236", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:15:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:15:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:11:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://keyt.com/news/national-world/cnn-world/2024/07/24/plane-crashes-during-takeoff-in-nepal-killing-at-least-18/", "title": "Plane crashes during takeoff in Nepal, killing at least 18", "body": "(CNN) -- At least 18 people were killed after a small plane skidded off the runway in Nepal's capital on Wednesday, according to local officials.\n\nOne person survived the Saurya Airlines crash, the Civil Aviation Authority said in a statement. All 19 people aboard were employees of the carrier, according to police.\n\nImages from Nepal police showed thick smoke billowing from the burning aircraft on the the airport runway.\n\nThe aircraft crashed during takeoff from Kathmandu to the city of Pokhara around 11 a.m. local time, Gyanendra Bhul, an information officer at Tribhuvan International Airport told CNN.\n\nThe plane was en route for technical maintenance, he added.\n\n\"Rescue efforts were started immediately and the situation was brought under control,\" the aviation authority said.\n\nThe crash once again highlights the dangers of air travel in Nepal, a country often referred to as one of the riskiest places to fly due to multiple factors including its mountainous terrain.\n\nThe Himalayan country, home to eight of the world's 14 highest mountains including Everest, has a record of air accidents. Its weather can change suddenly, and airstrips are typically sited in difficult-to-reach, mountainous areas.\n\nAircraft with 19 seats or fewer are more likely to have accidents due to these difficulties, according to a 2019 safety report from the Civil Aviation Authority.\n\nWhile the country has made improvements in safety standards in recent years, challenges remain, and a lack of investment in aging aircraft only adds to the risks of flying.\n\nIn early 2018, a US-Bangla Airlines flight from Bangladesh's capital Dhaka to Kathmandu crashed on landing and caught fire, killing 51 people.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. In the incident, 18 people onboard were killed and the pilot, the only survivor, was seriously injured. The plane flying from Kathmandu to Pokhara turned in the wrong direction.\n\nNepal has been criticised for its poor air safety record in recent years. But reasons for plane crashes also include partly sudden weather changes and partly airstrips located in hard-to-access rocky terrains apart from human error. In January last year, all 72 people on board, including five Indians, were killed when a Yeti Airlines aircraft crashed in the resort city of Pokhara. The crash was attributed to a human error.\n\nAccording to Nepal's civil aviation body, 914 people have died in air crashes in the country since the first disaster was recorded in August 1955. But why does Nepal witness frequent airplane crashes?\n\nThe first reason is Nepal's geographical challenges. According to the safety report of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority, Nepal's mountains and narrow valleys are a big challenge for pilots.\n\nThe second reason is Nepal's weather - Rain and fog are common in Nepal, which makes landing and takeoff of planes dangerous.\n\nNatural challenges are not the only reason for plane crashes in Nepal. A major reason for this is also the lack of technology in Nepal. Most of the planes of Nepali Airlines are old and second-hand, which have outdated systems installed.\n\nDespite being old, the lack of maintenance of planes is also a big problem which poses a safety risk. Apart from this, a big reason is also the lack of pilots. All aboard - 18 Nepalis and a Yemeni citizen - were employees of the carrier, according to police.\n\nImages from Nepal police showed thick smoke billowing from the burning aircraft on the the airport runway.\n\nThe aircraft crashed during takeoff from Kathmandu to the city of Pokhara around 11 a.m. local time, Gyanendra Bhul, an information officer at Tribhuvan International Airport told CNN.\n\nThe plane was en route for technical maintenance, he added.\n\n\"Rescue efforts were started immediately and the situation was brought under control,\" the aviation authority said.\n\nThe crash once again highlights the dangers of air travel in Nepal, a country often referred to as one of the riskiest places to fly due to multiple factors including its mountainous terrain.\n\nThe Himalayan country, home to eight of the world's 14 highest mountains including Everest, has a record of air accidents. Its weather can change suddenly, and airstrips are typically sited in difficult-to-reach, mountainous areas.\n\nAircraft with 19 seats or fewer are more likely to have accidents due to these difficulties, according to a 2019 safety report from the Civil Aviation Authority.\n\nWhile the country has made improvements in safety standards in recent years, challenges remain, and a lack of investment in aging aircraft only adds to the risks of flying.\n\nIn early 2018, a US-Bangla Airlines flight from Bangladesh's capital Dhaka to Kathmandu crashed on landing and caught fire, killing 51 people.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "8241169899", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "11:48:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T11:48:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T11:47:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.indiatoday.in/world/story/nepal-plane-crash-death-toll-family-killed-kathmandu-saurya-airlines-2571270-2024-07-24", "title": "Family of three among 18 killed in Nepal plane crash", "body": "Plane crashed while taking off in Kathmandu18 people died, pilot survived and hospitalisedPlane was carrying 2 crew members and 17 technicians\n\nA Saurya Airlines plane crashed while taking off from Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA) in Nepal's Kathmandu on Wednesday. Eighteen people died in the accident. Among the victims were three members of the same family: Manuraj Sharma, a flight maintenance staff member; his wife, Priza Khatiwada; and their four-year-old son, Adhiraj Sharma.\n\nThe airline reported that all passengers on board were employees of Saurya Airlines, including technical staff travelling for maintenance work. However, a spokesperson from the Ministry of Energy, Navinraj Singh, clarified that Priza Khatiwada was an assistant computer operator employed at the ministry. This was also confirmed by the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal, which listed the names of the deceased family members.\n\nThe aircraft, identified as 9N-AME (CRJ 200), was on its way to Pokhara Regional Airport for regular maintenance. The co-pilot, Sushant Katuwal, was among the victims, while the pilot, 37-year-old Manish Shakya, survived the crash and was taken to a nearby hospital in Sinamangal for treatment.\n\nThe crash occurred shortly after takeoff when the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway, as reported by the Civil Aviation Authority. The plane, carrying two crew members and 17 technicians, caught fire upon impact.\n\nVisuals from the spot showed firefighters attempting to extinguish the blaze, with thick black smoke rising into the sky.\n\nRescue operations were swiftly initiated, with local residents and officials working together to recover the bodies and transport them to ambulances.\n\nThe aircraft was scheduled to undergo maintenance from Thursday.\n\n\"The plane was scheduled to undergo maintenance for a month beginning Thursday ... {"uri": "8241652459", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:55:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:55:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:54:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://7news.com.au/news/plane-crashes-just-after-takeoff-from-nepals-capital-kathmandu-killing-18-people-c-15469130", "title": "18 dead, one survivor as plane crashes on takeoff in Nepal", "body": "The aircraft crashed moments after takeoff in the eastern section of the airport.\n\nAt least 18 people were killed when a small plane crashed just after taking off from Nepal's capital of Kathmandu on Wednesday.\n\nThe pilot, who was taken to Kathmandu Medical College Hospital with non-life-threatening injuries to his eyes, is the sole survivor of the Saurya Airlines crash at Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nAll those on board - 18 Nepalis and a Yemeni citizen - were either mechanics or airline employees, according to police.\n\nKnow the news with the 7NEWS app: Download today\n\nThe Bombardier CRJ 200 aircraft - en route for technical maintenance in the resort town of Pokhara - crashed moments after takeoff in the eastern section of the airport about 11am local time, airport spokesperson Gyanendra Bhul said.\n\nImages from Nepal police showed thick smoke billowing from the burning aircraft on the airport runway.\n\n\"Rescue efforts were started immediately and the situation was brought under control,\" the aviation authority said.\n\nIt is the monsoon rain season in Kathmandu but was not raining at the time of the crash. Visibility was low across the capital, however.\n\nThe bodies have been taken to the T.U. Teaching Hospital in Kathmandu for autopsy.\n\nGrieving relatives gathered at the hospital forensics department to collect the bodies of their loved ones, though they are not likely to be released for a day or two.\n\nThe co-pilot Sasant Katuwal had been flying only for the past three years after completing training in France, his uncle Dhyan Bahadur Khadka said at the hospital. He had just received a visa to go to Germany for further training and was excited about that, Khadka said.\n\nKhadka said his nephew had a bright future in aviation. \"His parents are grieving the loss of their only child,\" Khadka said. \"He was unmarried. He was not just tall and handsome, but he was well-behaved,\"\n\nThe crash again highlights the dangers of air travel in Nepal, a country often referred to as one of the riskiest places to fly due to multiple factors including its mountainous terrain.\n\nThe Himalayan country, home to eight of the world's 14 highest mountains including Everest, has a record of air accidents. Its weather can change suddenly, and airstrips are typically sited in difficult-to-reach, mountainous areas.\n\nAircraft with 19 seats or fewer are more likely to have accidents due to these difficulties, according to a 2019 safety report from the Civil Aviation Authority.\n\nWhile the country has made improvements in safety standards in recent years, challenges remain, and a lack of investment in aging aircraft only adds to the risks of flying.\n\nTribhuvan International Airport, the main airport in Nepal for international and domestic flights, was closed for hours as emergency crew and investigators began their work.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates the Bombardier CRJ 200 on domestic routes.", "source": {"uri": "7news.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "7NEWS.com.au"}, The Saurya Airlines flight was headed to Pokhara, a popular tourism destination known for its stunning landscapes and adventure activities.\n\nThe aircraft reportedly skidded off the runway during takeoff, leading to a devastating crash. Eyewitnesses and videos posted online depicted the plane engulfed in fire and smoke shortly after the incident, raising immediate concerns about the safety of those on board.\n\nEmergency response teams, including firefighters and medical personnel, were swiftly deployed to the crash site. Their efforts were focused on extinguishing the fire and rescuing passengers and crew from the wreckage. Initial reports from local media suggest that at least four people are feared dead, though this figure remains unconfirmed as of now.\n\nAn airline official, speaking to the BBC, confirmed that the Saurya Airlines flight was bound for Pokhara. Only the pilot has survived. The ill-fated flight, bound for Pokhara, met with disaster around 11am today, according to news agency PTI.\n\nPremnath Thakur, spokesperson for the airport, confirmed the crash and reported the tragic loss of lives. Police and firefighters immediately launched rescue operations at the scene. A security official revealed that the pilot was rushed to hospital but refrained from providing further details.\n\nEyewitness accounts described the harrowing moments as the plane caught fire, releasing a significant plume of smoke, reported news portal Khabarhub. Emergency services swiftly extinguished the blaze, but the damage had already been done.\n\nThe aircraft, a Bombardier CRJ 200 jet, was part of Saurya Airlines' fleet, primarily used to connect hard-to-reach areas and tourist destinations across Nepal. Despite the country's burgeoning air industry, safety concerns remain prevalent due to inadequate training and maintenance. Consequently, the European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace.\n\nNepal has a troubling history of aviation disasters, averaging one flight catastrophe per year. Since 2010, there have been at least 12 fatal crashes.\n\nIn January 2023, a Yeti Airlines flight tragically crashed near Pokhara, killing all 72 people on board. Similarly, in May 2022, a Tara Air plane went down in the Mustang district, resulting in 22 fatalities.\n\nAnother notable disaster occurred in 2018, when a US-Bangla Airlines flight crash-landed near Kathmandu, claiming 51 lives and seriously injuring 20 others, reported Hindustan Times.\n\nIn related news, Taliban officials confirmed that a plane, en route from Pattaya, Thailand, to Russia, crashed in Afghanistan on January 21, resulting in the loss of two lives, while four passengers managed to survive. killing 18 people - was on its way for maintenance, it's been revealed.\n\nMechanics and airline staff were aboard the Saurya Airlines flight out of the Nepali capital, which was bound for Pokhara for works.\n\nThe Bombardier CRJ plane nosedived moments later, smashing into the ground with a four-year-old boy and his parents among those killed.\n\nThe pilot was the only one on board to survive and was rushed to hospital - but miraculously only suffered injuries to his eyes with his condition non-life threatening.\n\nNow airport officials speaking anonymously have said most of the passengers were mechanics and airline workers, Associated Press reported.\n\nTragically, Saurya Airlines technician Manuraj Sharma and wife Prija Khatiwada died alongside their four-year-old son Adhiraj Sharma.\n\nPrija worked as an assistant computer operator at the Minister of Energy, Water, Resources and Irrigation, according to reports.\n\nThe flight took off from Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA) at 11:11am, but it when turned right it began to plunge.\n\nHorrifying footage captured the crash, showing the jet spiralling back down to earth.\n\nIt slams into the ground and a cloud of dark smoke erupts as terrified onlookers watch on helplessly.\n\nA witness told AP of the horror scene: \"I came out and saw a plane had crashed and there was huge smoke and fire coming out.\n\n\"There was chaos and confusion.\n\n\"It was just horrible and there was no way that anyone could just go near the plane and help out when there was so much fire and even explosions.\"\n\nThe bodies were sent for autopsy at Kathmandu's TU Teaching Hospital, where horrified family members gathered waiting for their relatives' bodies to be released.\n\nHeartbreaking pictures showed relatives in despair and trying to console one another as they broke down in tears.\n\nOne of those was the uncle of co-pilot Sasant Katuwal, who perished in the freak incident.\n\nHe said his nephew was destined to be a great pilot, with the family now left reeling after losing their only child.\n\nTIA airport was closed for hours with investigators combing over the crash.\n\nAll of the passengers killed were Nepali except for a Yemeni national.\n\nAccording Reuters, Saurya Airlines marketing boss Mukesh Khanal said: \"The plane was scheduled to undergo maintenance for a month beginning Thursday... It is unclear why it crashed.\"\n\nIt's not the first story of aviation horror out of Nepal, where unpredictable flying conditions can make for tricky take-off and landing.\n\nIn January 2023, 72 died in a Yeti Airlines disaster - it was later revealed pilots accidentally cut power.\n\nIn 1992, a devastating crash killed 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane.\n\nThe jet crashed {"uri": "2024-07-431751425", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "07:44:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T07:44:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T07:28:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://simpleflying.com/18-killed-in-saurya-airlines-crash-takeoff-kathmandu/", "title": "Breaking: 18 Killed In Saurya Airlines Crash After Takeoff In Kathmandu", "body": "An aircraft belonging to Kathmandu-based Saurya Airlines crashed moments after takeoff this morning, claiming several lives. The flight was scheduled between Nepal's capital city, Kathmandu, and Pokhara - a popular tourist hub. The incident took place at around 11:00 local time, with police and firefighting services reaching the accident site and responding to the situation.\n\n18 reportedly killed\n\nAccording to reports, the aircraft was carrying 19 people, including crew members. Casualties have also been reported, and while official figures will be confirmed by authorities later, some reports suggest that 18 people have died, with the captain of the flight rushed to the hospital.\n\nAccording to the Kathmandu Post, eyewitnesses said that the aircraft was taking off from the southern end of the runway at Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport and flipped suddenly, with its wing hitting the ground. The plane, which was soon engulfed in flames, also dropped into a gorge on the eastern side of the runway, as per reports.\n\nAccording to ch-aviation, Saurya Airlines has three Bombardier CRJ200ER aircraft, of which two are in active service.\n\nThis is a developing story. {"uri": "8240857687", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:41:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:41:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:39:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.news18.com/world/nepal-aircraft-crash-a-look-at-recent-air-accidents-in-the-himalayan-country-8976823.html", "title": "Mountainous Nepal's Sad History Of Air Crashes - News18", "body": "Before Wednesday's crash, nearly 360 people had been killed in the country in 19 air crashes since 2000.\n\nMountainous Nepal, where a small plane carrying 19 passengers caught fire during takeoff in the capital on Wednesday, has a sorry history of deadly air crashes.\n\nBefore Wednesday's crash, nearly 360 people had been killed in the country in 19 air crashes since 2000.\n\nHere are details of plane and helicopter crashes this century in the Himalayan country, where several airlines fly to small airports in remote hills and mountains shrouded in clouds and cut off from roads.\n\nJULY 24, 2024- At least 18 people were killed when a Bombardier CRJ 200 plane crashed and caught fire while it was taking off from Nepal's capital Kathmandu.\n\nJULY 11, 2023- Six people were killed in a helicopter crash in central Nepal. The chopper, which departed from Solukhunvhu district, home to Mount Everest and other high mountain peaks, had five Mexican nationals and one Nepali pilot on board.\n\nJAN 15, 2023- A twin-engine ATR 72 aircraft carrying 72 people, operated by Nepal's Yeti Airlines, crashed in Pokhara, killing all on board. It was the worst air crash in the country since 1992 when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane were killed when it ploughed into a hill as it tried to land in Kathmandu.\n\nMAY 29, 2022- Sixteen Nepalis, four Indians and two Germans died on a De Havilland Canada DHC-6-300 Twin Otter aircraft that crashed 15 minutes after taking off from Pokhara, 125 km (80 miles) west of Kathmandu.\n\nFEB 27, 2019- A helicopter crashed in bad weather in eastern Nepal, killing all seven people on board, including the tourism minister.\n\nMARCH 12, 2018- Fifty-one of 71 people on a Bangladeshi airliner operated by US-Bangla Airlines died when it crashed in cloudy weather as it came in to land at the Nepalese capital's hill-ringed airport.\n\nFEB 26, 2016- Two people were feared dead after a small plane crashed in western Nepal's Kalikot district. It was operated by Kasthamandap Airlines.\n\nFEB 24, 2016- A small plane crashed in bad weather, killing all 23 people on board. The Twin Otter aircraft, operated by Tara Air, was on a flight from Pokhara to Jomsom in western Nepal.\n\nFEB 16, 2014- All 18 people on a small plane that crashed in bad weather were killed. The Twin Otter aircraft was operated by state-run Nepal Airlines Corp.\n\nSEPT 28, 2012- A small propeller-driven Dornier aircraft struck a bird and crashed shortly after takeoff from Kathmandu, killing 19 people, including seven British and five Chinese passengers.\n\nSEPT 25, 2011- A small plane carrying foreign tourists to view Mount Everest crashed in bad weather near Kathmandu, killing all 19 people on board. The Beech aircraft was operated by private airline Buddha Air.\n\nDEC 16, 2010- A small plane crashed in the Himalayan foothills of remote east Nepal, killing all 22 people onboard. The Twin Otter aircraft was operated by Tara Air.\n\nAUG 24, 2010- Fourteen people - including four Americans, a Japanese and British national - were killed when their small plane crashed in bad weather in Nepal. It was operated by privately held Agni Air.\n\nOCT 8, 2008- A small Twin Otter plane crashed in the remote mountains of northeast Nepal, killing at least 18 people, mostly foreigners.\n\nMARCH 4, 2008- Four U.N. arms monitors were among at least 10 people killed in a helicopter crash in Nepal.\n\nJUNE 21, 2006- A Twin Otter passenger plane operated by Yeti Airlines crashed minutes before landing in the west of the country, killing all nine people on board.\n\nMAY 25, 2004- A Twin Otter cargo plane crashed in the Mount Everest region, killing its three crew. It was operated by Yeti Airlines.\n\nAUG 22, 2002- Another Twin Otter plane, carrying foreign tourists, slammed into a mountain in bad weather in Nepal, killing all 18 people on board. It was operated by Shangrila Air.\n\nJULY 17, 2002- Four people were feared dead after a twin-engined aircraft crashed into a mountain in west Nepal minutes before it was due to land.\n\nJULY 27, 2000- A Canadian-built Twin Otter passenger plane crashed in western Nepal, killing all 25 people on board. {"uri": "8240872419", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:49:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:49:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:49:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.flightglobal.com/safety/saurya-airlines-crj200-fatally-crashes-during-take-off-from-kathmandu/159333.article", "title": "Saurya Airlines CRJ200 fatally crashes during take-off from Kathmandu", "body": "A Bombardier CRJ200 operated by Nepalese carrier Saurya Airlines has crashed during take-off from Kathmandu airport, with fatalities among those on board.\n\nThe accident took place at 11:11 local time on 24 July, states the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal (CAAN). The aircraft (9N-AME) was operating a flight from Kathmandu to Pokhara.\n\nAccording to the CAAN, the regional jet veered right as it was taking off and crashed at the east side of runway 02. The accident left 18 dead, with the pilot the sole survivor.\n\nFootage circulating on social media indicates the aircraft banked excessively to the right at low height before appearing to start rolling back towards wings-level flight while descending, ultimately striking the ground right-wing low.\n\nCirium fleets data indicates the aircraft (MSN7772) is built in 2003, and is powered by two GE Aerospace CF34-3B1 turbofans.\n\nIt first operated with now-defunct US operator Atlantic Coast Airlines and entered service with Saurya Airlines - formerly known as Kuber Airlines - in 2017. Saurya Airlines has two CRJ200s in their fleet.\n\nThe accident comes a year since the fatal crash involving a Yeti Airlines ATR 72-500, which was operating flight YT691 from Kathmandu to Pokhara\n\nThe turboprop, carrying 72 passengers and crew, was on approach to Pokhara airport when it crashed, killing everyone on board. July 24 (UNI) A domestic plane crashed during take-off on Wednesday at the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal's capital, leaving 18 dead and 1 injured.\n\nA witness said the plane nosedived into the ground, and an explosion could be heard inside the airport.\n\nEighteen dead bodies were recovered at the crash site, said Hansa Raj Pandey, spokesman at the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal.\n\nPandey told Xinhua that one injured person was sent to the hospital for treatment and the airport has been closed over the incident.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight bound for the city of Pokhara was carrying 19 people and all of them were from the airline, said Pandey.\n\nSubash Jha, the airport spokesman, told Xinhua that the plane was going to Pokhara for \"a C check,\" or maintenance checks.\n\nThe captain of the plane is the only survivor being treated at the hospital, and a committee shall be formed to probe into the incident, Jha said.\n\nA foreigner was aboard the flight, according to passenger information unveiled by the airline.\n\nNepali Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli called a cabinet meeting over the plane crash, press reports said.\n\nUNI/XINHUA ARN", {"uri": "2024-07-431766293", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:00:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:00:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T03:39:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-07-24/factbox-mountainous-nepals-sad-history-of-air-crashes", "title": "Factbox-Mountainous Nepal's Sad History of Air Crashes", "body": "(Reuters) - Mountainous Nepal, where a small plane carrying 19 passengers caught fire during takeoff in the capital on Wednesday, has a sorry history of deadly air crashes.\n\nBefore Wednesday's crash, nearly 360 people had been killed in the country in 19 air crashes since 2000.\n\nHere are details of plane and helicopter crashes this century in the Himalayan country, where several airlines fly to small airports in remote hills and mountains shrouded in clouds and cut off from roads.\n\nJULY 24, 2024\n\nAt least 18 people were killed when a Bombardier CRJ 200 plane crashed and caught fire while it was taking off from Nepal's capital Kathmandu.\n\nJULY 11, 2023\n\nSix people were killed in a helicopter crash in central Nepal. The chopper, which departed from Solukhunvhu district, home to Mount Everest and other high mountain peaks, had five Mexican nationals and one Nepali pilot on board.\n\nJAN 15, 2023\n\nA twin-engine ATR 72 aircraft carrying 72 people, operated by Nepal's Yeti Airlines, crashed in Pokhara, killing all on board.\n\nIt was the worst air crash in the country since 1992 when all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines plane were killed when it ploughed into a hill as it tried to land in Kathmandu.\n\nMAY 29, 2022\n\nSixteen Nepalis, four Indians and two Germans died on a De Havilland Canada DHC-6-300 Twin Otter aircraft that crashed 15 minutes after taking off from Pokhara, 125 km (80 miles) west of Kathmandu.\n\nFEB 27, 2019\n\nA helicopter crashed in bad weather in eastern Nepal, killing all seven people on board, including the tourism minister.\n\nMARCH 12, 2018\n\nFifty-one of 71 people on a Bangladeshi airliner operated by US-Bangla Airlines died when it crashed in cloudy weather as it came in to land at the Nepalese capital's hill-ringed airport.\n\nFEB 26, 2016\n\nTwo people were feared dead after a small plane crashed in western Nepal's Kalikot district. It was operated by Kasthamandap Airlines.\n\nFEB 24, 2016\n\nA small plane crashed in bad weather, killing all 23 people on board. The Twin Otter aircraft, operated by Tara Air, was on a flight from Pokhara to Jomsom in western Nepal.\n\nFEB 16, 2014\n\nAll 18 people on a small plane that crashed in bad weather were killed. The Twin Otter aircraft was operated by state-run Nepal Airlines Corp.\n\nSEPT 28, 2012\n\nA small propeller-driven Dornier aircraft struck a bird and crashed shortly after takeoff from Kathmandu, killing 19 people, including seven British and five Chinese passengers.\n\nSEPT 25, 2011\n\nA small plane carrying foreign tourists to view Mount Everest crashed in bad weather near Kathmandu, killing all 19 people on board.\n\nThe Beech aircraft was operated by private airline Buddha Air.\n\nDEC 16, 2010\n\nA small plane crashed in the Himalayan foothills of remote east Nepal, killing all 22 people onboard. The Twin Otter aircraft was operated by Tara Air.\n\nAUG 24, 2010\n\nFourteen people - including four Americans, a Japanese and British national - were killed when their small plane crashed in bad weather in Nepal. It was operated by privately held Agni Air.\n\nOCT 8, 2008\n\nA small Twin Otter plane crashed in the remote mountains of northeast Nepal, killing at least 18 people, mostly foreigners.\n\nMARCH 4, 2008\n\nFour U.N. arms monitors were among at least 10 people killed in a helicopter crash in Nepal.\n\nJUNE 21, 2006\n\nA Twin Otter passenger plane operated by Yeti Airlines crashed minutes before landing in the west of the country, killing all nine people on board.\n\nMAY 25, 2004\n\nA Twin Otter cargo plane crashed in the Mount Everest region, killing its three crew. It was operated by Yeti Airlines.\n\nAUG 22, 2002\n\nAnother Twin Otter plane, carrying foreign tourists, slammed into a mountain in bad weather in Nepal, killing all 18 people on board. It was operated by Shangrila Air.\n\nJULY 17, 2002\n\nFour people were feared dead after a twin-engined aircraft crashed into a mountain in west Nepal minutes before it was due to land.\n\nJULY 27, 2000\n\nA Canadian-built Twin Otter passenger plane crashed in western Nepal, killing all 25 people on board. It was operated by state-owned Royal Nepal Airlines.\n\n(Compiled by Ainnie Arif, Krishna N. It had on board a total of 19 people, consisting of 17 technical staff members from Saurya Airlines and two crew members. The plane was conducting a test flight when it met with disaster.\n\nSearch and rescue operations are currently underway, with concerns that the number of fatalities may increase as the situation develops. Eyewitness videos shared online depict the aircraft engulfed in flames and smoke immediately following the incident.\n\nIn response to the crash, emergency services, including fire engines and ambulances, were dispatched to the location to attempt to save any survivors. According to police spokesperson Dan Bahadur Karki, a pilot is currently receiving medical treatment for injuries sustained during the crash.\n\nNepal has faced criticism regarding its air safety standards. Earlier this year, a major incident involving a Yeti Airlines crash resulted in the death of 72 individuals and was attributed to pilot error. Such incidents have raised alarms over the safety protocols surrounding aviation in the region.\n\nSaurya Airlines serves multiple destinations within Nepal, operating a fleet that includes three Bombardier CRJ-200 jets.
