{"uri": "2024-07-431791267", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:21:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:21:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:00:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5490196347236633, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/news/world/passenger-plane-crash-nepal-18-dead-3186760", "title": "Passenger plane crashes during takeoff in Nepal killing 18", "body": "Dramatic footage showed the plane tilting just after liftoff, while a separate video showed thick plumes of black smoke billowing from the wreckage\n\nAt least 18 people were killed after a plane crashed while it was taking off from the Nepalese capital of Kathmandu on Wednesday, officials said.\n\nThe plane was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians to nearby Pokhara city to repair another aircraft and the pilot is the only survivor, officials said.\n\nThe aircraft crashed at around 11am local time on Wednesday, according to The Kathmandu Post.\n\n\"Only the captain was rescued alive and is receiving treatment at a hospital,\" said Tej Bahadur Poudyal, the spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport.\n\nLocal media, citing airport officials, reported that the 9N-AME (CRJ 200) aircraft was only carrying technical staff from the airline and there were no paying passengers on board.\n\nDramatic footage showed the plane tilting just after liftoff, before a separate video showed thick plumes of black smoke billowing from the wreckage.\n\nOther images showed rescue workers picking through the charred remains of the plane. Bodies were later carried to ambulances on stretchers as residents watched, television footage showed.\n\nA search operation is ongoing with police, fire engines and ambulances at the scene, while the airport has been temporarily closed, officials added.\n\nNepal has come under heavy scrutiny for its poor air safety record after Yeti Airlines Flight plunged into a gorge in January, killing 72 people. A report by investigators later revealed that the pilots mistakenly cut power which caused the January crash that killed all those on board.\n\nNearly 350 people have died in plane or helicopter (Credit: Reuters)\n\nThe captain of a Nepali passenger plane was the sole survivor Wednesday when a Saurya Airlines aircraft taking off from the capital Kathmandu skidded off the runway and exploded, officials said.\n\nThe disastrous impact that left 18 dead has been captured on video. The pilot was taken to the hospital for treatment.\n\n\"It is unclear why it crashed,\" said Saurya Airlines marketing head Mukesh Khanal, according to Reuters.\n\nThe plane carrying 18 Nepalis and a Yemeni citizen, all employees of the carrier, was headed to a new airport in Pokhara. The technicians were scheduled to conduct routine maintenance, Reuters reported.\n\nDEADLY NEPAL PLANE CRASH LIKELY CAUSED BY BASIC PILOT ERROR, REPORT FINDS\n\n\"Shortly after takeoff, the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a statement.\n\nNEPAL CRASH: VIDEO FROM INSIDE PLANE SHOWS PASSENGERS' FINAL MOMENTS\n\nVideo showed firefighters combating the blaze as a plume of thick black smoke billowed into the sky.\n\nPhotos also captured first responders conducting search-and-rescue operations in the wreckage.\n\nReuters reported that the incident involving the 50-seat CRJ-200 aircraft caused the Kathmandu airport to close temporarily. The facility was able to reopen within hours.\n\nGET FOX BUSINESS ON THE GO BY CLICKING HERE\n\nThe crash once again highlights the dangers of air travel in Nepal, which has had a poor air safety record.\n\nThe Himalayan country is home to eight of the world's 14 tallest mountains, where airstrips are deemed difficult to reach - especially when planes must navigate near peaks shrouded in clouds. Kathmandu is particularly difficult to approach, as the airport is located in a valley surrounded by mountains, according to Aviation Safety Network.\n\nSince 2000, around 350 passengers have died while riding Nepali aircraft. Bodies of eighteen people have been recovered and a doctor says the pilot survived the crash.\n\nThe accident occurred at around 11 am local time after the Saurya Airlines flight suffered a runway excursion during takeoff, said TIA Spokesperson Subash Jha. The flight was en route to Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic.\n\n\"Nineteen people, including aircrew, were aboard,\" the airport spokesperson Premnath Thakur said.\n\nNews portal Khabarhub reported that the airplane had caught fire and was \"releasing a significant plume of smoke\".\n\nEyewitnesses say that the plane was taking off from the Southern-end of the runway (Koteshwor side) and suddenly flipped with the wing tip hitting the ground. The aircraft caught fire immediately. It then plunged to a gorge on the eastern side of the runway -- between Buddha Air hanger and the radar station.\n\nSaurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, according to its Additionally, less than an hour after, first responders conducted a search and rescue operation following the incident.\n\nThe deadly blaze and explosion prompted the Kathmandu airport to close temporarily. However, the facility was able to reopen within hours.\n\nK.P. Sharma Oli, the prime minister of Nepal, visited the crash site and made the vague request to \"be patient\" in a social media post.\n\nStay informed! {"uri": "8241012157", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:14:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:14:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:13:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5411764979362488, "url": "https://www.bbntimes.com/society/pilot-only-survivor-of-nepal-plane-crash-tragedy-at-kathmandu-airport", "title": "Pilot Only Survivor of Nepal Plane Crash: Tragedy at Kathmandu Airport", "body": "A Saurya Airlines test flight crashed and caught fire shortly after takeoff from Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport, killing 18 people.\n\nThe pilot is the sole survivor and is currently receiving treatment in a hospital. The doomed flight had 19 people on board, including technical staff members and two crew members. This incident highlights ongoing concerns about Nepal's aviation safety record, which has been criticized for years due to factors such as unpredictable weather conditions and lax regulatory oversight.\n\nThe crash occurred at approximately 11:15 local time (05:30 GMT), just minutes after the plane took off. According to a statement from the Nepal Civil Aviation Authority's search and rescue coordination center, the flight was headed to Pokhara, a popular tourist destination known for its scenic beauty and as a gateway to the Annapurna Circuit, a renowned trekking route.\n\nJagannath Niraula, the airport chief, informed BBC Nepali that the accident happened almost immediately after takeoff. \"It happened as soon as it left the ground, in not even a minute,\" he said. While the exact cause of the crash has yet to be determined, preliminary assessments suggest that the aircraft veered in the wrong direction. \"As soon as it took off, it turned right, [when it] should have turned left,\" Niraula explained.\n\nRescue workers were quickly on the scene, navigating through the charred wreckage. Photos from the site depict large portions of the plane blackened and burnt, with earlier visuals showing the aircraft engulfed in flames and smoke. Fire engines and ambulances responded rapidly to the emergency, but despite their swift action, 17 Nepali nationals and one Yemeni national, who was working as an engineer, lost their lives.\n\nEyewitnesses reported hearing \"some cracking noises\" from the plane before the crash, adding to the speculation about potential mechanical failure or pilot error. The exact sequence of events leading to the disaster will be the subject of a thorough investigation by aviation authorities.\n\nNepal's aviation industry has a notorious reputation for poor safety standards. This latest incident adds to a grim history of aviation disasters in the country. In January 2023, a Yeti Airlines crash resulted in the deaths of at least 72 people. That tragedy was attributed to the pilots mistakenly cutting off the power, marking the deadliest air crash in Nepal since 1992. In that earlier disaster, all 167 people aboard a Pakistan International Airlines flight perished when the plane crashed on approach to Kathmandu Airport.\n\nSaurya Airlines, which operates a fleet of three Bombardier CRJ-200 jets, flies to five destinations within Nepal. The airline's website states that it aims to provide safe and reliable air transport, but this incident casts a shadow over those claims.\n\nThe broader issues plaguing Nepal's aviation sector include a challenging topography, unpredictable weather patterns, and inadequate infrastructure. The country's mountainous terrain and rapidly changing weather can make flying hazardous, particularly for smaller aircraft. Additionally, the regulatory framework governing aviation in Nepal has been criticized for not enforcing stringent safety protocols and for being slow to adopt international best practices.\n\nIn response to past incidents, there have been calls for comprehensive reforms to improve aviation safety in Nepal. These reforms include upgrading airport infrastructure, enhancing pilot training programs, and implementing more rigorous maintenance procedures for aircraft. International aviation bodies have also urged Nepal to align its safety standards with global norms to prevent future tragedies.\n\nAs the investigation into this latest crash unfolds, the families of the victims and the sole surviving pilot face a long and difficult journey ahead. The pilot's testimony will be crucial in understanding what went wrong and in ensuring that lessons are learned to prevent similar accidents in the future.\n\nThis tragedy serves as a stark reminder of the risks associated with air travel in Nepal. Despite the beauty and allure of the country's landscapes, the safety of its aviation industry remains a pressing concern. Ensuring the safety of passengers and crew must be the top priority for airlines and regulatory authorities alike.\n\nIn the wake of this disaster, there will undoubtedly be renewed scrutiny of Saurya Airlines and the overall safety practices within Nepal's aviation sector. The international community and aviation experts will be watching closely to see how Nepal addresses these challenges and works to improve its safety record.\n\nFor now, the focus remains on supporting the families of those who lost their lives and on conducting a thorough investigation to uncover the causes of the crash. Only by addressing the underlying issues and implementing necessary reforms can Nepal hope to prevent future aviation tragedies and restore confidence in its air travel industry.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8241288694", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "13:00:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T13:00:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T12:59:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://www.businessinsider.com/nepal-plane-crash-all-airlines-banned-in-most-europe-2024-7", "title": "Nepal just suffered another fatal plane crash. Its aviation safety record is so poor that all its airlines are banned from flying to most of Europe.", "body": "This story is available exclusively to Business Insider subscribers. Become an Insider and start reading now. Have an account? Log in.\n\nAll 18 bodies have been recovered from the crash site at the Tribhuvan International Airport in Nepal. The pilot, Captain Manish Ratna Shkya, was rescued and is being treated for injuries at Kathmandu Medical College and Teaching Hospital.\n\nVideos and photos posted online showed billows of black smoke emerging from the wreckage of the plane, then on fire but since put out by firefighters.\n\nThe search and rescue coordination of the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal said in a recently released statement that the plane \"veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway.\"\n\n\"Rescue operations were initiated immediately,\" it said. \"The fire was brought under control,\" the statement added.\n\nNepal has a poor aviation safety record and is often regarded as one of the most dangerous countries for air travel. All Nepali air carriers are banned from entering the airspace of any European Union country, per the EU Air Safety List.\n\nThe European Union Aviation Safety Agency bans airlines from operating in the EU for \"failure to adhere to the applicable international safety standards.\"\n\nProfessor Ron Bartch, chairman and founding director of aviation consultancy firm AvLaw, told Business Insider that one reason for its poor safety record is that the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal is \"not a terribly well-resourced safety regulator.\"\n\nThe CAAN did not immediately respond to a request for comment from Business Insider.\n\nNepal's mountainous terrain, unpredictable weather, and remote runways have contributed to the country's reputation as one of the most difficult places to fly.\n\nKathmandu's high altitude makes for a \"challenging operating environment,\" Bartch added, noting that this means a greater distance and an accelerated approach speed are required for takeoff and landing as the air is less dense than at sea level.\n\nHe also said Nepal's monsoonal conditions affect the country's aviation safety.\n\nThe deadliest plane crash in Nepal in three decades occurred in January 2023, when at least 72 people were killed after a Yeti Airlines flight went down near Pokhara, which government investigators later attributed to the aircraft's pilots accidentally cutting off the power.\n\nIn 1992, all 167 passengers on board a Pakistan International Airlines flight to Kathmandu died when the Airbus crashed on approach to the airport.\n\nSince 2000, more than {"uri": "8240743471", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "07:27:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T07:27:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T07:26:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5333333611488342, "url": "https://www.travelandtourworld.com/news/article/nepal-plane-crash-what-caused-the-saurya-airlines-tragedy-that-led-to-19-deaths/", "title": "Nepal Plane Crash: What Caused the Saurya Airlines Tragedy That Led to 19 Deaths? - Travel And Tour World", "body": "A Saurya Airlines plane carrying 19 people has slipped off the runway and crashed at Kathmandu airport, according to state television reports. The tragic accident occurred around 11 am while the plane was en route to Pokhara. As of now, Reuters has reported that 18 bodies have been recovered from the wreckage.\n\nThe aircraft, which included passengers and aircrew, faced the mishap leading to immediate and chaotic rescue operations. Rescue teams, including police and firefighters, are diligently working at the crash site to locate and assist any survivors. The pilot of the aircraft has been rushed to a hospital, a security official deployed at the airport confirmed.\n\nA fire that ignited from the aircraft upon crashing has been extinguished, adding a layer of relief amidst the chaos. However, the current conditions of the remaining passengers are still unknown, creating a tense atmosphere for the families awaiting news of their loved ones.\n\nThis tragic event is eerily reminiscent of a previous accident involving a Yeti Airlines flight last January. In that incident, a plane crashed near Nepal's Pokhara, killing all 72 people on board. The aircraft plunged into a steep gorge, disintegrating before bursting into flames. A government investigation later attributed the crash to pilot error.\n\nThe recurring nature of such accidents within Nepal's aviation sector raises serious concerns about the safety protocols and operational standards of airlines operating in the region. For passengers, this incident not only highlights the inherent risks associated with air travel but also instills a profound sense of fear and uncertainty. The thought of a plane slipping off the runway and crashing during what should be a routine flight creates a horror scenario that is every traveler's nightmare.\n\nThe aftermath of such crashes leaves a lasting impact on passengers' psyche, influencing their future travel choices. The fear of flying is exacerbated by news of these tragic accidents, potentially leading to a decline in airline passenger numbers. For those who have experienced such trauma, either directly or through the loss of loved ones, the emotional scars can be deep and enduring.\n\nMoreover, this incident casts a shadow over the operational integrity of Saurya Airlines and similar carriers. Passengers will demand greater transparency and stringent safety measures to ensure such tragedies are not repeated. The aviation industry must respond with enhanced safety protocols, rigorous training for pilots, and comprehensive maintenance checks for aircraft to restore passenger confidence.\n\nThe psychological horror of a plane crash is profound, extending beyond the immediate physical dangers. Passengers boarding a flight do so with an inherent trust in the airline's ability to transport them safely to their destination. When this trust is shattered by such catastrophic events, it leaves an indelible mark on the collective consciousness of air travelers.\n\nIn the wake of this crash, Saurya Airlines faces the daunting task of not only addressing the immediate needs of the victims and their families but also rebuilding its reputation. This involves a thorough investigation into the cause of the crash, transparent communication with the public, and implementing robust measures to prevent future incidents.\n\nFor the aviation industry as a whole, this crash serves as a stark reminder of the importance of adhering to the highest safety standards. Airlines must prioritize the welfare of their passengers and crew, ensuring that every flight is conducted with the utmost care and precision. Magazine.\n\nA pilot was the sole survivor of a plane crash in Nepal's capital city, Kathmandu.\n\nOn the morning of Wednesday, July 24, a plane carrying mostly Saurya Airlines company employees crashed when it caught fire while taking off from Tribhuvan International Airport around 11:15 a.m. local time, according to the BBC and the Associated Press.\n\nAirport chief Jagannath Niraula told BBC Nepali that the crash \"happened as soon as it left the ground, in not even a minute\", per the BBC.\n\nNepal's Civil Aviation Authority said that the plane \"crashed on the east side of the runway\" before bursting into flames, per CBS News.\n\nAuthorities say that 18 bodies were recovered, while the pilot was rescued from the burning debris. He sustained only injuries to his eyes and forehead and is currently being treated at a hospital.\n\nThe airport closed following the crash but was open again within hours, per Reuters.\n\nThe flight was en route to Pokhara for a standard maintenance appointment at the time, according to the BBC.\n\nCBS News reported that videos online showed the plane descending at a sharp angle before getting engulfed in flames following the crash.\n\nNever miss a story -- sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from celebrity news to human (Photo by Sulav Shrestha/Xinhua)\n\nKATHMANDU, July 24 (Xinhua) -- Eighteen dead bodies have been recovered after a plane crashed on Wednesday at the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal's capital, said Hansa Raj Pandey, spokesman at the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal (CAAN).\n\nPandey told Xinhua that one injured person has been hospitalized, and the airport has been closed over the incident.\n\nThe spokesman initially put the death toll at 22, but he corrected it later saying the rescue team double-counted three people.\n\nThe CAAN's search and rescue coordination center issued a statement, saying 18 were killed and 1 injured in the incident.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight bound for the city of Pokhara was carrying 19 people, and all of them were from the airline, said Pandey.\n\nA witness said the plane nosedived into the ground and an explosion could be heard inside the airport. \u25a0\n\nThis photo taken on July 24, 2024 shows the site of an air crash at the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu, Nepal. He was rescued from the burning wreckage and was rushed to the hospital for medical treatment.\n\nLocal news agencies reported that the crash occurred around 11:15 am (0530 GMT) when the airplane caught fire after skidding on the runway.\n\nThe flight was being conducted for technical or maintenance purposes, according to Gyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority.\n\nImages shared by Nepal's military showed the plane's fuselage split apart and burnt, with soldiers standing on top of the wreckage carrying out rescue efforts.\n\nNepal's aviation industry has struggled with poor safety standards due to insufficient training and maintenance, along with challenging mountainous terrain. The European Union has banned all Nepali carriers from its airspace due to safety concerns.\n\nThe country has witnessed several major commercial flight accidents in recent years. In January 2023, a Yeti Airlines service crashed while landing at Pokhara, resulting in the loss of all 72 lives on board. This incident was Nepal's deadliest since 1992, when a Pakistan International Airlines plane crashed on approach to Kathmandu airport, killing all 167 people.\n\nEarlier in 1992, a Thai Airways aircraft had also crashed near the same airport, claiming 113 lives.\n\nAt TOI World Desk, our dedicated team of seasoned journalists and passionate writers tirelessly sifts through the vast tapestry of global events to bring you the latest news and diverse perspectives round the clock. {"uri": "2024-07-432290840", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:31:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:31:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:24:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5215686559677124, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/travel/travel-truths/why-do-planes-crash-often-nepal/", "title": "Why planes crash so often in Nepal", "body": "Another fatal crash has occurred in one of the world's deadliest places to fly\n\nAt least 18 people have been killed after a small plane crashed and caught fire while it was taking off from Nepal's capital Kathmandu.\n\nThe Saurya Airlines flight was carrying two crew and 17 of the company's staff members, Dan Bahadur Karki, a Nepali police spokesman, said.\n\nThe crash raises fresh concerns about the safety of Nepalese skies. The country has seen 19 fatal aviation incidents since the turn of the century, with a total of 359 fatalities. Today's accident follows the crash of Yeti Airlines Flight 691 in January 2023, Nepal's deadliest in 30 years.\n\nAll Nepalese airlines have been banned from European airspace since 2013 over their poor safety records and while aviation regulators have noted some improvements in recent years, they say issues remain.\n\nHere, we consider why Nepal remains one of the world's most dangerous places to fly, and ask what passengers looking to travel there can do to minimise their risks.\n\nWhat caused the latest crash?\n\nThe causes of the latest crash remain unclear, but more details are likely to emerge in the coming days.\n\nThe plane crashed at around 11:15 am (05:30 GMT), the Nepali military said in a statement. News site Khabarhub reported that the aircraft had caught fire after skidding on the runway.\n\nThe plane was scheduled to fly on Nepal's busiest air route between Kathmandu and Pokhara, an important tourism hub in the Himalayan republic. Saurya Airlines exclusively flies Bombardier CRJ200s, according to its website. The crash leaves it with a fleet of just one aircraft.\n\nDoes Nepal suffer more crashes than other countries?\n\nYes. The crash is Nepal's 12th fatal air accident in as many years, a remarkable stat considering its relatively modest flight schedule.\n\nWhile there is no definitive global reference of aviation safety by country, by most metrics Nepal is one of the world's most dangerous places to fly.\n\nAs mentioned above, all Nepalese airlines have been banned from European airspace since 2013 over their poor safety records.\n\nAn International Civil Aviation Organisation audit of aviation safety in 2022 found that the level of implementation of certain elements of safety management in Nepal remained below the global average.\n\nAirlineRatings.com ranks Nepal Airlines in its bottom 14 airlines for safety, with just one star, alongside carriers from Iran and Suriname.\n\nWhat are the causes of Nepal's poor safety record?\n\nA combination of factors have led to Nepal's worrying record. AirlineRatings.com Editor-in-Chief Geoffrey Thomas lists three key reasons, including \"treacherous flying conditions in and around the Himalayas\", sometimes \"substandard pilot training and thus skills\", plus \"poor and dangerous airports which are often below world standards due to the mountainous terrain.\"\n\nThe country is home to many of the world's highest mountains, which makes it uniquely hazardous for pilots, who must navigate both the peaks and rapidly changing weather. Back in 2015, the United Nations' International Civil Aviation Organization prioritised the country for technical assistance, subsequently stating its \"beautiful but rugged terrain makes the safety of air operations more challenging than in other areas of the world.\"\n\nMountainous airports generally have shorter runways, which require higher pilot skill and can only accommodate smaller, sometimes less reliable aircraft. Nepal's Lukla Airport, the gateway to the Everest region, has previously been dubbed the world's most dangerous, an unwelcome but unsurprising title given its accident rate. The airport's runway is just 1,729 feet long (Heathrow's shortest is 12,008 feet) and ends abruptly at a brick wall. With rising mountains all around there is little opportunity for an aborted landing so pilots must get it right the first time. The airport's altitude also means the air is thinner so planes have no choice but to arrive faster, too.\n\nAs Nepal remains one of the poorest countries in Asia, it's unsurprising that some of its airlines have ageing fleets and its pilot training programmes might not rival those of western countries. Industry insiders have observed some older planes don't even have GPS systems. Still, according to the website Planespotters.net, the Saurya Airlines Bombardier CRJ200 aircraft involved in the latest crash (registration 9N-AME) was 21 years old - a fairly typical age for a commercial plane. The Yeti Airlines aircraft involved in the 2023 crash was only 15 years old.\n\nSome feel Nepalese authorities could do more to increase safety in the skies. After a 2022 crash involving Tara Air, Ashok Pokharel, president of the Nepal Association of Tour Operators, told the Guardian: \"The older aircraft don't have modern weather radars. That could be mandated so the captain has real-time weather information for what he is flying into.\"\n\nWhat can travellers do to lessen their risks?\n\nThose hoping to head out on bucket-list Everest trips or other Himalayan trekking holidays may be anxious about booking internal flights in the country, which, given the poor state of its roads, are hard to avoid.\n\nThe Foreign Office (FCDO) travel advice page for Nepal states: \"Air crashes can have a variety of causes and are not necessarily linked with poor safety standards or non-compliance with international safety standards. However, there have been a number of fatal accidents and air crashes across Nepal in the commercial air transport sector (involving planes and helicopters). Over the last five years, this includes a number of separate incidents and at least 100 deaths.\n\nIt adds: \"The UK Air Safety List (ASL) lists all known airlines in Nepal that do not meet international safety standards and are banned from operating commercial air services to or from the UK. Check the UK Air Safety List when considering whether to fly and which airlines to fly with. The list is maintained by the Department for Transport, based on advice from the UK Civil Aviation Authority.\n\n\"Currently no Nepali airline meets the international safety standards and so all are listed on the ASL. This means they are all banned from operating commercial air services to or from the UK.\"\n\nIn the end, tourists set on a trip may simply have to assess their own appetite for risk. As Geoffrey Thomas states: \"For travellers and adventure tourists there is little choice. Everest is dangerous to climb and so is flying there.\"\n\nThis article was first published in January 2023 and has been revised and updated.", "source": {"uri": "telegraph.co.uk", "dataType": "news", Captain Manish Ratna Shakya survived the incident.\n\nThe pilot, who was pulled from the flaming wreckage on Wednesday and he is the only survivor of the tragic accident and is presently undergoing treatment in a hospital.\n\nTwo crew members and seventeen corporate personnel, including technical staff, were on board the Saurya Airlines test flight. It was headed west, to Pokhara, the popular tourist destination in the Himalayas.\n\nThe aviation sector in Nepal has a poor safety record, which has been ascribed to a number of things over the years, including erratic weather patterns and loose laws.\n\nAs part of a routine maintenance check, the aircraft was headed for Pokhara when it crashed a few minutes after take-off from Tribhuvan International Airport. The crash occurred at approximately 11:15 local time (05:30 GMT), according to a statement from the search and rescue coordination centre of the Nepal Civil Aviation Authority.\n\nThe pilot got lacerations on his forehead and eyes, according to police spokeswoman Dan Bahadur Karki, but his life was not in jeopardy.\n\n\"There was a very loud noise, it sounded like maybe a truck had overturned on the road. The plane then hit the ground and caught fire. We were about to run to the site but then there was an explosion so we ran away again,\" a man present in a shop near the crash told the news agency.\n\nAccording to Saurya Airlines' website, Captain Manish Ratna Shakya, who pilots the CRJ200 regional aircraft has survived the crash. He serves as the airline's chief of operations. He worked for Simrik Airlines for over three years before joining Saurya Airlines, according to his LinkedIn profile. His time at St. Xavier's School is now over.\n\nAccording to the police, Captain Shakya, 37, was pulled from the wreckage and brought to KMC Hospital in Sinamangal for medical attention. With the verified deaths of eighteen of the nineteen passengers on board, he is the only survivor of the disaster.\n\nPrevious to this incident, on May 29, 2022, a Tara aircraft carrying 22 passengers including four Indians from Thane crashed in Nepal's rugged Mustang province, killing every person on board. It appears that the primary cause of aviation crashes in Nepal is bad weather. {"uri": "8240816141", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:14:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:14:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:13:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5176470875740051, "url": "https://www.moneycontrol.com/news/india/saurya-airlines-aircraft-crashes-in-kathmandu-why-nepal-is-prone-to-aviation-disasters-12776911.html", "title": "Saurya airlines aircraft crashes in Kathmandu: Why Nepal is prone to aviation disasters?", "body": "Nepal: Saurya Airlines plane carrying at least 19 people crashes during takeoff at Kathmandu airport.\n\nA Saurya airlines aircraft carrying 19 people onboard slipped off the runway and crashed on Wednesday in Nepal's Kathmandu airport. Wednesday's crash is the latest addition to the series of crash witnessed in the mountainous region over the last few decades. The plane was en route to the resort town of Pokhara.\n\nAccording to preliminary reports from Nepal state media, 18 people have succumbed to the crash. Nepal has been working to overcome its challenges in aviation.\n\nDespite the tragic casualty record, Nepal has stepped up its efforts to improve aviation safety.\n\nThe Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal has been focusing on improving safety in Nepali aviation - such as building improvements at airports, upgrading safety equipment, and fostering a positive safety culture by encouraging hazard reporting.\n\nNepal's considerable improvement in safety measures and compliance with international standards was recognised by ICAO in 2018. However, the country must continue work on its aviation reform to make its skies safe for everyone.\n\nThe ATR 72 aircraft is one typical aircraft used by Nepali carriers. It is a turboprop-powered regional aircraft with a capacity between 44 and 78 passengers. These aircraft are manufactured by a joint venture of Airbus in France and Leonardo in Italy.\n\nChallenging topography\n\nNepal, situated between India and China, is home to eight of the world's 14 highest mountains, including Mount Everest. For flight operations, it's an almost unrivalled, harsh environment with sudden weather changes that can make for hazardous conditions.\n\nAviation experts say commercial aircrafts in Nepal never get to a point where they are not fit to fly and still in operation. Most of the aircraft operating in Nepal are not brand new. They cost a lot and flying them may not be viable in an economically backward nation.\n\nThe unpredictable weather changes in the high terrains between takeoff and landing is the reason for most accidents. In these routes, most domestic flights use visual flight rules (VFR) in which the pilot controls and navigates the plane using visual references from outside.\n\nWhy 'table-top runways are prone to accidents\n\nTable-top runways are often constructed by excavating the peaks of hills create what is known as a table-top. Kathmandu airport is one with a table-top, making the runway vulnerable to air tragedies.\n\nSuch runways have steep drops at one or both ends, increasing the possibility of injuries and fatalities if pilots under or overshoot their approach, either through human error or mechanical failure.\n\nThey are most commonly found in mountainous areas where flat land is scarce, or in low-lying areas like Kozhikode in India where space is at a premium or there is fear of waterlogging at ground level.", "source": {"uri": "moneycontrol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "MoneyControl"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "2024-07-432149769", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "13:23:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T13:23:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T13:22:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://indianexpress.com/article/explained/kathmandu-plane-crash-kills-18-what-we-know-so-far-why-nepal-has-a-poor-aviation-safety-record-9473402/", "title": "Kathmandu plane crash kills 18: What we know so far, why Nepal has a poor aviation safety record", "body": "The aircraft, which belonged to regional carrier Saurya Airlines, was carrying two crew members and 17 technicians from Nepal's capital to the city of Pokhara for maintenance checks. Only pilot Manish Shankya survived the crash -- he is currently being treated at a nearby hospital for a head injury.\n\nNepal is notorious for its poor aviation safety record with multiple factors -- the country's challenging mountainous terrain, unpredictable weather, aging aircraft, poor infrastructure, and inadequate regulatory oversight -- leading to frequent accidents.\n\nWhat do we know about the crash on Wednesday?\n\nThe Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal (CAAN), in a press release, said that the ill-fated aircraft took off from the Tribhuvan International Airport at 11.11 am (Nepal Standard Time) on Wednesday. \"Shortly after takeoff from runway 02, the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" the press release said.\n\nAccording to eyewitness accounts, as quoted in The Kathmandu Post, the plane flipped after the wing-tip hit the ground during takeoff. Witnesses said that the aircraft immediately caught fire, and plunged deep into a gorge to the east of the runway. Multiple videos doing rounds on social media show the aircraft flying slightly above the runway before banking sharply to one side and crashing.\n\nWhat caused the crash?\n\nThis can happen due to a number of reasons including engine failure (the sharp bank could have been caused by one engine failing/stalling), faulty pre-flight planning (the plane was heavier than expected), other technical issues, or even pilot error. A proper investigation will shed further light into exactly what was behind the mishap on Wednesday.\n\nConditions on the airport, however, not all too bad. It is the monsoon season in Kathmandu, but it was not raining at the time of the crash although visibility was low across the capital.\n\nWhy does Nepal have such a poor aviation safety record?\n\nAccording to the Geneva-based Bureau of Aircraft Accidents Archives (B3A), Nepal has seen 68 aviation accidents since 1946, which have claimed a total of 900 lives. The Aviation Safety Network puts the number of fatal accidents (since 1919) at 41, with 878 total fatalities.\n\nThese numbers are very high, when taking into account the relatively low number of flights Nepal has seen takeoff or land on its soil. The rugged mountainous terrain, dearth of investment in new planes and infrastructure, and poor regulation have contributed to these crashes.\n\nIn Nepal, airstrips are often precariously placed on plateaus or cut mountains. They require a high degree of skill to land on, and are conducive to frequent accidents simply on the basis of pilot errors. Smaller runways are also capable of handling lighter, often single-engine, aircraft. These, however, are more susceptible to inclement weather which is common across Nepal.\n\nThe Kathmandu airport too is challenging for pilots. Although it boasts a relatively longer 3,350 m runway (compared to other Nepalese airports) allowing heavier aircraft to operate, this is still shorter than most major international airports. Given the altitude (1,338 m) at which the airport is located, this is more of a challenge -- in higher altitudes, aircraft need more speed to takeoff due to the thinner air.\n\nMoreover, constructed in the narrow, oval-shaped Kathmandu valley, the airport is sandwiched between jagged high mountains on all sides. This means pilots have less room in which to maneouvre their aircraft. The mountains also impact local weather conditions, and can lead to sudden turbulence and weather changes.\n\nAccording to reports, many of the aircraft operating in Nepal are aging and lack world class maintenance. Many lack equipment and facilities which are nowadays considered standard in other countries.\n\nThis is why all Nepal-based aircraft were banned from entering European airspace by the European Union in 2013. The Kathmandu Post reported in 2022 that behind the ban (which is still active) was the Nepal government's failure to act on improving aviation safety regulation and its implementation.\n\nCentral to this problem is the fact that Nepal's aviation regulator, CAAN, is also the country's primary service provider in the areas of 'air navigation services' and 'aerodrome operations'. This is a serious conflict of interest because effectively, CAAN is policing its own operations. In India, for example, the Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) is the regulator whereas the Airports Authority of India (AAI) provides air-navigation services and runs airports.", "source": They revealed that if the plane hadn't hit the container, it would have definitely crashed into a residential area.\n\nAadesh Lama, an eyewitness, said, 'I was working at my garage in the morning when I heard a loud sound. We initially thought it was a tyre burst but discovered it was a plane crash. It struck a container, saving the residential area from potential disaster.'\n\nAnother eyewitness, Krishna Bahadur Thapa, detailed the chaotic moments following the crash. 'I heard a loud bang and thought it was a vehicle accident. It turned out to be an aircraft. The plane slid down, stopped, then caught fire. I rushed to the site, heard an explosion, and ran back in fear,' Thapa told ANI.\n\nAccording to The Himalayan Times, a Saurya Airlines aircraft crashed during take-off at Tribhuvan International Airport on Wednesday. TIA officials confirmed 18 fatalities and one survivor, the pilot.\n\nGyanendra Bhul, information officer at TIA, confirmed that the CRJ 200 aircraft, registered as 9N-AME, was only carrying technical staff and no passengers. Unsettling pre-crash video has surfaced.\n\nNepal Plane Crash: Wednesday morning saw a terrible plane crash at Tribhuvan International Airport, Kathmandu, Nepal, killing 18 out of 19 passengers. A Saurya Airlines aircraft, in the air for Pokhara, encountered disaster barely minutes after takeoff at about 11 am.\n\nPlane Skids and Catches Fire During Ascent\n\nAccording to TIA spokesperson Premnath Thakur, the plane skidded off the runway during its ascent. The impact caused the aircraft to burst into flames with a thick billow of smoke covering the atmosphere. Panic and screams from the passengers were seen, eyewitnesses said, as the plane crashed and caught fire.\n\nThe police and firefighting emergency response teams immediately initiated firefighting and rescue operations. The blaze was tremendous in size, and for the firefighting teams to accomplish the job of extinguishing it, it was very overwhelming. It consumed a lot of time to get rid of the flames and prevent further damage. In the background, billows of smoke rose dramatically, in a somber show of just how bad this situation was.\n\nRushed to Medical Facility with Serious Injuries\n\nOf the 19 onboard, only the captain, identified as Shakya, survived with serious injuries. The captain was rushed to a nearby medical facility for treatment. The rest of 18 victims are still unidentified, and it has not been fully disclosed to the public as of now; the identity and condition of the deceased are still pending formal identification and notification of next of kin.\n\nThe Nepal government responded to the disaster by immediately dispatching military personnel into the town to join the search and rescue operations. Medical teams and army units have been mobilized to support ongoing operations for any survivors and to lend their support with aid. The extent of this blaze and the number of lost souls it has consumed have cast a pall of gloom over the incident, drawing countrywide and international concern and sympathy.\n\nAuthorities Probe Factors Behind Kathmandu Plane Crash\n\nAuthorities investigate the cause of the crash. According to them, factors are being probed for their possible contributions in making the aircraft fail during takeoff. This incident is one of the most tragic that Nepal remembers ever having witnessed an aviation accident, calling for a lot of review and close attention to safety protocols and emergency response procedures.\n\nThe investigation is still on, but all hands are on deck in ways of supporting the family of the victims and making sure such calamity does not occur again. {"uri": "8241637308", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:44:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:44:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:43:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/nepal-most-plane-crashes-world-163305713.html", "title": "Nepal has the most plane crashes in the world - how many more before it starts tackling safety?", "body": "Passenger aviation worldwide has become extraordinarily safe. In 2023, there were no fatal crashes involving passenger jet aircraft on scheduled flights.\n\nOf the two fatal accidents - both involving propellor aircraft - the first and deadliest was in Nepal. Yeti Airlines flight YT673 from Kathmandu crashe on approach to Pokhara. All 72 passengers and crew died in an accident attributed to pilot error.\n\nWe have yet to find out what went wrong with the latest tragedy, which took place on the same route. The Saurya Airlines commuter jet was taking off from the Nepali capital when it rolled and crashed into a ravine. The pilot survived but the remaining 18 on board did not.\n\nThe calamity takes Nepal to a tragic score of 14 crashes in 14 years - a rate way beyond any other country in the world.\n\nThe current sequence began in August 2010, when 14 people lost their lives on an Agni Air domestic flight from Kathmandu to Lukla, which had turned back due to a technical problem.\n\nTwenty-two more people died aboard a Tara Air Twin Otter during a domestic flight to Kathmandu in December 2010.\n\nIn September 2011, 19 people lost their lives on the approach to Kathmandu on a Buddha Air Beechcraft.\n\nA year later, seven British passengers were among the 19 people who died aboard a Sita Air Dornier 228 that came down shortly after take off from Kathmandu, destination Lukla. They were at the start of what was to be a three-week trek.\n\nThe crash was blamed on \"a combination of factors, including an overweight aircraft with too much luggage stowed on board\".\n\nThe litany of tragedy continues. Crashes in parts of Africa, South America and the former Soviet Union are far from unknown. But accident rates in Nepal are a different order of magnitude - resembling those from the early days of mass passenger air transport in the 1950s rather than the ultra-safe 2020s.\n\nThe challenging terrain and weather in Nepal demand pilots and engineers of the highest standards, but time and again they fall short.\n\nThe nation's airlines tend to use old, ill-maintained aircraft; the Saurya Airlines plane was over 20 years old, which is not an issue with good technical support. But Nepal has inadequate training in, and enforcement of, international aviation norms.\n\nAll Nepali airlines are banned from the European Union because of safety shortcomings.\n\nFor the past decade, the International Civil Aviation Organization has sought to improve safety under its \"No Country Left Behind\" initiative. The aim of this UN body is to harmonise \"Standards and Recommended Practices\" - those vital norms that keep the vast majority of passengers and crew. The aim is to give every nation \"access to the significant socio-economic benefits of a safe and reliable aviation system\".\n\nTravellers to the mountain kingdom must continue to weigh the risks of flying - while also being aware that Nepal's roads are lethal, too, with an accident rate six times higher than in the UK.\n\nThere is little hope that this litany of tragedy will end soon.", The incident is the latest in a tragic series of air disasters that have plagued the Himalayan country.\n\nSince 2000, Nepal has experienced nearly 360 fatalities in 19 air crashes, underscoring the perilous combination of adverse weather and treacherous landscapes. Notable recent incidents include a 2024 Bombardier CRJ 200 crash in Kathmandu that killed 18, and a 2023 Yeti Airlines disaster in Pokhara that claimed 72 lives -- marking the worst air crash since 1992.\n\nAmong other devastating accidents, a helicopter crash in 2019 killed the country's tourism minister, and a 2018 US-Bangla Airlines crash near Kathmandu airport resulted in 51 deaths. The Bombardier CRJ-200 aircraft of Saurya Airlines, carrying 19 people, including two crew members and technical staff of the airline, was bound for Pokhara International Airport for regular maintenance service when the accident occurred at 11.11 am (local time).\n\nAccording to Tribhuvan International Airport chief Jagannath Niraula, the plane flying from Kathmandu to Pokhara turned in the wrong direction. \"Shortly after takeoff from runway 02, the aircraft veered off to the right and crashed on the east side of the runway,\" said a statement issued by the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal.\n\n\"Technical glitches are regular in the newly built airports in Nepal due to quick completion by the Chinese for the advantage of an individual heading CAAN. The Pokhara airport is still not ready, but made available for the benefit of CAAN leadership. Unnecessary flights are also diverted to the airport to show it is operational,\" said the source from the aviation sector.\n\nALSO READ | With At Least 68 Plane Accidents So Far, What Makes Nepal Prone To Aviation Disasters?\n\nAccording to sources, the earlier Pokhara crash, where 72 people killed, and Wednesday's accident were due to the careless attitude of CAAN. \"Despite all efforts, seven domestic and four international flights are operating from Pokhara airport...The government is aware that these airports are not fully operational and services are also not that quick compared to the Tribhuvan airport,\" said sources.\n\nMeanwhile, the CAAN is pushing to build one more airport at Nijgadh. {"uri": "8240899190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:06:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:06:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:05:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://newsable.asianetnews.com/world/nepal-plane-crash-highlights-risks-of-table-top-runways-india-has-5-such-airports-ajr-sh4eh3", "title": "Nepal plane crash highlights risks of table-top runways; India has 5 such airports", "body": "India has five airports with table-top runways: Shimla, Calicut, Mangalore, Lengpui (Mizoram), and Pakyong (Sikkim). Both Calicut and Mangalore airports have experienced major crashes in the past.\n\nA tragic plane crash in Nepal that claimed as many as 18 lives has once again brought attention to the dangers linked with table-top runways, which have been the sites of several plane accidents globally. Table-top runways are elevated above the surrounding terrain, creating steep drops on one or more sides. This elevation leaves pilots with little margin for error, as overshooting the runway can result in the plane plummeting down the slope.\n\nIndia has five airports with table-top runways: Shimla, Calicut, Mangalore, Lengpui (Mizoram), and Pakyong (Sikkim). Both Calicut and Mangalore airports have experienced major crashes in the past. On May 22, 2010, Air India Express Flight 812 from Dubai to Mangaluru crashed on landing, killing 158 people, including six crew members.\n\nSaurya Airlines aircraft crashes in Kathmandu: Revisiting history of fatal plane crashes in Nepal\n\nTen years later, on August 7, 2020, another table-top runway in India became the site of a tragedy. An Air India Express flight from Dubai to Kozhikode, part of the Vande Bharat mission to repatriate Indians stranded by the COVID-19 pandemic, skidded off the runway and crashed. The accident claimed 19 lives, including both pilots, but 169 passengers survived.\n\nCivil aviation regulator, Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA) periodically reviews table-top airports to ensure passenger safety. In 2022, a DGCA official said that these reviews aim to prevent unforeseen incidents and make landings at these challenging airports safer.\n\nTable-top runways have also been the sites of crashes outside India. For instance, Madeira airport in Portugal witnessed a deadly accident in 1977 when an Air Portugal Flight 425 overshot the runway and crashed onto a beach, killing 131 people.\n\nNepal, with a poor air travel safety record, has also seen crashes on table-top runways. On May 27, 2017, a cargo plane crashed at Tenzing-Hillary Airport in Solukhumbu, another airport with such a runway.\n\nCaught on camera: Dramatic moment when out-of-control Saurya Airlines plane crashed in Kathmandu (WATCH)\n\nIn the recent crash in Nepal, a Bombardier CRJ 200 flight skidded off the runway at Tribhuvan Airport in Kathmandu and burst into flames. The airport, located atop a plateau surrounded by deep gorges and valleys, is considered one of the riskiest to land at.\n\nIt was also the site of a devastating crash in 1992 when a Pakistan International Airlines plane crashed, killing 167 people. The Saurya Airlines flight involved in the latest crash was en route to Pokhara and had crew and technical staff on board.", "source": {"uri": "newsable.asianetnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8240859849", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "08:41:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T08:41:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T08:40:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4666666686534882, "url": "https://kmaupdates.com/2024/07/24/just-in-saurya-airlines-plane-crashes-in-kathmandu/", "title": "JUST IN: Saurya Airlines plane crashes in Kathmandu - Kmaupdates", "body": "A Saurya Airlines aircraft crashed during takeoff at the Tribhuvan International Airport in Kathmandu on Wednesday. Casualties have been reported.\n\nThe accident occurred after the Pokhara-bound flight suffered a runway excursion during takeoff, said TIA Spokesperson Subash Jha.\n\nNineteen people, including crew members, were aboard the plane. As per preliminary information, eighteen bodies have been recovered from the crash site.\n\nCaptain MR Shakya has been rushed to hospital, said Jha.\n\nEyewitnesses say that the plane was taking off from the Southern-end of the runway (Koteshwor side) and suddenly flipped with the wing tip hitting the ground. The aircraft caught fire immediately. {"uri": "8240787546", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "07:55:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T07:55:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T07:55:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/nepal-plane-crash-kathmandu-crash-nepal-crash-puts-spotlight-on-table-top-runways-risk-india-has-5-of-them-6176860", "title": "Nepal Crash Puts Spotlight On Table-Top Runways Risk, India Has 5 Of Them", "body": "Five airports in India have table-top runways and two of them have reported crashes big in the past\n\n18 people were killed in the plane crash at Nepal's Kathmandu today\n\nThe plane crash in Nepal that left 18 people dead has yet again put the spotlight on table-top runways that have been the site of major plane accidents across the world.\n\nTable-top runways are located on an elevated level than the surrounding terrain. This means there is a steep drop on one or more sides of the runway and this leaves a very slim margin of error for the pilot because if the plane overshoots the runway, it will crash down.\n\nFive airports in India have table-top runways -- Shimla, Calicut, Mangalore, Lengpui (Mizoram) and Pakyong (Sikkim). Of these, Kerala and Mangalore airports have seen big crashes in the past. On May 22, 2010, Air India Express Flight 812 from Dubai to Mangaluru crashed on landing at and 158 passengers, including six crew members, were killed.\n\nTen years later, on August 7, 2020, another table-top runway became the site of a tragedy. The Air India Express flight from Dubai to Kozhikode was part of the Vande Bharat mission to bring back Indian nationals stranded due to Covid pandemic. The plane skidded off the table-top runway and crashed below. Nineteen passengers and both pilots died, but 169 others survived.\n\nCivil Aviation regulator, Directorate General of Civil Aviation, holds periodical reviews of table-top airports to ensure passenger safety. Back in 2022, an official of the DGCA had told the media that the objective behind the review was to prevent any unforeseen incidents and look for ways to make landings in these airports less challenging.\n\nPortugal's Madeira airport, which has a table-top runway, reported a crash back in 1977 when an Air Portugal Flight 425 overshot and crashed onto a beach, killing 131 people.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nEven Nepal, which has a poor air travel safety record, has reported crashes involving table-top runways in the past. On May 27, 2017, a cargo plane at crashed at the Tenzing-Hillary airport in Solukhumbu, which has such a runway.\n\nIn the crash that took place this morning, the Bombardier CRJ 200 flight skidded off the runway and burst into flames, a spokesperson of the airport has told NDTV. Tribhuvan airport in Kathmandu, where the crash took place, is on the top of a plateau and is surrounded by deep gorges and valleys on all sides. Kathmandu airport is among the most risky airports to land and was the site of a huge crash back in 1992, when 167 passengers of a Pakistan International Airlines plane had died. The Saurya Airlines flight that crashed today had crew and technical staff on board and was on its way to Pokhara.", "source": {"uri": "ndtv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NDTV"}, "authors": {"uri": "8240922190", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "09:20:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T09:20:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T09:19:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4274509847164154, "url": "https://www.wionews.com/south-asia/nepal-plane-crash-tribhuvan-airport-with-tabletop-field-is-one-of-scariest-to-land-on-or-take-off-from-743711", "title": "Nepal plane crash kills 18: Tribhuvan Airport with tabletop runway one of scariest to land or take off", "body": "Nepal plane crash: The Nepal plane crash on Wednesday (July 24) that killed at least 19 people is the latest such accident in Tribhuvan International Airport (TIA), which is considered one of the toughest to land on or take off from. Located in Kathmandu's Bagmati, TIA has a 'tabletop' runway. That and other factors like high altitude, weather changes and Himalayan terrain are the reasons why Tribhuvan airport is the site of several crashes.", "source": {"uri": "wionews.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8242204809", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "02:02:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T02:02:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T02:01:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4235294163227081, "url": "https://kathmandupost.com/national/2024/07/25/planes-are-coming-down-nepali-state-is-least-bothered", "title": "Planes are coming down. Nepali state is least bothered", "body": "A plane flies above the wreckage of the Saurya Airlines aircraft that crashed shortly after takeoff at the Kathmandu airport on Wednesday. Angad Dhakal/TKP\n\nThere is a saying about Nepal's aviation industry: Every new tourism minister is greeted by at least one crash.\n\nThis is because the industry is beset by deep-rooted corruption and mismanagement as the country builds airports worth billions of rupees but fails to attract flights. Improving safety remains a far cry.\n\nOn different occasions, global aviation watchdogs have voiced serious concerns about the capability of Nepal's civil aviation authority to oversee safety issues.\n\nIn the past year and a half, more than 100 people have lost their lives in plane crashes -- despite air travel being the world's safest and most regulated industry in the world.\n\nWednesday's crash is the seventh under Pradip Adhikari, the director general of the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal who fits into all political systems, and the fourth fatal one of his tenure.\n\nHere are a few examples of how policy corruption has paralysed the Nepali aviation industry, the lifeline of the country's tourism industry and transport in the mountain region.\n\nA few years back, a parliamentary sub-committee headed by Madhav Kumar Nepal had ordered the government to immediately split the civil aviation body due to its dual role of doing business and regulating the sector.\n\nNepal, the CPN (Unified Socialist) leader, sent Prem Ale to head the tourism ministry a few months later. Ale stopped the bills from being tabled in the lower house for discussion, although the upper house had passed them.\n\nThen, Jeevan Ram Shrestha was appointed tourism minister. On his first day, he announced that he would wait to meet the European Commission's request to separate Nepal's civil aviation into regulatory and service-providing organisations.\n\nAfter that, Sudan Kirati was picked as the tourism minister by the Maoist Centre. He took the initiative to register the civil aviation bills in Parliament.\n\nKirati had accused Director General Adhikari of consistently failing to ensure aviation safety, as five aircraft incidents and accidents, including three major disasters, have occurred under Adhikari's watch.\n\nSources said then-prime minister Pushpa Kamal Dahal summoned Kirati and Adhikari and ordered them to work \"in tandem\". Kirati then stopped talking about the separation.\n\nThe issue was then taken up by the parliamentary International Relations and Tourism Committee, which directed Dahal, then prime minister, to table the civil aviation bills in the House of Representatives as soon as possible. The directive was issued in December last year.\n\n\"The bills have been languishing for a long time. As we doubt the civil aviation ministry will table them in Parliament, we have directed the Prime Minister's Office to do so,\" Raj Kishore Yadav, chairman of the committee, had told the Post.\n\nA few months later, when the Post approached Yadav to inquire about any progress on the bills, Yadav replied that a split \"was not necessary\". The budget for this fiscal year, too, makes no mention of the plan to split the aviation body, after including it in the federal government's document for three consecutive years.\n\nIn April, lawmaker and member of the International Relations and Tourism Committee Udaya Shumsher Rana told an interaction that he was informed by a former tourism minister that there is an \"invisible\" hand preventing the passage of two crucial civil aviation bills.\n\nIn August 2022, the International Civil Aviation Organisation, the United Nations aviation watchdog, formally asked Nepal to split the civil aviation body and ensure a proper regulatory system. However, the Civil Aviation Authority chose to keep the report secret.\n\nA former director general said the tourism industry is bearing the repercussions as planes come down each passing year due to a lax regulatory system. \"People are dying due to 'policy corruption.'\"\n\nOn a sunny Wednesday, nineteen people, including two crew members, were on the Saurya Airlines flight to Pokhara. The 50-seater bombardier CRJ 200 with registration mark 9N-AME was flying 15 technicians to the city, where the jet's heavy maintenance C-check was planned.\n\nAt 11:11 am, the plane took off from the runway's southern end (Koteshwar). But just a few seconds after the takeoff, people around the airport heard a loud \"bang\".\n\n\"That was an unusual sound. It was a big bang like a bomb [exploding],\" said a top official of a private airline, who was a close witness to the crash.\n\nVideo footage obtained by the Post shows that the jet rolled and climbed around 80-90ft from the ground. It then tilted towards the right and instantly came down. It hit the ground and burst into flames.\n\nThe plane then rolled down into a ravine.\n\nThe cockpit slammed into a cargo container, and it was stuck there, which observers say saved the pilot-in-command, Manish Ratna Shakya, the chief of the operation department at Saurya Airlines.\n\n\"The pilot survived. He is in stable condition,\" said DIG Dan Bahadur Karki, spokesperson for Nepal Police. \"It was a miracle.\"\n\nThe fuselage came apart, hit the slope of the tabletop airport, and ricocheted 50 metres away, finally coming to rest on the muddy ground.\n\nEighteen people, including the co-pilot and a foreigner, died. The cockpit and tail were intact.\n\nThe 21.4-year-old aircraft was inducted into the Saurya Airlines fleet on March 14, 2017.\n\nCCTV footage shows that the nature of the crash was similar to last January's Yeti Airlines crash in Pokhara.\n\nExperts suspect many factors, including an engine failure, a bird strike, and poor maintenance.\n\n\"The investigation will tell the truth,\" said Subash Jha, spokesman for Kathmandu's Tribhuvan International Airport. This is the second biggest crash inside the Kathmandu airport after the US Bangla, a Dhaka-based airline, accident in March 2018 killed 52 of the 71 passengers aboard.\n\nExperts observing the crash closely say that, given the nature of the plane's fall, the right engine might have stopped working and the aircraft eventually lost the \"control panel\" mode. This narrow panel, located centrally in front of the pilot, can be used to control heading, speed, altitude, vertical speed, vertical navigation, and lateral navigation.\n\n\"The aircraft has banked,\" said an aircraft engineer. A banked turn (or banking turn) is a turn or change of direction in which the aircraft banks or inclines, usually towards the inside of the turn.\n\n\"Had it been the left engine, it could have potentially crashed into at least two big planes parked at the tarmac of the airport and the domestic terminal. The impact was huge. The plane just exploded.\"\n\nOne official at the safety department of the civil aviation body suspected a potential bird strike. \"What happens when a bird enters an aircraft engine? If an aircraft engine ingests a bird, it can result in engine failure.\"\n\n\"In such a case, if the pilot failed to judge and identify which of the two engines is the problematic one, it could lead to such a situation.\"\n\nBut a senior airline executive countered the argument.\n\n\"The aircraft has two engines. Even if one engine fails, it would be difficult to climb, but only if it has a full load. The 50-seater plane was carrying just 17 people, a third of its capacity. I don't believe a bird strike downed the plane.\"\n\nHe, however, suspects poor maintenance. On Wednesday, the plane had taken off after 30 days on the ground.\n\nIn many cases, a plane stored for several weeks or months could encounter problems if it is flown without a proper inspection. Saurya does not have a hangar in Kathmandu.\n\nA civil aviation body official confirmed that the 9N-AME had been on the ground for 30 days.\n\n\"The engine exploded. Given the nature of the explosion, foreign object damage (FOD) to an aircraft engine can be suspected. FOD happens when a foreign object impacts the engine. Since there are no proper hangers for the storage of its planes in Kathmandu, FOD cannot be ruled out,\" said the expert, dismissing the bird strike theory.\n\nA senior air safety specialist, who wished not to be named because the investigation is ongoing, said both events -- a bird strike and FOD -- cannot be ruled out.\n\n\"Only the flying captain, the lone survivor, and the black box can tell us what exactly happened,\" said the air safety specialist. \"However, to stop unnecessary rumours, the investigation team should record the captain's statement and release a preliminary report immediately.\"\n\nAviation analyst Hemanta Arjyal wrote on the social media platform X: \"We do not know what actually happened in today's crash, but engine seems to be the culprit. And technically, IF a multi-engine aircraft suffers an engine failure during the takeoff roll, THE AIRCRAFT WILL YAW TOWARDS THE FAILED ENGINE.\"\n\nThe airline company has been in a financial crisis for several years. Its financial health deteriorated especially after the Covid pandemic.\n\nLast year, it submitted a plan to the civil aviation body to switch to ATR-72-type aircraft and promised to maintain safety standards of the existing fleet until it imported the ATR planes. However, airline officials say they could not secure investment to replace their fleet.\n\nHowever, the civil aviation body overlooked the airline's financial condition, which is obviously a major safety concern.\n\n\"With Nepal's key festival just over two months away, Saurya, which had a total of three aircraft, was planning a full maintenance of the Bombardier that crashed on Wednesday to remain afloat. The Bombardier CRJ200 had 200 engine hours left for full maintenance,\" according to insiders. Full maintenance alone does not necessarily ensure full safety of flights.\n\nNow the airline is left with just one airworthy plane, and authorities are unlikely to allow the company to operate for the same reason. Prime Minister KP Sharma Oli paid a rare visit to the crash site on Wednesday.\n\nSaurya Airlines had also laid off staff due to financial problems last year. Despite several attempts, the airline officials could not be reached for comments.\n\nAccording to insiders, poor aircraft maintenance could be one of the potential crash factors, as keeping planes airworthy is costly.\n\nEngineers who wrote \"fit to fly\" too died in the crash.\n\nYet in the immediate aftermath of the crash, there is also a lot of confusion.\n\nAnother aviation expert ruled out the possibility of poor maintenance. \"The entire maintenance team was on the plane. Why would they be on a suicide mission if the plane was ill-maintained?\"\n\nHowever, the crash has shed light on different aspects of regulatory failure.\n\nIt was later found that among the entire maintenance team, two passengers [one child and a woman], the son and wife of a Saurya technician, were flown in the plane cleared for maintenance, which is against the rule.\n\n\"This suggests the regulator's negligence,\" said Sanjiv Gautam, former director general of the Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal. \"How can the regulator allow passengers on the ferry flight? That's sheer negligence.\"\n\nA ferry flight involves flying an aircraft from one location to another without passengers or cargo, typically for maintenance purposes.\n\nAviation in Nepal is beset with deep-set corruption and mismanagement.\n\nThe frequent crashes have deterred foreign tourists. Especially high-end tourists have been avoiding travel outside Kathmandu by air because they worry about safety, according to tour operators.\n\nGlobal aviation watchdogs have questioned the civil aviation body's dual role and urged Nepal to split the organisation into two entities -- service provider and regulator -- to enhance the safety of flyers.\n\nHowever, successive governments have not shown much interest, although they have spent over Rs 500 million on drafting the civil aviation bills.\n\nFollowing the September 2012 crash of Sita Air Flight 601 in the Manohara river, which killed 19 people, including seven British citizens, the European Commission imposed a blanket ban on Nepali airlines from flying into the 27-nation bloc in December 2013.\n\nIt's been 11 years, and the ban has not been lifted as Nepal has failed to address safety deficiencies.\n\nAccording to Nepal's civil aviation body, nearly 950 people have died in air crashes in the country since the first disaster was recorded in August 1955. And just in a year and a half, more than 100 people have perished in air crashes, indicating higher casualties as bigger aircraft are involved in recent accidents.\n\nIn January 2023, a Yeti Airlines plane crashed in Pokhara, killing all 72 people on board, in the third biggest air accident in terms of casualties. The crash happened two weeks after the inauguration of the China-funded airport.\n\nThe first big air accident in Nepal happened on September 28, 1992, when an Airbus A310 belonging to Pakistan International Airlines slammed into a hillside at Bhattedanda near the Kathmandu Valley, killing 167 people on board.\n\nBefore that, on July 31, 1992, an Airbus A310 of Thai Airways crashed in Ghyangphedi, killing 113 on board.\n\nThe government on Wednesday formed a five-member commission headed by Ratish Chandra Lal Suman, former director general of Civil Aviation Authority of Nepal, to investigate the crash.", "source": {"uri": "kathmandupost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "kathmandupost.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saurya_Airlines", {"uri": "8241233345", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "12:25:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T12:25:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T12:25:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4117647111415863, "url": "https://www.urdupoint.com/en/world/plane-crash-in-nepal-claims-18-lives-with-so-1846665.html", "title": "Plane Crash In Nepal Claims 18 Lives, With Sole Pilot Survivor   - UrduPoint", "body": "Nepal has a troubling history with aviation safety, experiencing numerous fatal accidents involving small planes and helicopters over the years.\n\nKATHMANDU: (UrduPoint/UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News-July 24, 2024) A passenger plane crashed during takeoff in Kathmandu on Wednesday, resulting in the tragic death of all 18 passengers aboard, while the pilot was rescued from the burning wreckage and is currently receiving medical treatment, according to police in Nepal's capital.\n\nNepal has a troubling history with aviation safety, experiencing numerous fatal accidents involving small planes and helicopters over the years.\n\nThe ill-fated Saurya Airlines flight was carrying two crew members and 17 employees of the airline, stated Nepali police spokesman Dan Bahadur Karki.\n\n\"The pilot has been rescued and is being treated,\" Karki said, adding, \"Eighteen bodies have been recovered, including one foreign national. The process of transporting them for post-mortem examinations is underway.\"\n\nGyanendra Bhul of Nepal's Civil Aviation Authority mentioned that the flight was either for technical or maintenance purposes but did not provide additional details.\n\nBoth Karki and Bhul could not confirm the nationality of the sole foreigner aboard.\n\nPhotos shared by Nepal's military displayed the plane's fuselage split and charred. Approximately a dozen soldiers in camouflage were seen on the wreckage, with the surrounding ground covered in fire retardant.\n\nThe crash occurred around 11:15 am local time (0530 GMT), with the military noting that their quick response team was aiding in rescue efforts.\n\nSaurya Airlines operates Bombardier CRJ 200 jets, as stated on its website.\n\nNepal's aviation industry has grown rapidly in recent years, transporting goods and passengers to remote areas, as well as catering to foreign trekkers and climbers. However, the industry has struggled with safety issues due to inadequate training and maintenance, exacerbated by the country's challenging mountainous terrain.\n\nThe European Union has prohibited all Nepali carriers from its airspace due to safety concerns.\n\nThe Himalayan nation has some of the world's most difficult runways, surrounded by snow-capped peaks and requiring approaches that challenge even the most skilled pilots. Fire engines and ambulances were rushed to the spot after the incident.\n\nOf the deceased, 15 died on the spot while three died during treatment at a local hospital, authorities said. A Yemeni national, who was an airline staff, also died in the crash.\n\nPrime Minister KP Sharma Oli said he was deeply saddened by the tragic deaths in the crash and was at the site to inquire about the cause of the air crash with the Civil Aviation Authority's officials. He urged all for patience at this hour of grief.
